1 of 500 DOCUMENTS




The Daily Telegraph (London)


October 2, 2014 Thursday  
Edition 2;
National Edition


Ebola 'will soon become an economic disaster'


BYLINE: Elizabeth Anderson


SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. 5


LENGTH: 417 words


THE head of the World Bank has said the world has an economic duty, as well as a moral duty, to respond to Ebola before the disease spreads further.

Jim Yong Kim said that lessons were having to be learned again about the "terrible consequences" of responding too slowly to a pandemic. 

He said global leaders had left it too late to come to the aid of the three countries most affected by Ebola - Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone - and that the epidemic could spread further afield.

His speech came after the first case of Ebola was diagnosed in America. The unidentified patient, who was being kept in isolation in Dallas, Texas, is thought to have contracted the virus in Liberia before travelling to the US nearly two weeks ago.

The news spooked investors, pushing the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 238.19 points, or 1.4pc, to 16,804.71 last night.

The World Bank estimates that the disease could cost the three African countries $809m (£500m) by next year if it continues to spread. In Liberia, the hardest-hit country, it predicts that Ebola could reduce output by 11.7pc in 2015, costing the country $93m and reducing GDP growth from 6.8pc to -4.9pc.

"Inflation and food prices were initially contained but are now rising in response to shortages, panic buying and speculation," the World Bank said.

"Exchange rate volatility has increased in all three countries, particularly since June, fuelled by uncertainty and some capital flight."

The institution added that the "fear of contagion" was affecting labour movement, disrupting transportation and has forced the closure of sea ports and airports.

The World Bank has come up with a $230m finance package for the African countries affected so far. But it thinks a total of $1bn in aid could be needed.

The World Health Organisation first reported an Ebola outbreak in March this year and by August it had declared the epidemic an international public health emergency.

The often-fatal illness has infected around 6,500 people in Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone so far, with more than 3,000 deaths. The disease, which is not contagious until symptoms appear, is spread via close contact with bodily fluids.

Health officials have predicted that deaths from other infectious diseases are likely to rise as the countries' health systems feel the strain.

Health problems such as obesity and diabetes can have an ongoing impact on a country's economy, but epidemics attract more attention from economists because of their short-term significance.


LOAD-DATE: October 2, 2014


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: AP/MICHAEL DUFFFear of contagion is disrupting labour movement and transporation in Sierra Leone

2 of 500 DOCUMENTS




The Daily Telegraph (London)


October 2, 2014 Thursday  
Edition 1;
National Edition


Children exposed to US Ebola victim;
Hospital sent home Liberian infected with disease UN confirms its first death as toll in west Africa passes 3,300


BYLINE: Nick Allen


SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 20


LENGTH: 559 words


UP TO 18 people in America, including five children, may have been exposed to Ebola after coming into direct contact with the first patient to be diagnosed with the disease on US soil.

Thomas Eric Duncan, who arrived in Dallas, Texas, from Liberia on Sept 20, was infectious for up to eight days and health officials are already examining a second potential case in someone close to him.

They said the children who encountered Mr Duncan and who went to four different schools in Dallas were "priority number one" and would be closely observed for any symptoms over the next three weeks, the incubation period for the disease. Mr Duncan, who is from Monrovia, Liberia, and has also lived in Accra, Ghana, was visiting relations in Dallas including his sister, Mai Wureh. 

She described how he had gone to Texas Health Presbyterian Hospital on Sept 26 but was given a prescription for antibiotics and told to go home. According to Miss Wureh, he told the hospital he was visiting from Liberia, but it failed to suspect he was suffering from Ebola.

Eventually, on Sept 28, an ambulance was called and took him back to the hospital where he was diagnosed with the disease and placed in isolation. He is in a "serious" condition but doctors said he was "awake, talking and hungry".

Meanwhile, the United Nations said yesterday that a staff member in Liberia had died from "probable Ebola". A spokesman for Ban Ki-moon, the UN secretary-general, said it was the first death of a UN staffer in the outbreak that has so far killed more than 3,300 people in west Africa. The victim was Liberian.

In Texas, Zach Thompson, the director of Dallas county health and human services, said the children who had been in contact with the infected man were "priority number one".

He said: "The precaution is to keep the children home. We will evaluate and they will be monitored. The fact that we have one confirmed case ... there may be another case that is a close associate with this particular patient. So, I want to be frank, this is real."

The group being monitored includes two fire service paramedics and their intern who were sent to pick up the patient.

Tests on the paramedics have so far proved negative but they have been isolated for three weeks.

An ambulance they used had remained in service for another 48 hours but has now been decontaminated and quarantined.

Dr Tom Frieden, the director of the US Centres for Disease Control and Prevention, said: "It's possible that someone who had contact with this individual could develop Ebola in the coming weeks."

He urged people not to panic, saying the disease would be "stopped in its tracks". But after the diagnosis was announced, social media networks exploded, with up to 50,000 mentions of Ebola in an hour on Twitter.

Dallas has a Liberian community of about 10,000. Stanley Gaye, president of the Liberian Community Association of Dallas-Fort Worth, said: "We've been telling people to try to stay away from social gatherings. We need to know who it is so that they can all go get tested."

A Liberian official confirmed that Mr stopped in Brussels on his way to the US. But health officials said there was "zero" chance of him being infectious during the flight because he did not have symptoms at that point.

An investigation has been opened at the hospital to see why he was not admitted on his first visit.


LOAD-DATE: October 2, 2014


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


JOURNAL-CODE: DTL

The Daily Telegraph (London)


October 2, 2014 Thursday  
Edition 2;
National Edition


Children exposed to US Ebola victim;
oHospital sent home Liberian infected with disease #UN confirms its first death as toll in west Africa passes 3,300


BYLINE: Nick Allen


SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 20


LENGTH: 563 words


UP TO 18 people in America, including five children, may have been exposed to Ebola after coming into direct contact with the first patient to be diagnosed with the disease on US soil.

Thomas Eric Duncan, who arrived in Dallas from Liberia on Sept 20, was infectious for up to eight days and health offi-cials are already examining a second potential case in someone close to him.

They said the children who encountered him and who went to four different schools in the Texan city were "priority number one" and would be closely observed for any symptoms over the next three weeks, the incubation period. Mr Duncan, who is from Monrovia, Liberia, appears to have contracted the disease while helping carry a stricken pregnant woman to a hospital there. 

He has also lived in Accra, Ghana, and was visiting relations in Dallas including his sister, Mai Wureh.

She said he had gone to Texas Health Presbyterian Hospital on Sept 26 but was given a prescription for antibiotics and told to go home. According to Miss Wureh, he told the hospital he was visiting from Liberia, but it failed to suspect he was suffering from Ebola.

Eventually, on Sept 28, an ambulance was called and took him back to the hospital where he was diagnosed with the disease and placed in isolation. He is in a "serious" condition but doctors said he was "awake, talking and hungry".

Meanwhile, the United Nations said yesterday that a local staff member in Liberia had died from "probable Ebola", the first death of a UN employee in the outbreak that has so far killed more than 3,300 people in west Africa.

Bill Gates announced that his foundation will offer a $50 million (£30 million) fund to help tackle the Ebola outbreak, its largest single endowment to date.

In Texas, Zach Thompson, the director of Dallas county health and human services, said the children who had been in contact with the infected man were "priority number one". He said: "The precaution is to keep the children home. The fact that we have one confirmed case ... there may be another case that is a close associate with this particular patient. So, I want to be frank, this is real."

The group being monitored includes two paramedics and their intern who were sent to pick up the patient.

Tests on them so far have proved negative but they have been isolated for three weeks. An ambulance they used had remained in service for another 48 hours but has now been decontaminated and quarantined.

Dr Tom Frieden, the director of the US Centres for Disease Control and Prevention, said: "It's possible that someone who had contact with this individual could develop Ebola in the coming weeks."

He urged people not to panic, saying the disease would be "stopped in its tracks". But social media networks saw heavy traffic on the subject, with up to 50,000 mentions of Ebola in an hour on Twitter.

The hospital is investigating why Mr Duncan was not originally admitted.

Dallas has a Liberian community of about 10,000. Stanley Gaye, president of the Liberian Community Association of Dallas-Fort Worth, said: "We've been telling people to try to stay away from social gatherings. We need to know who it is so that they can all go get tested."

A Liberian official confirmed that Mr Duncan had stopped in Brussels on his way to the US. But officials said there was "zero" chance of him being infectious during the flight as he had no symptoms at that time.

4 of 500 DOCUMENTS




The Guardian (London) - Final Edition


October 2, 2014 Thursday


Ebola sufferer was sent home from US hospital: Staff were told he had just returned from Liberia: Vomiting patient finally admitted two days later


BYLINE: Tom Dart in Dallas and Lauren Gambino in New York


SECTION: GUARDIAN INTERNATIONAL PAGES; Pg. 19


LENGTH: 533 words


The first patient to be diagnosed with Ebola outside Africa told medical staff he had recently travelled from Liberia, but was not admitted to hospital until he returned two days later, health officials in Texas said yesterday. 

Thomas Eric Duncan told a nurse he had just travelled from the west African country, which has been ravaged by the Ebola outbreak, but the information was not widely enough shared with the medical team, said a spokesman for Texas Health Presbyterian hospital.

Duncan's sister, Mai Wureh, told the Associated Press he first visited the hospital's emergency room on Friday, but was sent home with antibiotics - an outcome Texas health chiefs describe as a matter of regret. He was admitted only after his condition worsened and he returned to the hospital on Sunday. Yesterday his condition was described as serious but stable.

Speaking at the apartment complex where Duncan was staying, Mesud Osmanovic, 21, a fellow resident, said he saw the ambulance arrive.

"When it came, his whole family were all screaming, he got outside and he was throwing up all over the place . . . when he was throwing up he was trying to walk and he couldn't walk," Osmanovic said. He said Duncan was helpful to neighbours, adding: "I know him through his family . . . this ain't his first time coming to America. He was a quiet guy, a really nice guy."

Texas governor Rick Perry said school-age children who may have been in contact with the patient were being monitored at home for signs of the disease.

Mark Lester, a senior executive at Texas Health Resources, which operates the hospital, said medical staff used an Ebola checklist on his first visit, which included a question about travel history. "Regretfully, that information was not fully communicated throughout the full team. As a result the full import of that question was not factored in to the clinical decision-making," he said.

That failure led staff to conclude that Duncan's symptoms were "not yet typical" for Ebola and that he was suffering from a "low-grade, common viral disease".

Duncan was vomiting when the ambulance got to the hospital, said Dallas city spokeswoman Sana Syed. Three of the ambulance crew have tested negative for the virus but were restricted to their homes while their conditions were observed.

The Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), the federal public health agency, has sent a team of nine to Texas to assist officials. "If anyone develops fever, we'll immediately isolate them to stop the chain of transmission," said Tom Frieden, director of the CDC.

David Lakey, commissioner of the Texas department of state health services, said: "This is not west Africa. This is a very sophisticated city, a very sophisticated hospital, and the dynamics are so significantly different than they are in west Africa that the chances of it being spread are very, very, very small."

Last night a spokeswoman for United Airlines said the carrier believes it flew Duncan from Brussels to Dallas Fort Worth via Washington on 20 September.

The CDC said there was "zero risk of transmission" on these two flights because the patient showed no symptoms at the time and therefore could not have been contagious.


LOAD-DATE: October 2, 2014


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2014 Guardian Newspapers Limited
All Rights Reserved


5 of 500 DOCUMENTS




The Guardian (London) - Final Edition


October 2, 2014 Thursday


Disease outbreak accelerates across west Africa


BYLINE: Monica Mark, West Africa correspondent


SECTION: GUARDIAN INTERNATIONAL PAGES; Pg. 19


LENGTH: 321 words


Health workers in west Africa have warned that promises of international aid have failed to translate into a meaningful response on the ground in Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone, where Ebola has now killed about 3,100 people. 

Joanne Liu, president of Medecins sans Frontieres, said that rhetoric had to be translated into action. "Everybody in their intentions (is) moving fast, but in the field we are moving at the speed of a turtle," she told National Public Radio, in the US.

Each day doctors are removing the dead from their beds and admitting the same number of patients to the MSF treatment centre in the Liberian capital, Monrovia.

"We only open one of our centres for 30 minutes, just to admit people who can fill the beds of the people who died overnight. This is how bad it is. The rest of the day we are turning patients back home to go and infect their neighbours and loved ones."

The UN, in its first mission for a public health emergency, opened a regional HQ in Accra, Ghana this week, which will serve as an air bridge to affected countries.

Eight hundred beds have been promised by the international community - less than a third of the 3,000 the World Health Organisation says is urgently needed. The global health body estimates that up to 250 medical staff are needed to safely manage every 70 beds. "All agreed that the demands of the Ebola outbreak have completely outstripped the government's and partners' capacity to respond," it said.

On Tuesday, scenes of joy occurred in Makeni after residents insisted the epidemic was over. Health authorities had to broadcast messages debunking the rumours, and police enforced a curfew.

"Imagine our disappointment to realise the terrible Ebola was far from finished," said Solomon Faley, a rice farmer who lost two relatives to the disease.

Captions:

Nowa Paye, 9, is taken to an ambulance in a Liberian village after showing symptoms of Ebola Photograph: Jerome Delay/AP

6 of 500 DOCUMENTS



The Analyst


October 01, 2014


Ugandan Doctor Calls for More Blood Donations to Fight Ebola


BYLINE: Gabriel M. Dixon, Jallah Grayfield, E. Orlind Cooper


LENGTH: 862 words


The head of a medical team of volunteers from Uganda has stressed the need for more blood donation to various ETUs as one of the surest ways of fighting the Ebola Virus Disease. Dr. Anne Deborah Atai-Omoruto wants Philanthropists and kind-hearted individuals to donate blood to help save the lives of thousands of Liberians who are facing the life threatening EVD.

The Ugandan trained doctor and WHO consultant on Ebola says that patients need more blood during treatment because the Ebola virus damages the clotting system of the body that usually helps to protect and prevent abnormal loss of plasma when there is bleeding. She told Developmental Media Incorporated (DMI) that those clotting factors are available in every human, because the body repairs itself all the time. 

Stressing the importance of blood in this Ebola struggle, Dr. Atai-Omoruto said: "We need the antibodies of people, especially from the survivors, because when the body system is stunned by the Ebola virus and you are able to quickly infuse a survivor's blood into a patient, it helps fight the virus.

"It suffocates more about the virus and gives the person better chance of survival." She wants a blood bank to be established, where blood donated by Liberians will be managed by WHO, CDC and the government of Liberia.

Meanwhile, Dr. Atai has regretted the lack of space to accommodate sick people turning out at treatment centers across the country, saying "As a medical doctor, it is very frustrating to see that you cannot help a patient who is desperately in need of your help even though you would love to render them assistance, my desire is that everyone who comes here should get treatment; even if I have to put them under a tree, I will definitely do that, that is actually what I want to do."

Speaking on the severity of the West African outbreak, Dr. Atai explicated that the strand of the Ebola virus that they know in Uganda is different from what she and her colleagues are battling in West Africa stating that the strand of the Ebola virus in Liberia and neighboring countries is very strange and deceptive.

The Ugandan Doctor said it is difficult to fight this new strand of EVD because of the very high population in the Capital. "There is much crowding, there are lots of activities, a lot of body contact and the virus took the country completely unaware."

Dr. Atai and her team has been training local health workers from across the country in handling, treatment of patients of the filo-virus Ebola since they arrived in Liberia.

"I am just hoping that I can build enough capacity so that I can hand over those health workers to ETUs that are being built after been through the training and knowing exactly what need to be done" she said.

Dr. Anne Deborah Atai-Omoruto, a graduate of Makerere University in Uganda and chair of the Department of Family Medicine, is a Practicing Family Physician and a founding member of the Association of Family Physicians of East Africa.

In addition to her role as the President of the Family Physicians of Uganda, she has also conducted insightful research as a doctor, primarily in the field of infectious diseases such as tuberculosis, HIVs, and malaria. She's currently serving as a consultant to WHO assigned at the Island Hospital (formerly Island Clinic) Ebola Treatment Unit (ETU) in Tweh Farm Community. She is the head of a team of twelve Ugandan health workers, which includes two Physician Assistants, eight Nurses, and two doctors.

Few days ago, Dr. Tolbert Nyanswah, Assistant Health Minister for Curative Services, spoke of the government's efforts to increase the number of treatment units across the country to 17; so that those who are sick can access those centers in their respective counties. "This will ensure quick treatment and survival for people turning out soon for treatment" he said.

The Ebola Treatment Unit at the island hospital in Tweh Farm Community which is being managed by the Ugandan team was built to help boost patient survival chances as other ETUs around Monrovia continue to receive a multiplicity of cases. But it has dramatically experienced a sharp increase in the number of patients that it's capacitated to handle from 150, with a little over 170 patients.

It is now six months since the deadly Ebola virus entered into Liberia through the Republic of Guinea, affecting Liberia which now reports the highest cases of death from the virus in the sub-region.

According to the Center of Disease Control, the death toll now stands at 1,677, and the number of cases reported at 3,280 with 890 laboratory confirmed cases in Liberia. Even in the wake of increased international support to countries affected by the virus, the case level continues to upsurge exponentially-not linearly, on a daily basis with international experts from WHO and CDC estimating that a total of 1.4m cases before the virus are brought under control.

Meanwhile, an elderly healthcare worker emphasized to DMI, the need for government to set up mini-clinics at the various Ebola treatment centers so that those who are sick from curable diseases can be prevented from dying from the lack of attention and rejection at regular facilities.


LOAD-DATE: October 1, 2014


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

7 of 500 DOCUMENTS



The Analyst


October 01, 2014


MOE Plans to Reopen Schools - Introduces Radio Program


BYLINE: Edward B. Palmer


LENGTH: 362 words


The Ministry of Education says it is planning to re-open schools but with no mention of the definite time, announcing also that it will soon begin providing educational courses via radio. Deputy Minister for Early Child Education, Felicia Doe-Somah, who addressed the Ministry of Information's regular Ebola press briefings Tuesday clarified, however, that the reopening of school is contingent on instructions by the necessary authorities. 

She told journalists that hand washing buckets will be placed at every school corner at various institutions when schools are reopened to ensure the necessary hygienic measure that will forestall the spreading of the deadly Ebola virus amongst students.

According to her, the Education Ministry has been involved with awareness of how to prevent the further spread of the virus since the outbreak of the deadly Ebola virus which led to the subsequent closure of schools around the country. She noted that in early August the ministry was concerned about students being put out of schools, which prompted the ministry to launch awareness campaigns in eight counties.

The deputy minister said the idea of the awareness is to engage the citizens of the county, district, and community levels on the method of teaching by radio, stressing that the MoE wants to jump start a process that will benefit the entire citizenry. Noting that the MoE has a big stake in the fight against Ebola, Madam Somah also disclosed a teaching by radio program which she said is underway at the ministry and will continue even after the Ebola crisis.

Stressing the need for early childhood education, Madam Somah said providing early childhood education via radio is not limited to the Ebola period, but is instead an inter-sectoral project that will continue even in a post Ebola era and will include "Meet the counselor strategy".

The meet the counselor strategy will provide psychosocial counseling for victims who lost their family members as the result of the Ebola tragedy. Madam some expressed confidence that the public will benefit more from listening to the radio when the program is launched, adding that lots of people are already showing interest.

8 of 500 DOCUMENTS



The Analyst


October 01, 2014


"Use Discretionary Powers" - Chief Justice Warns Magistrates


BYLINE: Victoria G. Wesseh


LENGTH: 504 words


Chief justice Francis S. Korkpor, Sr. has Warned Magistrates against acts that do not conform with the law during this Ebola crisis. Chief justice, Francis Korkpor, has encouraged Magistrates to make maximum use of the safeguards under the law during this Ebola crisis period, taking into consideration options for arrest and detention. 

He said, though the judiciary will not go about disseminating information to the public regarding precautionary measures against the Ebola virus in the county, the third branch of government should contribute immensely to the fight against the Ebola virus in the county.

He said while he is not ordering them to perform their duties out of the scope of the law, he is encouraging them to play a meaningful role in exercising discretionary powers under Sections 10.12 and 13.5 of the criminal procedure law. He pointed out that the judiciary is to ensure that it plays one of the pivotal roles in containing the deadly Ebola viral disease.

Speaking at the Supreme Court's regular administrative meeting with Magistrates of the Temple of Justice Tuesday, Justice Korkpor however, indicated that the application of discretionary powers must be done on a case by case basis given the facts and circumstances of the prevailing situation in the country.

He urged them to be punctual on duty, stressing that any magistrate that does not take time into consideration and absenting himself from the job will be considered non-essential staff, and that stringent administrative measures will be instituted against those magistrates involved in such practice.

Touching on jury sequestration, Chief Justice Francis Korkpor said the judiciary has held deliberations with the Liberian National Bar Association, where the issue of the reduction of the number of jurors and the sequestration of the jury were addressed due to the out-break of the Ebola virus in the country. He indicated that instead of 15- man jury with three alternates, they resolved that the number be reduced to nine with three alternates out of the nine.

Chief Justice Korkpor extolled the cordial working relationship between the Judiciary and the Executive, making specific reference to the Ministry of Justice and the Liberian National Bar Association regarding efforts aimed at playing a meaningful role in the fight against the Ebola virus.

Speaking on behalf of the justice Ministry, Montserrado County Attorney, Cllr, Daku J. Mulbah, and Assistant justice Minister for Litigation and Acting Solicitor General, Cllr. Augustine Fayiah assured the judiciary that the ministry will continue to exhibit the spirit of collaboration so as to be able to play pivotal roles in the fight against the virus.

For their part, the magistrates told the Chief Justice that they will exercise maximum judicial powers as enshrined in statutes having into consideration the use discretionary powers that will reduce over-crowdedness of prisons, especially when it comes to arrest, summon and detention of defendants during the fight against the Ebola.


LOAD-DATE: October 1, 2014

9 of 500 DOCUMENTS



The Analyst


October 01, 2014


'I'll Sue Govt' - Rep Forh Threatens Health Center


BYLINE: Anthony Q. Jiffan, Jr


LENGTH: 318 words


Montserrado County District #16 Representative, Edward S. Forh, has threatened legal action against the government of Liberia and the John F. Kennedy Medical Center in Monrovia for the death of his 20-year-old daughter Nakita Dieh Forh last Saturday. 

The lawmaker said the JFK workers refused his daughter treatment and requested for Ebola clearance before catering to her. "I will sue this government and the JFK," Forh exclaimed, and said the government should be responsible for the untimely death of his daughter.

The government, he explained, should take responsibility for the death of Nakita for what he termed "wrong mandate" given to health care workers which demands submission of Ebola clearance before accepting to treat patients. According to Representative Forh, his anger arises from the rejection of his daughter by medical center, leaving her to die before performing a test that proved her Ebola negative.

The Montserrado County representative said the late Nakita was a crown holder as "Miss Stella Maris Polytechnic" and was preparing for graduation this semester, asserting that the government needs to reconsider its decision which demands Ebola clearance before treatment is given to a patient.

Rep. Forh also recommends the establishment of testing centers at every major health care center in the country. He now understands and believes that several persons have died from common illness due to what he describes as an inappropriate rejection of patients by the health workers using the fear of Ebola. His understanding of the troubling mandate given health care centers derived from the handling of his daughter, Nakita, which caused her death.

Meanwhile, the Federation of borough youth (FOBY), the umbrella organization of youth in the Municipal borough of New Kru town extends deepest condolence to the representative and the entire Forh family for the loss of the late Nakita Die For.

The Analyst


October 01, 2014


Gov't Urges Non-Essential Employees to Stay Home


LENGTH: 201 words


The Government of Liberia has extended the decongestion measure at all public institutions by requesting all non-essential government employees continue to remain at home with full pay and benefits, until otherwise instructed. 

According to an Executive Mansion release, during the period, non-essential government employees are strongly encouraged to engage in community-based awareness and cleanup exercises aimed at preventing and halting the further spread of the deadly Ebola virus disease in Liberia.

The government is also thanking all public servants, especially those at the forefront of the fight against Ebola, for continuing to deliver essential services to the Liberian people.

It further reminds all that the crisis is not yet over; but that the government and people have made significant progress by putting in place the structures necessary to contain and subsequently eradicate the Ebola virus from the country.

To build up the gains, the government encourages all public institutions to keep a safe working environment for all employees. It further advised that established safety protocols must be reinforced in all workplaces, including hand washing and periodic general cleaning up exercises.


LOAD-DATE: October 1, 2014


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2014 AllAfrica Global Media.

11 of 500 DOCUMENTS



The Analyst


October 01, 2014


'No Condition Can Stop Us' - U.S. Mission Commander


LENGTH: 1057 words


The commander of the United States Military Mission to Liberia, Major-General Darryl A. Williams, says the US Military will not be deterred in their operations in Liberia by any condition, including that bad road network.

The Commander of the U. S. Mission, Major-General Williams indicated that the United States military had conducted an assessment that have documented useful information about the challenges and conditions the United States soldiers are expected to grapple during their operations in the country before the mission's gradual build up and subsequent arrival.

He told journalist during a news conference that the mission's operational scope is by far bigger than the Monrovia area, saying that the troops were fully prepared to enter every part of the country to achieve the mandate of the mission. 

Deployment has begun

Already, the 3,000-membered States military mission has begun deploying troops to strategic military positions for its operations in Liberia, according to military sources.

Addressing a press conference at the US Embassy in Monrovia Monday, Maj. Gen. Williams, the commander of the US Army Africa Command (AFRICOM), clarified that the mission of the United States Army in Liberia is different from the US battle Frontline troop in Afghanistan.

General Williams said a skeletal team of about 175 troops have already landed in Liberia undertaking operations along with the Armed Forces of Liberia (AFL) for the constructions of Ebola care centers as well as the US logistical plans to support medical operations in the fight against the Ebola virus in every part of Liberia.

In the course of the next few weeks or days, he said, Liberians will soon start to witness the movement of US Military choppers and vehicles in Monrovia and other parts of Liberia, calling on the people of Liberia not to worry about the movement and the visibility of the US military in full readiness to support efforts by the United States Government and international partners towards the fight against Ebola in Liberia.

The US marines, Maj. Gen. Williams indicated, has begun working with the AFL in executing the Liberian government's health plans presented to him by President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf towards the anti-Ebola fight to curb the outbreak in Liberia.

The US general, who described the Liberian government's plan as well, said the AFL and the US troops will operate within the plan to support the anti-Ebola efforts, stressing that the US military mission in Liberia was for logistical supports in the fight against the Ebola virus.

Accordingly, the US troops have begun the erecting of 25-bed hospital as part of 17 Ebola care centers earmarked for construction in Liberia.

No Plan to force regime out

Also speaking at the news conference, U.S. Ambassador Deborah R. Malac clarified that the US military mission's mandate does not contain forceful removal of the Government of Liberia from power; instead it is here to support the plans relating to the fight against the deadly Ebola virus out of Liberia.

Ambassador Malac, taking not of speculation that troops were coming to replace the Liberian government, emphasized that any plan of forceful removal of the Liberian government from power is not a part of the U. S. Government's plan for Liberia.

The field team leader of the US Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), Dr. Brendan Flannery, also spoke at the conference and said Ebola patients should be treated with compassion due to the nature of their situation.

Dr. Flannery said the situation in Liberia is serious and does not call for stigmatizing Ebola patients who need to be treated with compassion and Ebola survivors must also be accepted in their communities to give them hope when they survive the deadly pestilence.

Though the CDC head to Liberia did not attach timeline to the end of the virus outbreak, but indicated the importance in establishing Ebola care centers in communities to serve as the first place for sick persons go and get separated from the others.

Dr. Flannery further said when such system is established, there will be an easy approach in fighting the virus from the community level while the ETUs will only serve as treatment centers for only Ebola patients identified by these care centers in communities.

Concluding, Dr. Flannery said the presence of a CDC team in Liberia will also help in the training of Liberian health workers in the fight against Ebola while the 25-bed room unit will provide care to health workers contacting the virus.

In a related development, U.S. military C-17s has landed at Roberts International Airport over the weekend carrying key pieces of U.S. military equipment to aid in the anti-Ebola fight: two mobile Ebola testing labs and equipment to build the 25-bed field hospital for health care workers.

The mobile labs will be placed at the Ebola Treatment Centers (ETUs) at Island Clinic and in Bong County, and are expected to be operational this week. The labs are a huge step in stopping the spread of Ebola, because they reduce the time needed to determine if a patient has Ebola from several days to just a few hours. The labs will be operated by members of a U.S. Navy Medical Research Unit.

The 25-bed hospital arrived as U.S. Seabees broke ground on the hospital site in Margibi County. Originally designed to treat military service members in combat zones, the facility will be staffed by the U.S. Public Health Service and will be used to care for health workers in Liberia.

The 25-bed hospital and mobile testing labs are part of the U.S. effort to help the government of Liberia and other Ebola-affected countries contain the Ebola virus, save lives and alleviate human suffering. Other U.S. activities include setting up a logistics base to facilitate the flow of military personnel, supplies, and equipment into the affected region, helping to build 17 Ebola treatment units, and training for hundreds of health care workers.

The U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) is the lead U.S. government agency overseeing the overall U.S. response to the Ebola outbreak in West Africa. The U.S. military response, led by Major General Darryl Williams, Commanding General of U.S. Army Africa, is acting in support of the USAID-led Disaster Assistance Response Team by providing expertise in command and control, engineering and logistics.


LOAD-DATE: October 1, 2014

12 of 500 DOCUMENTS



The Analyst


October 01, 2014


Ngafuan Tells Liberia's 'Sad Story'


LENGTH: 2151 words


Just 12 months ago the United Nations and other members of the international community hailed Liberia as a "success story" of international partnership for peace and development.

A robust UN peace-building force has taken charge of the security while a new civil administration that grew out of these efforts fostered peace, reconciliation, reconstruction, and economic growth. But 12 months later, the nation is staring down a nefarious abyss created by the Ebola virus.

Many lives have been lost and counting. The economy has not only grounded to a halt, but it is also on a downward spiral. Liberia's Foreign Minister Augustine KpeheNgafuan was at the United Nations General Assembly in New York to tell Liberia's "sad story" to the world. The Analyst, reports.

Foreign Minister Augustine Ngafuan has congratulated leaders of UN and other members of the international community for rushing to Liberia's side against the deadly Ebola virus. He, however warned that it would be a deadly mistake to allow the flurry of international efforts and commitment to lead to complacency. 

The foreign minister's comments were contained in a statement he delivered on behalf of President Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf on September 29, 2014, at the 69th Regular Session of the United Nations General Assembly in New York. Minister Ngafuan briefly reminisced on the upward thrust of the Liberian economy by the end of 2013 before he launched into the "sad story" of a nation deep in the throes of death and almost-complete economic reversal.

The Liberian foreign minister recalled that by the end of fiscal 2013, Liberia was on course with the theme of the 69th UN Regular Session, "Delivering on and Implementing a Transformative Post-2015 Development Agenda".

With its own development agenda dubbed, "Agenda for Transformation (AfT)", he said, postwar Liberia had transitioned from emphasis on stabilization to focus on transformation within the framework of a long-term development agenda christened "Vision 2030".

But he said all of this came to an abrupt halt in a few months with the outbreak of the Ebola epidemic in March 2014. Within a month, the economy began spinning out of control as Ebola mowed down helpless Liberians and overwhelmed the already struggling health sector.

In Liberia, he said, this sudden downward spiral has not only undermined the UN High-Level Panel's "leave no one behind" call, but that it has also threatened the very foundation of the Liberian economy and reversed all gains. In a sense according to him, a few months of the Ebola plague has wolfed up a decade of progress and curtained hope.

He quoted President Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf's August 2013 address to the UN General Assembly as detailing the strides Liberia had recorded. Despite the challenges that faced the nation, he recalled, President Sirleaf had told the UN assembly that her administration had helped foster a regional integration within the Mano River enclave. She also reported Liberia's role in regional peacekeeping efforts and disclosed that the enclave was about to facilitate power connectivity and transport systems to promote regional trade.

"[But] one year later, as I stand to address this august body, I have become the purveyor of a different kind of story - a sad story," he told the world assembly.

"Over the past six months, a dark cloud has been hanging over the Liberian landscape such that instead of reporting on economic growth, we are constrained to report economic decline. Implementation of virtually all pillars of our Agenda for Transformation (AfT) has been placed on hold, and gains are perhaps already being reversed," the Liberian foreign minister said.

Now, he said, the nation is buckling down to seeking regional and international cooperation to fight what he called the "deadly enemy". "The deadly enemy that has visited so much harm and misery on my country, a small country of only 4 million people, and our neighbors, Sierra Leone and Guinea, is the Ebola Virus Disease (EVD), which began wreaking havoc in Liberia in March of this year," he said.

In efforts to ward off the havoc, he said, the government declared a state of emergency, suspended schools, and stepped up awareness and prevention campaigns in collaboration with the civil society and the NGO community. These efforts have so far helped to address what he called the crystallized denial and deeply rooted traditional and cultural practices that create a fertile ground for the spread of the disease.

"We have also committed and will continue to commit significant portions of our own paltry resources to the fight," he said. But he was quick to note that daunting challenges remained.

"Ebola has confounded all of us and has sprinted faster than our collective efforts, snuffing out the life candle of more than 1,800 of our compatriots with a total of nearly 3,500 infected In spite of these efforts," he said.

According to him, the grim statistics was in spite of the government's efforts being buttressed by partners from the World Health Organization, the US Centers for Disease Control, Medecins Sans Frontiers, the Samaritans Purse and several bilateral and multilateral partners.

Added to human toll left in the wake of the virus' devastation, Minister Ngafuan revealed, is a trail of traumatized orphans scattered in several communities in Monrovia and other affected areas. He gave no figure; but he noted that it was a problem in waiting.

He told a story of a 10-year-old who is a lone survivor of a family of 12. He then noted that with a pool of endangered, a timid health workforce that has suffered 89 deaths out of 182 infected, it was a matter of time before Liberia crumbled under the weight of what seems 21st Century's biggest health disaster in modern Africa.

The Liberian Foreign Service boss said, "The resulting panic that arises from health workers seeing their colleagues die from Ebola has precipitated the closure of many health facilities across the country. As we and our many international partners struggle to douse the wildfire caused by Ebola, we have been left with inadequate resources, time and personnel to attend to other routine illnesses like malaria, typhoid fever and measles, thereby causing many more tangential deaths.

"An increasing number of pregnant women are dying in the process of bringing forth life. In short, our public health system, which totally collapsed during years of conflict and was being gradually rebuilt, has relapsed under the weight of the deadly virus."

What this meant, he said, was that the world needed to come to the realization that "Ebola is not just a health crisis". "It is a total crisis- it is an economic crisis, a social crisis, and a potential political and security crisis. Indeed, its deleterious impact has been very wide and very deep," he disclosed.

As an economic crisis, he said, Ebola has caused a 3.4% downward slide in economic growth, from a high of 5.9% to a low of 2.5% in 2014; and some experts have predicted that, if not contained quickly, Ebola could cause a 12% decline in our economy in 2015.

But, that is not all, he said. "Domestic food production, mining, transport services, the construction and hospitality industries, trade and many other productive components of our economy have all registered significant reversals.

"Concessionaires have scaled down their operations, causing a large contingent of expatriates to leave the country. As a result of the slowdown in economic activities, our revenue generation capacity has been seriously undermined resulting in a nearly 20% downward revision of our budget for Fiscal Year 2014/2015. In spite of this depressing domestic revenue outlook, our country has been dedicating a hefty portion of its scarce resources to the fight. Consequently, our ability to provide for basic social services and continue to fund key development projects are significantly diminished.

"The suspension of flights as well as the travel and other restrictions/sanctions imposed on Liberia and other affected countries, contrary to expert advice from WHO and others, did not only undermine the humanitarian efforts aimed at quickly containing the disease, but also aggravated the adverse economic effects of the Ebola crisis."

Even though the statistics and prevailing conditions portend bigger hardship and more lost of innocent lives, the Liberian foreign minister was hopeful of a coming new day.

"Through separate and joint appeals of the Heads of State of Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone to the UN Secretary-General and leaders of friendly countries and institutions, the international community is showing a better understanding and deeper appreciation of the unprecedented scope and magnitude of the Ebola outbreak in our countries. There is a chorus of leaders advocating and committing to support more robust, scaled up and urgent assistance to the affected countries," he said.

Amongst these "positive developments", the minister said, is the decision by the US government to deploy 3000 military and medical specialist personnel to build treatment centers, train health personnel and provide other types of much needed support to Liberia and other affected countries. The personnel, he said, have already begun to arrive in Liberia.

Another sign of bubbling international partnership that inspire hope, he noted, was the UN Security Council's September 18 Resolution 2177, which recognized the Ebola crisis as a threat to international peace and security, necessitating strong and concerted international response.

Liberia's cause for hope also, he said, rests with an announcement by the Secretary-General on 18 September of his intention to establish the UN Mission for Ebola Emergency Response (UNMEER).

"As I speak, the Head of UNMEER is in the region and will be discussing the Status of Forces Agreement (SOFA) for activating the mission," he disclosed further.

He said the start of the deployment of the African Union (AU) contingents of medical and relevant personnel drawn from across Africa to Liberia, other worst affected countries, and the convening by the Secretary-General on 25 September of a High-Level meeting on the Ebola epidemic gave further ground for hope.

According to him, the September 25th UN meeting witnessed the announcements of substantial commitments of assistance from many countries, including France, China, Germany, the United Kingdom, Japan, Timor Leste and multilateral institutions including the World Bank and regional organizations such as the European Union.

Besides these efforts, he said, the air travel nightmare imposed by restriction to Liberia has been eased by the relaxation of travel restrictions by some AU and ECOWAS member states.

For instance, he said, Air Cote D'Ivoire is poised to resume flights to Liberia within a week while Kenya Airways would resume flight sometime this month. The resumption of flights to Liberia, he said, would make it easy for the airlifting of critically needed protective equipment and supplies to Liberia.

Two wars ahead: No time for complacency

"The expressions of solidarity have taken many forms and we are deeply grateful for all of them," the foreign minister said. But he warned that these efforts should not lead toward complacency because containing the spread of the virus opens a two-front war corridor to recovery. "While we struggle with the first war of actually disrupting the transmission of Ebola, we, along with our bilateral and multilateral partners, must begin to prepare for the second war," he said.

The second war, he said, would entail tackling the long-term socioeconomic impacts of the Ebola crisis. That aspect of the war, he said, entails "building and capacitating a new public health system that can robustly deal with any future health challenge, catering for the increasing numbers of orphans and other traumatized and impoverished family members, and quickly raising resources to address a legion of socioeconomic, political, security and other challenges made more acute by the presence of Ebola".

Meanwhile, the foreign minister has expressed the Sirleaf Administration's appreciation to the UN for UNMIL's presence in Liberia, which he said, reassures Liberians and creates a secure climate at the time the country was experiencing isolation.

"Therefore, UNMIL's continued engagement in Liberia will be critical to enabling Liberia to transition smoothly from the Ebola Crisis and resume implementation of strategies for the achievement of our long-term development agenda," he said.

He said despite the challenges posed by Ebola, UNMIL's presence has inspired courage in the population to fight in efforts to defeat the grim statistics of 1.4 million deaths by January 2015.

"Instead, President Sirleaf and the resilient people of Liberia feel that the Ebola epidemic has presented us with a one-option, multiple-choice test; and that option is to fight back! And we are fighting back," he said.

October 01, 2014


Sirleaf Meets With U.S. Assistant Secretary of Defense


LENGTH: 858 words


President Sirleaf Meets With US Assistant Secretary of Defense, Michael Lumpkin Meets with UN Secretary-General's Special Representative on Ebola Response, Anthony Banbury.

A high-powered United States delegation currently in the country has hailed President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf's international engagements since the outbreak of the Ebola epidemic in Liberia.

According to an Executive Mansion release, the head of delegation, Assistant Secretary of Defense Michael Lumpkin, said the United States sees the eradication of the Ebola virus disease as paramount and urgent and will work with the Liberian authorities in achieving this goal. Mr. Lumpkin said he has felt and seen the courage of the Liberian people in fighting the virus and their eagerness to return to normalcy should be supported by the international community. 

The US Assistant Secretary of Defense told the Liberian leader that the delegation's presence in Monrovia was in further demonstration of the United States Government's commitment to help Liberia fight the deadly virus and will remain closely engaged as all fight together in eradicating the disease. He assured the Liberian leader that the US military has already begun working with their Liberian counterparts to carry out the construction of Ebola Treatment Units across the country.

Mr. Lumpkin said he foresees tremendous progress in the fight with the level of cooperation between Liberians and Americans and called for more collaborative efforts toward the eradication. Briefing the delegation earlier, President Sirleaf said government in collaboration with national and international partners has now formulated a common strategy which is working well.

She, however informed the US delegation that Liberia would love to take ownership of the process with the support of the international community which she said will go a long way in future eventualities particularly in health care delivery. President Sirleaf said Liberia has begun to see progress with the support of the international community and is eager to see a stabilization of the situation thereby resuscitating the economy that has been hardly hit by the epidemic.

She informed the American delegation that their presence has made a huge difference and expressed the hope that with the intervention by other friendly governments, Liberia will soon record the Ebola outbreak as history. Finance and Development Planning Minister-designate Amara Konneh and Defense Minister Brownie Samukai, respectively briefed the delegation on the economic outlook and Armed Force of Liberia (AFL) involvement in the Ebola fight.

Minister Konneh thanked the US Government for the US$5 million dollar budget support as health workers' incentives, but pleaded for more budgetary support as that amount would only take the health workers' incentive payment up to January 2015.

Other members of the delegation who met with President Sirleaf included the United States Agency for International Development (USAID) assistant administrator, Nancy Linborg; DART team leader, William Berger; Center for Disease Control and Prevention, Dr. Thomas Kenyon; policy advisor, Denise Marsh; USAID mission director, John Mark Winfield; and economic officer, Eric Johnson. They were accompanied by US Ambassador Deborah Malac.

In the other presidential news, the Liberian leader met with the UN Secretary-General's Special Representative on Ebola Response during a courtesy visit on Wednesday, October 1, 2014. Mr. Anthony Banbury, who is resident in Accra, Ghana, was accompanied to the President Sirleaf'sForeign Ministry office by the head of the UN Mission in Liberia (UNMIL) Ms. Karen Langren. She encouraged the Liberian leader to remain internationally engaged as it has yielded fruitful results as regards her leadership's effort in the Ebola fight.

For his part, the Mr. Bonbury promised President Sirleaf that the UN Ebola fight would be integrated into the country's national plan and strategy and agreed with the President of Liberian ownership with full partners' participation tapping on their expertise. He said the new UN agency, UN Mission on Ebola Response, as part of its terms of reference, will fill in gaps in the Ebola fight in consultation with the national strategy in order to prevent any form of duplication of an already existing strategy.

In response, President Sirleaf welcomed the creation of the UN Ebola Response office in Accra and encouraged the office to promote information exchange on the virus among affected countries.

Besides, President Sirleaf urged the agency to support government in strengthening its rural outreach initiatives. She named bad roads and under reporting on the status of Ebola in the rural settings which has prevented the government from moving into those areas to arrest any further spread. "Affected people are leaving from urban places and hiding out in remote communities. If we do not move in as quickly as possible, the virus would further spread in rural areas. This has led to all the 15 counties now reporting cases with those that had no case now reporting the low number of cases," President Sirleaf informed Mr. Bonbury.

October 01, 2014


Sirleaf Meets Delegation From Heartt Foundation


LENGTH: 821 words


President Sirleaf meets with delegation from Heartt Foundation and AmeriCares led by the Foundation's interim executive director, Masmina Sirleaf.

A visiting delegation of the Health Education and Relief through Teaching (HEARTT) Foundation and its collaborating partner, AmeriCares has held a meeting with President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf at her Foreign Ministry office.

According to an Executive Mansion release, the head of delegation, HEARTT Foundation's interim executive director Masmina Sirleaf, informed the Liberian leader that the visit was aimed at briefing her about HEARTT and AmeriCares' intervention in West Africa and Liberia in particular in light of the outbreak of the deadly Ebola virus disease now ravaging the sub-region. 

She pointed out that HEARTT's response to the West African Ebola outbreak has focused on support for Liberian health facilities and protection of the frontline health workers. "Through our partners and donor networks, we have provided shipments of personal protective equipment, IV fluids and other life-saving supplies worth more than $500,000 to hospitals, clinics and treatment centers," Mrs. Sirleaf stressed, adding, "Over the next several days, HEARTT will distribute three shipments from AmeriCares and one from Liberia Medical Relief with the assistance of local chapters of Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, Alpha Phi Alpha Fraternity and the Monrovia Rotary Club."

For her part, President Sirleaf welcomed HEARTT and AmeriCares to Liberia and recognized their local partners, Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, Alpha Phi Alpha Fraternity and the Monrovia Rotary Club. She reflected that she has followed HEARTT's work in Liberia long before the start of her administration and described their work as "a good example of Liberians helping Liberia".

The Liberian leader further noted the good work of HEARTT and AmeriCares that include several interventions at the John F. Kennedy (JFK) Medical Center and the Redemption Hospital in Monrovia which has helped train medical staffers and provide opportunity for the deployment of doctors and other healthcare professionals to render voluntary services to Liberians.

President Sirleaf also recognized that the group has been a major contributor to Liberia's healthcare services which ensured that doctors performed critical free operations at the JFK Medical Center. "Even though the voluntary doctors left Liberia due to the Ebola outbreak, we are happy to know that HEARTT, AmeriCares and their local partners are still here providing and distributing essentially needed medical supplies and protective equipment to Ebola Treatment Centers and other regular health facilities," she pointed out.

She told both HEARTT and AmeriCares that their partnership has not only given hope to Liberians but proven that there are still groups out there that really care for people in need and in crisis; adding that she applauds the institutions for their role in all they are doing as the country battles an unknown disease.

President Sirleaf also praised the Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, Alpha Phil Alpha Fraternity and Monrovia Rotary Club who are utilizing their own resources, with no request from government to help Liberia overcome the further spread of the deadly Ebola virus disease.

The HEARTT Foundation was born against the backdrop of post-conflict Liberia reweaving its social and economic fabric. HEARTT Foundation recruits and facilitates the travel of volunteer clinicians to increase clinical care capacity and provide hands-on training and lectures to local healthcare workers at the JFK Medical Center and Redemption Hospital in Monrovia. It has established programs in emergency medicine, internal medicine, pediatric and orthopedic surgery at the JFK Medical Center and pediatric and obstetrics-gynecology at Redemption Hospital; rotating up to 70 primary care and specialty Physicians to Liberia annually for continuous coverage.

AmeriCares is an emergency response and global health organization committed to saving lives and building healthier futures for people in crisis in the United States and around the world. Today, AmeriCares is the world's largest provider of donated medicines and medical supplies, both in the United States and worldwide and works along with more than 3,500 local partners to restore and enhance health services, particularly in the face of disaster; provide quality primary care; increase access to medicines and supplies in under-resourced settings and catalyze long-term improvements in healthcare delivery.

The visiting delegation included HEARTT Foundation's interim executive director, Masmina Sirleaf; AmeriCare's director of emergency response, GarettIngoglia; head of assessment at AmeriCare. Brian Hoyer; Alpha Phil Alpha Liberia chapter's president and chief dean, T. Nelson Williams; Alpha Kappa Alpha's medical and relief coordinator, Ellen Pratt; and a representative of the Rotary Club of Liberia.

October 01, 2014


'It Takes God's Intervention" to Run Ebola Out of Liberia'


BYLINE: Victoria G. Wesseh


LENGTH: 474 words


A Liberian Cleric, Prophet Ignatius W. White, says it takes the intervention of God to rid the country of the deadly Ebola virus, calling on Liberians and the government and partners not rule out God's intercession in the fight against Ebola in Liberia. 

The founder and general overseer of the Power in Prayer Ministry told The Analyst in Monrovia yesterday that the fight against Ebola can be won as speedily as possible provided Liberians and international involve the church to invoke God's intervention.

He said in a not too distant future, Liberians and their international partners will soon join hands in dancing and singing glory to God through Jesus for the victory over the Ebola virus in Liberia. He reminded Liberians and the international community to bow in worship to Jesus, focus on God for the efforts in the fight against the virus that was claiming lives in the country, the Mino River Union basin as well as in other parts of the world.

According to the general overseer of the Power in Prayer Ministry, there is power in prayer. The Overseer who is also the Senior Pastor of the Headquarter Church of the Power in Prayer Ministryassured that God has removed the Ebola virus from Liberia and just in the matters of time Liberians and their international partners will soon be celebrating the defeat of the deadly Ebola virus in Liberia.

Prophet White further explained that God's miracle manifested and many persons saved in the Name of Jesus Christ at a fast and a prayer service that had nearly 400 persons in attendance, indicating that the service which had a direct focus for a particular Liberian family base in Liberia and USA drew the attention of others.

Prophet White began his ministry as far back in 2006 following a year of fast and prayer after family rejection. He said through the favor of the ministry God is now growing with a membership of more than 200 persons as the power of God continues to prevail in everyday service.

He clarified that the work of God and salvation through Jesus, we're free, added that he is not selling healing miracles manifested through the power of God. According to Prophet White, until God's appointed time Ebola will run out of Liberia, which time he added was already at hand.

The Power in Prayer Ministry General Overseer, Prophet White stressed that the power of God was still alive and could be realized when people continue to demonstrate faith in Jesus regarding their situation or whatever they may be experienced regardless of the kind of disease or sickness they were experiencing in life.

Prophet White said the power of God was being manifested in his ministry with God healing all kinds of sicknesses, stressing that it was important that the people of Liberia commit their lives into the care of the God through Jesus as God was able to perform His miracles at anytime.

October 01, 2014


UN Security Council Extends Unmil Mandate in Liberia


LENGTH: 292 words


The United Nations Security Council has extended the mandate of the United Nations Mission in Liberia (UNMILL) by one year to September 30, 2015. Disclosing this during a press conference at UNMIL's headquarters in Monrovia Wednesday, the Special Representative of the Secretary General (SRSG), Karin Landgren, said this is due to the Ebola pandemic that has hit the country and claimed the lives of hundreds since March this year. 

Landgren explained that because of the Ebola crisis, the United Nations Security Council did not discuss the drawdown of UNMIL and security transition during its Council meeting on September 9, 2014. The UN official said it devoted discussions entirely to the rapid development related to Ebola outbreak, which they termed as Liberia's 'gravest threat since the end of the civil war."

She added that discussion about UNMIL drawdown in Liberia was suspended in order to focus discussion entirely on the destabilizing impact of Ebola and the economic, social, political and security consequences that are already being felt.

She stressed that prices have risen, economic growth is expected to be cut by more than half, trade has reduced, many farmers are not tending their fields in affected areas, and children are not in school. Landgren pointed out that the Security Council adopted its resolution on UNMIL on September 15th, expressing grave concern about the extent of the outbreak of the virus.

She noted that one of the messages reinforced by the Security Council is that UNMIL is staying at Liberia's side as the country battles to turn the tide of Ebola infections. She emphasized that UNMIL's mandate has been rolled over until the end of 2014 which, according to her, means that UNMIL was extended without any changes.

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

The Analyst


October 01, 2014


U.S. Delegation Seeks Understanding On Ebola Response


LENGTH: 295 words


A high power delegation of the United States of America is in Liberia seeking understanding on how to response to the Ebola outbreak in the country.

The US delegation headed by Assistance Administrator of USAID's Bureau for Democracy, Conflict and Humanitarian Assistance, Nancy Lindborg, told a news conference at the US Embassy near Monrovia Wednesday that the delegation was in the country to have a better understanding on how the situation was on the Liberian soil especially as it relates to the Ebola virus outbreak. 

Madam Lindborg said the US Government had a very clear strategy in line with the Liberian government and international partners to respond to the pandemic in Liberia and the sub-region as a whole. He concluded by praising the Liberian government and partners for the progress made so far in the fight against the Ebola virus in the country.

Also speaking was the head of the US Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), Dr. Thomas Kenyon, who reiterated the willingness of the US Government through the CDC to help respond to the Ebola outbreak min Liberia.

Dr. Kenyon said it was regrettable that Liberian families were experiencing the untold pains as a result of the Ebola outbreak, promising the CDC's readiness to respond with the fight against.

For his part, Michael D. Lumkpin, Assistant Secretary for Special Operations /Low -Intensity said the US Military involvement in the fight against Ebola was to support efforts by the US Government to construct Ebola treatment facilities in communities around the country.

The Military, he said, will lead efforts for the support of logistic delivery in communities where Ebola Treatment Units will be constructed, assuring Liberians that the US Military will be felt in almost every part of Liberia.

18 of 500 DOCUMENTS



The Analyst


October 01, 2014


Press Union President - 50th Anniv. Statement [document]


LENGTH: 1593 words


Today had promised to be a very exciting date on the calendar of the Press Union of Liberia - 50 years on the struggle to ensure a free and responsible media landscape - 50 years of standing up to power...

K. Abdullai Kamara, President - Press Union of Liberia - 50th Anniversary Statement

Media Ebola Awareness Activity

September 30, 2014 

Esteemed Members of the Press Union of Liberia

Veteran members of the Press Union of Liberia

Surviving Organizers of the Press Union of Liberia

Compatriots in the march for a better Liberia

My fellow citizens

Ladies & Gentlemen

Today had promised to be a very exciting date on the calendar of the Press Union of Liberia - 50 years on the struggle to ensure a free and responsible media landscape - 50 years of standing up to power, demanding and insisting upon the right to freely express ourselves, in so far as this expression was not tearing down bridges and creating division. Unfortunately, the difficult and cruel army of the Ebola virus disease has restricted our desire to celebrate this day, given the wily disruption it has posed in our country and the subregion.

Further on the account of the Ebola situation, all aspects of Liberian life have gradually ground to a halt. Schools are no longer open - children are lazying home; non-essential staff - whether from government service, NGOs, factories or other work places - have been ordered to stay away from work; Hospitals are operating at less than a quarter of their potentials, restoring such previously ignored diseases as mainline killers. In other instances, basic health services no longer run, and people are living until they die. Now in our country, the most significant activity that keeps working is the search for food - to survive.

In the few instances where some work is going on, the preoccupation is on addressing the Ebola situation. Today, every newspaper story has an Ebola angle and every development grant is now directed at Ebola. Now, given the gravity of the Ebola situation and the risks involved with holding a normal celebration, the Press Union of Liberia has dedicated the observance of its 50th Anniversary to a nationwide Media Ebola Awareness Day.

While we are joining the rest of the people of Liberia in talking about the gravity of the Ebola situation, we also like to pay tribute to the men and women who, on this day in 1964, set forth the challenge to organize a body to protect the rights of journalists in this country, coordinate space for a free, independent and impartial media in Liberia, and at the same time chart their role in the development of the Liberian state, especially towards ensuring freedom of speech, the actualization of democracy and ensuring a guarantee of freedom, justice, equality and development in our country.

The task set forth by those our compatriots have today bloomed into a most respectable organization - which cannot be ignored in anything good that has come out of Liberia. While our notes will continuously refer to E. Reginald Townsend, Henry B. Cole, Chauncey Cooper, Aston King and J. Persey Gumel, I nonetheless like to reference Tuan Wreh, who would go on to become a professor of law, but especially because he has provided for Liberian journalism students one academic text that provides a clearer idea of what journalism was in the days the Press Union of Liberia was organized. I also noted the longevity of James E Dennis, who has survived his contemporaries, and has given us the opportunity to think of the men who led the struggle.

I also like to recognize Kenneth Y. Best, who has remained in the newsroom, even at the ripe age of 75.

I wouldn't forget T Nelson Williams, Sr, who led the organization of the Department of Mass Communications at the University of Liberia, providing for once an opportunity for Liberian journalists to gain academic qualifications here at home. But among all, our hero remains Stanton A. Peabody, who had the audacity to describe members of the House of Representatives in the best disposition of his thoughts, risking contempt and jail, raising the conviction of Liberian journalists to hold together and resist intolerance and alarm that speech must for once be free, especially within the realm of public service.

Regrettably, despite a revolutionary coup in 1980, a new democracy-based constitution in 1985, despite ravaging wars that reorganized the entire state in 1990 and again in 2003, the very contempt of 1964 remains ridiculously unclarified in 2014.

This simply says that the purpose of the Press Union of Liberia is just as relevant today (perhaps more) as it was 50 years ago.

Across these years, the work of the Liberian media - now away from just newspapers and radio as in 1964 - has become even more challenged.

The rights to freely speak, think and write - as guaranteed by the constitution have often been suppressed by various methods. At one point it was fancy to lock journalists up. As sensitivity grew and there is now the resort to court of laws to prevent that, other measures grew. Those have included shutting down, burning and in some instances torture and death.

In more recent years, printing establishments were warned against printing certain papers, and as more papers have metamorphosed to owning printing presses, multiple, crime-based lawsuits are cropping up, with intent to shut down media houses.

In still other cases, media houses have been shut down on claims of hate crimes, and at times just short of sedition

In all of these, our observation is that governments - in and out - have simply not come to grips with the reality that none can stop others from disagreeing in words, unless they have the capacity to stop others from thinking. Because the latter is impossible, efforts to prevent people from disagreeing is but a failed venture that only contributes to the evolution of conflict in our society.

Ladies and Gentlemen:

Given that we have dedicated our 50th Anniversary to the fight against Ebola, we are keen not to get involved with rhetoric that will take over the recognition we are giving to the fight. Nonetheless, it is fair to note that the fight against Ebola can only succeed when the various parties are confident that we are all in it together. That means, principles are standard and do not sway from case to case.

We have a situation here, where all Ebola deaths are buried en masse, and then burnt. Note is taken of the Ugandan Doctor from Redemption Hospital and the Catholic Priest. In the future - perhaps with better knowledge - some deaths are allowed special burial rites.

At one point, all unexplained deaths will be treated as Ebola deaths. A lot of loved ones were allowed to be carried away by a burial, then a burning team. At some point, the ratio changed, and the death certificates began. With deaths extending into the families of lost ones, an alarm has sounded.

While crying aloud about denial and traditional practices, and telling all relatives and friends to accept the Ebola reality, a new row has come forth when deaths in high quarters are cited to be Ebola.

There must be one standard that will instead get appreciation from all. Otherwise, those who have also doubted the circumstances of Ebola in the first place will always have reason to maintain their doubts.

On the other hand, the Ebola situation has brought more challenge to the role of the media in reporting occurrences in our society. The state of emergency and yet unexplained restrictions introduces a tricky situation for a battle that must be fought inclusively. While media has pledged to work along in providing public education, the yet unknown keeps media in a position of fear, not sure of what happens next.

In all of these, the Press Union has become a victim, observing 50 years of existence with a closure of a fearless newspaper outside of due process. As difficult as we find this, we still look forward in confidence to a High Court ruling on a number of constitutional issues that will effectively open up the space for freedom and justice for journalists and others in the wider Liberian society.

So, as we arrange the 50th anniversary, our admonition is for journalists to strengthen their drive into making their journalism one that tells the entire Liberian story in a factual and inclusive manner. Our admonition is for journalists to take the greater responsibility of making their journalism enviable, stepping up to the challenge to ensure opportunities for all.

On the other hand, after 50 years, and after a number of transformation in Liberia, it is time that the government - including the legislature, the judiciary and of course the executive - take additional efforts to tolerate dissent and disagreement. This is the purpose of journalism, and of democracy and human rights. Appreciation of free expression is more of the issues and expressions that one find especially offensive. The wider the diversity in our thought and speech, the better we can work together to find a common ground.

We will continue working to improve the quality of journalism in Liberia; We will continue with our self-regulatory mechanism to show greater accountability by Liberian journalists to their audience, but we demand that going beyond fifty years - there must be increased opportunities to make journalism the pivot of our democracy, our governance system and stretching out accountability in Liberian society.

Our disagreement with journalists should not be expressed through the power we wield, to the extent of violating rights and ignoring guarantees of freedom and accountability.

Thank You!


LOAD-DATE: October 2, 2014


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2014 AllAfrica Global Media.
