234 of 500 DOCUMENTS



The NEWS (Monrovia)


September 16, 2014


Liberian Woman Commits 'Suicide'


LENGTH: 389 words


The fear of having the Ebola virus disease has led a Liberian woman living in Lagos to commit suicide by hanging herself in Lagos last Friday.

The woman, identified as Kate, decided to hang herself in the early hours of Friday after falling sick and thinking that what she suffered from was the Ebola Virus. 

The incident caused confusion on Bankole Street, Isheri-Oke, when residents woke up to the sight of a woman hanging on a tree, wearing a black sweater and orange skirt. It was gathered from the residents that the woman did not live on the street.

Residents who spoke on condition of anonymity said she was a Liberian who worked in a sachet water factory before she died.

While they said the woman had been sickly for some time, residents said she did not appear to have any problem with anyone in the community.

But after the outbreak of the Ebola disease that was brought to Nigeria by a Liberian, Patrick Sawyer, some of the people in the area opted not to have anything to do with her.

One of the residents who pleaded anonymity said, "We see her in this neighborhood every day. She always looked sick but people stopped selling to her after the Ebola outbreak. It could be because she was a Liberian and looked sickly. This might have frustrated her."

Another resident said, "She attended a church in the area and her church members still saw her yesterday. I used to see her every day in the dress she died in. She was sick and people in this area avoided her, especially after the Ebola outbreak."

When contacted, the Lagos State Police Public Relations Officer, Ngozi Braide, said she was not aware of the incident and promised to check with the police.

In another development, Minister of Health Professor Oyebuchi Chukwu, while making a speech during a requiem Mass held in memory of late Dr. Stella Adedevoh on Friday at Holy Cross Cathedral, Lagos, confirmed the report that a South African woman had been quarantined in Lagos for having symptoms of Ebola,

Prof. Oyebuchi advised Nigerians to always look out for fresh cases of Ebola because Nigeria is not yet free from the disease until there was no trace of Ebola in Liberia, Guinea, Congo, Sierra Leone.

The minister explained that the Federal Government decided to shift school resumption date because of the need to train teachers on how to take care of pupils in schools.

235 of 500 DOCUMENTS



The NEWS (Monrovia)


September 16, 2014


Respect Rights in Ebola Response


LENGTH: 134 words


An International Right group, Human Rights Watch, has urged governments in Ebola affected West African counties to ensure rights protections as a crucial element in controlling the unprecedented epidemic ravaging the region. 

In a statement issued Monday, Human Rights Watch expressed its sympathy to the families, friends, and colleagues of those who have died as a result of the Ebola outbreak, and recognized the courage of many health workers and others in caring for the sick.

The group said governments in Ebola-affected countries should better protect health workers from infection, limit use of quarantines, address the gender dimensions of the outbreak, ensure security forces responding to the crisis, respect basic rights, and facilitate independent monitoring of emergency measures and donations.

The NEWS (Monrovia)


September 16, 2014


Senatorial Election Decision Out of Order


LENGTH: 566 words


The Ebola Disease remains the number one killer for now and it could continue to rage havoc unless it is contained within the most reasonable time. No one knows exactly when the disease would be eradicated within the West African sub-region. As long the virus remains active and continues to spread in the sub-region, it poses a serious threat to our survival. 

While Our Government is struggling to deal with the Ebola spread, the Chairman of the National Elections Commission (NEC) says both houses of the national legislature have informed the commission to hold the special senatorial elections next month as scheduled.

Speaking Last Friday during an interview with the Voice of America (VOA), Cllr. Jerome Kokoya said he had written the legislature asking for a postponement of the October 14 election to December this year, saying his commission could not hold a free, fair, and credible election because of the ongoing deadly Ebola crisis. He said consultations are continuing on the holding of the elections in October which the Liberian constitution says must be held on the second Tuesday in October. However, Chairman Kokoya said some lawmakers have expressed concern that by not having the elections [at all] could create a constitutional crisis, which could have wider consequences.

"They have decided that we must hold elections. The question they are working on now is the technical side of it. The Judiciary Committees of both the House of Representatives and the Senate were meeting, and we were told by the Speaker that by early next week, we're going to have some information from them with respect to the date. Like us, they too want the election to go on this year so as to avoid any serious constitutional issues come January," Kokoya told the VOA.

Based On The mandate from lawmakers, Kokoya said he would begin publishing the final listing of candidates by this week or next week. However, he acknowledged that there are challenges under the current situation with the Ebola disease having a potential effect on the population and the suspension of several flights to Liberia due to Ebola crisis could make the election even more expensive or perhaps inconsequential.

As Much As Liberians respect the constitution which provides for holding special senatorial election in October, the Ebola crisis has overshadowed the spirits of the election and makes the entire contest inconsequential.

Right Now, Most Liberians, if not all are frightened by the human calamity caused by the Ebola virus. Last week, the World Health Organization (WHO) warned that there would be an "exponential" rise in the cases of Ebola particularly in Liberia if 1,000 beds are not made available to deal with the worst Ebola disaster in history.

The Lawmakers Must understand that we are at war and our government does not have the capacity to deal with the current situation that has overwhelmed us. A constitutional crisis is not important than the survival of our people. What good is the election when people are dying? How can you hold election when the population has been advised against touching or coming in close contact? The human destruction from the Ebola crisis is unimaginable; therefore, those suggesting the holding of the election in October are callous.

We Believe There will be sufficient time to hold a national conversation on constitutional issues. For now, we must eradicate Ebola first.


LOAD-DATE: September 17, 2014


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2014 AllAfrica Global Media.
All Rights Reserved


237 of 500 DOCUMENTS



The NEWS (Monrovia)


September 16, 2014


PUL Raises Newspaper Closure With Ellen


LENGTH: 350 words


The leadership of the Press Union of Liberia (PUL) last Friday paid a courtesy call on President Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf, an Executive Mansion release has disclosed.

Speaking during the meeting, PUL President Abdullai Kamara assured the Liberian leader that the Union remains a part of the National Taskforce and are playing the role it can but with very limited support and resources. 

He said the Ebola virus outbreak has also affected every sphere of the media landscape with newsprints and advertisement all running low.

"The Union is also concerned about freedom and rights issues during the outbreak and is prepared to work with government to address outstanding freedom and right issues concerning the media," Mr. Kamara emphasized.

He used the opportunity to raise the issue about the closure of the National Chronicle newspaper and support for community radio stations across the country.

Mr. Kamara thanked President Johnson-Sirleaf for accepting to meet with them and thanked her for the effort government is making thus far in trying to contain the further spread of Ebola virus in the country.

Responding, the Liberian leader welcomed continuous engagement with civil society groups such as the PUL and others on a routine basis.

She agreed with the PUL that community radio stations must be supported to enable them play their role during this critical health crisis in the country.

The Liberian leader urged the media not to heighten the fears of Liberians and the international community by their reportage.

She informed the PUL that the issue of the National Chronicle is before the courts and will be resolved within that context.

Although President Sirleaf claimed that the issue of National Chronicle Newspaper is before the court but the Liberia National Police are still investigating the paper's publisher Philipbert Brown.

The paper's license was suspended by the Ministry of Information pending the outcome of the probe. The comment by President Sirleaf indicates that she is not aware that the matter is still languishing at the LNP headquarters on Capitol Hill and not the Temple of Justice.

238 of 500 DOCUMENTS



The NEWS (Monrovia)


September 16, 2014


UN Assures Liberia of Support to Fight Ebola


LENGTH: 580 words


The United Nations Under-Secretary-General for Peacekeeping Operations, Mr. Hervé Ladsous has assured President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf that the United Nations remains on the side of Liberia in the wake of the Ebola epidemic.

He said the UN is prepared to support ongoing international efforts led by the World Health Organization (WHO) and others to contain the virus.

He reiterated that WHO has taken the initiative to mobilize the entire UN system and beyond to effectively respond to the outbreak with the aim of containing further spread of the deadly Ebola virus disease in the sub-region. 

"Currently, the United Nations Secretary-General, Mr. Ban Ki-moon has taken advantage of the ongoing United Nations General Assembly to engage different levels of world leaders and is committed to doing all he can to stop the epidemic," Mr. Ladsous noted.

According to an Executive Mansion release, the UN Under-Secretary General made the statement when he met with the Liberian leader at her Foreign Ministry office recently.

Mr. Ladsous conveyed deep feelings of Mr. Ban about the current Ebola epidemic in Liberia and other countries in the sub-region. "My visit to Liberia is also to express the solidarity of the Secretary-General and to assure President Sirleaf of the UN system's commitment to help mitigate the risk placed on the hard won gains made in Liberia so far. I am here to sit with you and the Government on how we can more effectively help the situation," Mr. Ladsous said.

For her part, President Sirleaf thanked the UN Under-Secretary-General for his visit to Liberia and recounted previous visits including that of the UN Systems Coordinator on Ebola, David Nabarro and others to help respond to the outbreak.

The Liberian leader described the Ebola virus as an unknown enemy to the Liberian setting, making it critical to the respond efforts. "Our collective response is yet to catch up with the acceleration rate of the virus thus far, but concrete efforts in strategic partnership with the international community and international responders are now in place to mitigate the situation," President Sirleaf pointed out.

President Sirleaf briefed Mr. Ladsous about several initial measures taken by the Government including the closure of schools, entertainment centers, video clubs, etc. and noted that cultural and traditional practices also remain at the heart of efforts to break the transmission of the disease.

She, however, expressed hope that the end will come soon as there are so many success stories associated with the release of more survivors from the treatment centers across the country.

"Our regular healthcare system was hard hit by the outbreak and needs support and attention to be able to respond to the growing number of non-Ebola cases that are also adding to the death rate in the country. We are working with our partners to fully restore regular healthcare, and the UN's involvement is encouraged," President Johnson-Sirleaf urged.

The President pointed out that the Ebola outbreak is having serious consequences on the country's economy, and assured that the government is working with the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund and others to mitigate the situation now and the post-Ebola period.

She informed Mr. Ladsous that the security situation in the country so far remains calm, and pointed out that the desire of training more personnel in the security sector, particularly the police was on course but now restrained by the Ebola outbreak.


LOAD-DATE: September 17, 2014


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2014 AllAfrica Global Media.
All Rights Reserved


239 of 500 DOCUMENTS



The Analyst


September 15, 2014


'Stop Abusing State of Emergency' - Woods


LENGTH: 1299 words


Early fears about the declaration of a state of emergency by Government to contain a vicious pestilence were that it would be used to prey on unsuspecting individuals and groups, particularly dissenting voices that the Government has got eyes on for a long time and that it would set loose marauding armed men upon the civilian population. The fears have not proven unwarranted.

In less than a month of the declaration, the fears found legitimacy in the cow-boy styled knockdown of the Chronicle Newspaper and the gunning down of an adolescent youth West Point.

This has alarmed, though not surprised, members of the Liberian human rights community who understand the traits and behaviors of Liberia's military and police forces and had predict the perversion of the state of emergency. Now another prominent member of the community, Kofi Woods, currently visiting the United States is warning against continued abuse of the state of emergency. The Analyst reports. 

The former Public Works Minister now Legal Consultant of the Liberia Law Society is warning that the state of emergency in Liberia should not be used by the government and its security forces to violate individual and collective rights of the people. Woods, one of Liberia's renowned human rights lawyers, urges Government not to use the state of emergency imposed professedly to address a health crisis to militarize the country and to restrict press freedom and freedom of speech.

He made the remarks, according to a dispatch from the United States, while speaking to journalists. Woods used the occasion to condemn the shooting to death of Shaki Kamara, a youth in West Point, by soldiers of the Armed Forces of Liberia, as well as the closure of the National Chronicle Newspaper; terming these actions as overreaching, heavy handed and unwarranted.

He called on the Government to commission an Independent Inquiry into the circumstances leading to the shooting and killing of Kamara and the bullet wounds suffered by another citizen. Woods also called on the government to re-open the Chronicle Newspaper and halt all further intimidation of the Press, including the restriction on the freedom of the Chronicle's publisher to travel.

Atty. Woods insists that the Independent Inquiry should also examine the constitutionality of the blanketed state of emergency, the use of the security forces during this national health emergency, as well as their deportment and exercise of force. He noted that the work of the independent panel must also consider the future role of security and military personnel in non- military crisis, and the improvement of the psychology and capacity of security forces to deal with matters of civil engagements.

The human rights lawyer also strongly criticized the declaration of the state of emergency, noting that it lacks specificities as to its purpose, scope and limitations, as required by the Constitution of Liberia.

He questioned the constitutionality of the President's declaration of a state of emergency; noting that while Article 86 (a) of the Constitution grants the President the power to declare a state of emergency, Article 86 (b) clearly states that: "A state of emergency may be declared only where there is a threat or outbreak of war or where there is civil unrest affecting the existence, security or well-being of the Republic amounting to a clear and present danger."

Woods noted that the best way to deal with the Ebola emergency while at the same time avoiding a constitutional crisis, stigmatizing the country and population and giving security forces the perception that they have the liberty to trample the rights of citizens is to use the Public Health Law, as opposed to the imposition a sweeping constitutional state of emergency with no specific objectives, targets and benchmarks.

"How can we impose a national state of emergency, quarantine entire swaths of our population, restrict the movement of our own people, but at the same time criticize other countries and even airlines for imposing similar restrictions on our citizens,? Woods argued.

Woods maintained that the Ebola crisis is a national public health emergency that must be dealt with as such, but noted that political decisions and considerations continue to dominate real health decisions and programs. In a health emergency, we must listen to the health experts and health workers to guide our decisions and actions and revert to other legal/constitutional actions only where the public health law proves inadequate.

"Without any doubt, the Government's policies and actions appear uncoordinated, fragmented and fraught with contradictions. This has led to increased distrust in our national government and lack of national ownership of the on-going fight against the Ebola Virus", the renowned human rights activist averred.

Atty. Woods noted that some of the recent policies of government constitute what he terms as "moral sin and ethical transgression against the poor and weak in our society," emphasizing that the government must return to the drawing board to review some of those policy options, in the hope of restoring confidence and re-energizing the fight against Ebola.

He has recommended the review of all policies and parallel actions to address the suffering of the poor. This includes the current restrictions on freedom of movement, health interventions, humanitarian intervention and other issues. "As a nation and people, now is the time for us to begin to address with urgency, the moral, legal and ethical imperatives heighten the fight against Ebola, restore the hope of our people, and assure them that this too shall come to pass, Woods, observed.

Lamenting the death of Dr. Abraham Borbor whom he referred to as a schoolmate, Atty Woods expressed his condolences to the bereaved family and maintained that the Liberian Government is under obligation to conduct a full-scale medical inquiry on the use of the experimental drug (ZMAPP) and bring to closure any doubt associated with its application. The former Public Works Minister has made a number of recommendations to Government in the fight against Ebola.

Amongst other thing, Mr. Wood called for a review all actions and the term of reference of the National Task Force and restructure the national framework for policy, action and implementation; prioritizing the needs and demands of health workers and practitioners. Those at the forefront of this fight continue to complain of neglect thus victimizing the foot soldiers and a review and restructure and National Health Team led by the Ministry of Health. Bold decisions need to be taken in the regards.

He also urged government provide an initial financial update on all income, contributions and expenditures made to the fight against Ebola to date; develop task-sharing pathways assigning unto itself the monitoring and evaluation component of the fight while existing INGOs and their national counterparts, including the Liberian Red Cross must be empowered to do the implementation; and that 85% of salaries, allowances and benefits in higher brackets (Executive, Legislative and Judiciary) must be sacrificed for three months during the emergency to provide for the poor.

This is a real sacrifice demonstrate that they too can sacrifice to help rescue our country, the human rights advocate said, adding: "All non-essential civil servants must be retrained and redeployed to assist with the fight against Ebola. The crisis with volunteers won't be occurring if the already paid civil servants are re-deployed and that there should be no negotiations and sale of oil blocks and concessions."

In another development and in support of the appeals made by Dr. Jerry Brown of ELWA, he has donated a laptop through CASE-Liberia and will send some drugs to assist the treatment center.


LOAD-DATE: September 15, 2014


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2014 AllAfrica Global Media.
All Rights Reserved


240 of 500 DOCUMENTS



The Analyst


September 15, 2014


Brumskine Provides Aid to Ebola-Fighting Institutions


LENGTH: 1034 words


Emergency relief efforts to contain the deadly Ebola virus, as it was during the civil conflict, have largely been concentrated in Montserrado County, understandably because the casualty figures are high in this urban province of Liberia.

But death tolls are also climbing in the countryside and there is evidently little nor no major concentration in terms of external assistance. Charles Walker Brumskine, the political leader of the opposition Liberty Party has discerned the disparity. Over the weekend, he was in Bong and Nimba Counties where he delivered much needed assistance. The Analyst reports.

During the weekend, and following a meeting with President Sirleaf and other opposition political parties where she rallied all Liberians to assist in the fight against Ebola, Liberty Party strongman Charles Walker Brumskine was in Bong and Nimba Counties. 

He entered Gbarnga, Bong County on Friday, September 12, 2014, along with the county's Senator Franklin Siakor, where they presented several consignments of rice to be distributed to quarantined communities in Gbarnga: Civil Compound and Millionaire Quarters. They also delivered rice to the association of disabled persons in Gbarnga.

Speaking to The Analyst in Gbarnga, Cllr. Brumskine said that he decided to visit Bong County in order to identify with the people as he has been doing in other counties.

He said his presence in Bong as well as Nimba counties, where he visited Saturday, would make a difference in the lives of some of the people.

Brumskine said if only one life was saved because that one person's trust him and the belief in the need to do things differently, his trip is worth the while. He implored all Liberians to follow the instructions of the medical experts, adding, "We will overcome this national catastrophe."

The standard bearer emeritus of the Liberty Party emphasized that every Liberian needed to embark on a personal crusade within the limit of the capacity of their resources to complement government and the international community's efforts to rid Liberia of Ebola. Counselor Brumskine called on Liberians to stop doubting the existence of Ebola in the country and take advantage of preventative measures recommended by the World Health Organization, (WHO) and the Ministry of Health and Social Welfare.

Speaking to a cross session of Bong County citizens Friday, September 11, 2014 in Gbarnga, Counselor Brumskine said he was in the County to identify with citizens amidst deadly Ebola virus disease outbreak in the County. According to the Bong County Health Team, the virus has killed more sixty persons in the county, including health care providers and ordinary citizens.

Counselor Brumskine said Bong County is centrally located and hosts thousands of Liberians from different parts of the country and therefore called on residents of the county to join efforts in combating the deadly Ebola virus diseases that continues to devastate the country. He noted that his visit to the county was the beginning of series of visits he intends to do in Bong County in the coming weeks.

As part of his visit to Bong County, he provided 65 five bags of rice to the Bong County branch of Liberty Party for distribution to quarantined quarters in the county. It can be recalled that the LP strongman on August 16, 2014 provided LD$100,000 to the Bong County Health Team to support the work of the Team in fighting Ebola in the County.

Then last Saturday the LP strongman was in Nimba County where he and the former Superintendent of Nimba County, Edith Gongloe Weh, presented PPE to Dr. Albert Willicor, Chief Medical Officer, United Methodist Hospital, Ganta.

Making the presentation, Cllr. Brumskine told Dr. Willicor that the fight against the Ebola virus begins with the medical professionals who are at the frontline in the national effort to contain the virus.

"That is why all of our medical practitioners and health workers need to be protected with personal protective equipment," he said. Cllr. Brumskine and Hon. Gongloe Weh also presented a consignment of rice to be distributed to quarantined families in Nimba, along with other materials to be used in containing the Ebola virus.

Brumskine's message to the people of Bong and Nimba counties was uniform: everyone with whom you interact must be presumed Ebola infected. He said his presence in the counties which have produced reasonably high numbers of virus-infected persons meant that no matter the situation, he cannot shy away from coming to visit his fellow countrymen and women.

"Until the Ebola virus is eradicated from our country, we will have to do away with certain cultural habits, such as handshaking, hugging, kissing, and so forth," he told citizens in Bong and Nimba Counties.

"We are an intimate and caring people, but we have to now stop providing home healthcare for the sick, even if is a close relative, and have the health professionals take care of those who are ill, regardless of what we think the ailment is. Until the doctors have ruled out Ebola, it has to be hand off. No touching, not even your spouse."

In a related development, Liberty Party Bong County Senatorial Candidate Franklin Siakor has provided US$500 to Community Radio Stations in Gbarnga as part of efforts to intensify awareness and outreach activities in Bong County. The stations include Radio Gbarnga and Super Bongese Radio.

Mr. Siakor told The Analyst that the donation was to complement the efforts of the stations in reaching remote villages in the county to provide the opportunity for the voiceless to make inputs in the midst of the rapid spread of the virus.

The Liberty Party Bong County Senatorial Candidate also noted that the gesture is to also be used to improve the station's programming. Mr. Siakor recommended that portion of the money be used be used to purchase digital recorders for the Language Programs at the two stations.

He commanded the Management of the Radio Gbarnga and Super Bongese for the role they continue to play in the fight against Ebola by creating the platform for medical practitioners, civil society actors and community people in the county to create awareness about the danger of the Ebola virus disease and preventative measures.


LOAD-DATE: September 15, 2014

241 of 500 DOCUMENTS



The Analyst


September 15, 2014


U.S. Anti-Ebola Aid - Announces $100 Million Donation


LENGTH: 628 words


If the Ebola virus refuses to be contained and continues to claim the lives of many more Liberians, it would not be because the international community has failed to help Liberia overcome it.

This is particularly true for Liberia's traditional friends, chiefly the United States of America, which, for its part, reportedly made an intervention as early as March this year when the deadly Ebola was first announced creeping on the population of neighboring Guinea. Again, the US has expanded its assistance in the wake of predictions that the fight against the deadly virus would be long and costly. The Analyst reports.

The United States says it is committing more than $100 million to combat Ebola Virus Disease (EVD) in West Africa since the outbreak was first reported in March 2014, and has expanded its efforts and increased personnel in response to the growing severity of the health emergency. 

In a statement delivered by the US Ambassador to Liberia last Thursday at a public forum, the United States announced it has already deployed than 100 specialists working in Ebola-affected countries, including a 26-member Disaster Assistance Response Team (DART) in Liberia, Sierra Leone and Guinea, and more than 70 disease-control experts from the Atlanta-based Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).

In April 2014, the US ambassador said, U.S. laboratory experts upgraded the testing laboratory at the Liberia Institute for Biological Research (LIBR) so that it could test for Ebola, which was not done in Liberia at the time. Since then, their work has helped to more than double LIBR's testing capacity.

"CDC, in partnership with the Global Outbreak Alert and Response Network and the U.S. National Institutes of Health, established the second Ebola-testing laboratory in Liberia. The mobile testing laboratory, placed at the ELWA campus, shortened the response time of tests for patients at the largest facility currently in Liberia," Ambassador Deborah Malac announced.

She added that, "Since August 23, the U.S. Government, through DART, has airlifted more than 16 tons of medical supplies and emergency equipment to Liberia, including 10,000 sets of personal protective equipment (PPE), 5,000 body bags, 2 water treatment units, 2 portable water tanks, capable of storing 10,000liters each, 500 infrared thermometers to bolster Ebola Screening efforts, and 100 rolls of plastic sheeting for construction of Ebola Treatment Units (ETUs)

In addition to bringing in supplies from outside the region, DART has purchased basic supplies locally, including 50,000 pieces of soap, 400 mattresses, 5,200 gallons of chlorine, and 2,500 buckets, she said, noting, "USAID has provided the World Health Organization with 105,000 sets of PPE for healthcare staff and outbreak investigators in Ebola-affected countries."

Other assistance from the US, she said, include, a charter flight, funded by the U.S. Government and UNICEF that brought more than 40 tons of chlorine and 400-thousand pairs of medical gloves into Monrovia; supporting the UN Humanitarian Air Service (UNHAS), which is operating flights in and out of Liberia, Sierra Leone, and Guinea, the United States by providing $10 million to support the African Union deployment of 100 health workers to West Africa. Ambassador Malac said the U.S. Government is working to expand the pipeline of medical equipment and supplies flowing into Monrovia.

In coming weeks, the DART will airlift 130,000 sets of personal protective equipment (PPE) to ensure the health care workers have the supplies they need to safely do their jobs, she said, stating further that USAID has also funded grants to conduct social mobilization campaigns, expand treatment units and to support the safe removal of the bodies of Ebola victims.


LOAD-DATE: September 15, 2014


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2014 AllAfrica Global Media.

242 of 500 DOCUMENTS



The Analyst


September 15, 2014


Ref. - We Think You Must Attend [column]


LENGTH: 825 words


Your Excellency:

All indications are that you will not be attending the United Nations General Assembly this year, and that you have turned over to some Government delegation the role ascribed to you as head of state to appear before the world body to give the state of the nation. The other day, it was the Minister of Defense who addressed the Security Council of the United Nations. In the next couple of days, it would be one Liberian or the other that would take of podium to act in your stead.

We understand, and somewhat acknowledge, that you are not making the trip and would not be seen and heard at the United Nations as expected because you intend to be on the ground here with Liberians to provide leadership, inspiration and confidence as the fight against the virulent Ebola virus rages. Perhaps you think, and we somewhat acknowledge, that it is more honorable, substantive and worthy staying on the ground to back up efforts and rally fighting forces repel Ebola, to comfort victims' families and to keep a semblance of normalcy than to embark on a talking shop tour. Or perhaps you think, and may be advised, that nothing you may say or do in New York that your principle deputies cannot say or do. 

While the justification for staying on the home front to mother the fight against Ebola sounds good, we think your personal presence in New York for a few days to rally international support for the situation back home is more strategic, rewarding and critical for ultimate victory against the pandemic. We remember when you were often criticized for frequent foreign travels at the onset of your administration, your defense as amplified by supporters was that the magic wand for Liberia's recovery and development lied outside of the country since we lacked the resources and expertise, and in fact the recognition and respect of the international community, due to a protracted civil conflict. And it was said that no other member of your administration--and no other Liberian for that matter--had the charisma and acumen to charm the then highly suspicious international community and to bring home the badly need goodies. And, to some convincing degree, you proved yourself an indisputable maestro of diplomacy, well articulate and well respected. A lot of the goodies came.

So, Madam President, let us ask: When does a child destined to be great prove its worth to parents and the nation? Or what is the best time a true mother proves her parenthood? When does a warrior show his trait and powers?

For us, if there was any time in your life, and in the history of Liberia, you needed to manifest your inborn powers as an Iron Lady, an international whiz, an acclaimed lobbyist and fundraiser, the time is now. While it is true that Ebola's temporary triumph over Liberia is due to the fact that it's the country's first experience and also due to pervasive denial and distrust, we believe the major reason is the lack of capacity--both human and material capacities--to respond quickly and decisively. And we also have no doubt that the worst scenario predictions could come true or be thwarted depending on how much is done to address this resource capacity problem.

And, Your Excellency, the upcoming General Assembly of the United Nations presents the perfect platform for Liberia, particularly for you as the head of state, to get over the resource capacity problem. The time has come to, as you are well known for doing, make the global community rally around Liberia in this great time of need. You know the key international partners very well than any of your lieutenants do, and the international partners do have explicit confidence and deeper respect for you than they do for any of your lieutenants, and would therefore listen and feel moved to act swiftly to our emergency crisis where you to appear before them in person.

As anyone would note, Madam President, the scourge and trail of the Ebola virus is no different from an armed incursion. Like a military insurrection, Ebola kills. It maims. It makes orphans, widows and paupers. It ruins the national economy and renders the nation vulnerable to intermittent instability. So, let us ask again: If fatalities and upheaval caused by Ebola had come from an armed incursion, wouldn't you be in haste to run to the international community to rescue? Certainly, this pandemic has overwhelmed your administration. It has put to risk everything and everyone you preside over as head of state.

The ultimate solution lies in a global response and you are well suited to drum up that response. Other leaders from countries similarly plagued by Ebola will be making their various cases; they will be competing for the ears and hands of the economic powers meeting at the 69th General Assembly of the United States. Liberia cannot afford to lose the grand opportunity in these critical times. We trust you can do better. You need to attend.

Thanks for listening to voice of reason.


LOAD-DATE: September 15, 2014


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2014 AllAfrica Global Media.
All Rights Reserved

The Analyst


September 15, 2014


Ghana's President Visits Liberia Sept. 15


LENGTH: 279 words


In respond to devastations the Ebola virus has unleashed on Liberia, Sierra Leone, Guinea and other West African countries, several African nations have closed their borders. At the onset of the Ebola advent in Liberia, Ghanaians reportedly picked up bulldozers to demolish a refugee camp where Liberians resided for over 20 years and chased them out. 

This rather unfriendly response, which pundits describe as un-African and inhumane, has triggered outrage amongst the affected countries, sparking diplomatic talks around the Continent to lift the African quarantine. Reports of the arrival in the country today of President John Dramani Mahama of Ghana to show "solidarity" appear to point to a breakthrough into the diplomatic complications or a commencement of damage control measures by some African countries. The Analyst reports.

Ghanaian President and the ECOWAS current Chairman John Dramani Mahama will pay an official visit to Liberia today Monday, September 15, 2014. While in Liberia, the Ghanaian Leader will make a donation of assorted food items to aid Liberia's fight against the deadly Ebola virus.

According to a Foreign Ministry release, the visit by the Ghanaian leader will also be a show of solidarity with the people of Ghana to Liberia as the country goes through this difficult period. The release said President Mahama will also meet President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf for a brief bilateral discussion.

The military aircraft carrying the food items arrived in Liberia on Saturday at the Roberts International airport. The Ghanaian Leader is expected to also pay similar visits to neighboring Sierra Leone and Guinea which are also hard hit by the Ebola virus.

244 of 500 DOCUMENTS



The Analyst


September 15, 2014


'Tell Us Your Mission or Leave Bong County'


BYLINE: Edward B. Palmer


LENGTH: 436 words


Bong County superintendent Madam Selena P. Mappy has warned international aid partners without defined objectives of operation in the county to account for their operations in Bong or leave. The deadly Ebola outbreak has attracted huge attention of the international community for quick intervention as it becomes a matter of global threat and concern. 

Accordingly, the World Health Organization, Medicine San Frontier, USAID, Samaritan Purse and others have been engaged in the country intervening to bring the spread of the disease under control. But Bong County Superintendent Mappy said some aid agencies have been operating in her county with some degree of insincerity.

Addressing a large audience during the dedication ceremony of the Bong County Ebola Treatment Unit erected by the Medcine San Frontiers (MSF) recently, Supt. Mappy noted that many aid partners are operating in the county without a defined goal or objective.

She asserted that aid partners are carrying out operations without reference to local authorities, adding that whatever aid that is being provided by these partners, be it financial or logistical, is not accounted for and not done with the consent with the county authorities.

Although she did not name a particular aid agency in Bong that her office is not officially aware of, she is not withstanding expressed believe that aid agencies should know that it is the locals that should set priorities for areas of their operations.

"Let me be clear about this, to you our partners, you either tell us what you came here to do or leave. I am saying this because most of you come here to eat the same money you are claiming to be providing to assist the county without achieving anything," she said. She warned further, "So you either tell us what you have or don't get involved. We don't want people operating here under false pretense," she added.

Supt. Mappy who was praised for her efforts in ensuring the erection of the treatment unit, lauded the efforts of MSF, citing the enviable and the major role they continue to play in helping to eradicate the deadly Ebola virus not only in the county, but in the country at large.

She expressed confidence that with the erection of the treatment unit, the rate of Ebola cases will reduce in the county since, according to her, they have somewhere to admit, observe and treat suspected and confirmed cases.

The Superintendent called for concerted efforts in dealing with the spread of the virus, while cautioning the Bong Legislative Caucus to do away with politics and unite in the fight against Ebola as there is no time for political bickering.

245 of 500 DOCUMENTS



The Analyst


September 15, 2014


Liberian Youths Unite Against Ebola


LENGTH: 1035 words


A conglomeration of accredited grassroots youth-led development organizations as well as community volunteers has galvanized efforts to combat the widespread and unprecedented Ebola virus disease in Liberia in partnership with families, schools, communities, faith-based organizations, nongovernmental institutions, businesses, and government.

This joint initiative, which is named and styled National Youth Action Against Ebola (NYAA-EVD) focuses on community mobilization, capacity building, policy advocacy, awareness and sensitivity, WASH (water, sanitation and hygiene) education, tracking the implementation of the Liberian government National Action Plan and its Operational Plan for Accelerated Response to Re-occurrence of Ebola Epidemic as it relates to highlighting transparency and accountability issues. 

NYAA-EVD has also designed a strategic plan to assist the government and other international partners in carrying out training, public education and contact-tracing as well as explaining in simple terms what it means to be isolated, quarantined, suspected, probable, and confirmed as it pertains to the Ebola virus disease.

Launched on August 22 at the Friends of Friends Hatai Association Headquarters in Monrovia, the NYAA-EVD engages, education, and empowers a new generation of tolerant and critical thinkers of passionate volunteers. NYAA-EVD has been able to mobilize, focus person in 12 counties in Liberia to join the fight against the deadly Ebola virus that has engulfed Liberia since March of this year.

NYAA-EVD creates a platform that incorporates every registered nonprofit youth-led organization alongside people of all ages and gender through a mutual voluntary partnership agreement designed to involve people and fast-track progress. The youth-led movement also strives to enlighten and broaden the minds of people within Liberia to understand basic facts about Ebola as it relates to signs and symptoms, diagnosis, prevention and control.

James Karyor, one of the co-founders of NYAA-EVD, who spearheads Mobilization, Program & Outreach activities asserted that the ultimate goal of this youth-led anti-Ebola organization is primarily geared towards motivating and mobilizing young people to get involved in the fight against Ebola through engaging, educating and empowering people of all ages and gender.

"Living in the hardest-hit country which already accounts for about half of all cases and deaths with an exponential increase of new cases in a very short span of time; the young people who constitute over 60 percent of the population are not only at high risk, but need to be involved in the decision making process and empowered to take action in their communities without any unnecessary bureaucracy" the staunch youth anti-Ebola campaigner noted.

Karyor who is also the Executive Director of Consolidated Youth for Peace and Development recounted that since the pronouncement from the Liberian leader encouraging all citizens to join the fight in kicking Ebola out of Liberia; many young people across the country have been eager to get involved, but don't know how and what their responsibilities are in such medical crisis.

The passionate anti-Ebola campaigner indicated: "NYAA-EVD was established to bridge the gap in bringing young people on board, harnessing their talents, and creating an enabling environment for young people to be involved, inspired and informed in eradicating the deadliest Ebola outbreak the world has ever known."

The Coordinator for Mobilization, Program & Outreach pointed out that NYAA-EVD has initiated three training workshops and awareness in the Police Academy community, Swagger Island and ClaraTown community, where the youth-led anti-Ebola organization trained 210 community volunteers. The youth movement has also carried out two media outreach activities on Radio VERITAS and Truth FM with status updates from Bomi, Margibi, Nimba and Grand Cape Mount respectively.

"We are doing all we can, utilizing our ideas and scarce resources without any financial or material support from any source. Consequently, I would like to plead for urgent support from embassies accredited near Monrovia, local and international nonprofit organizations, and the government and people of Liberia" the youth leader requested.

Stephen B. Lavalah, a Cuttington University trained public health practitioner who heads NYAA-EVD disclosed that the outbreak of the world's deadliest Ebola virus disease has drifted in another direction to spin out of control in an already shaky health system.

"We have got a broken public health system with a very minute portion of our national budget allocated for preventive medicine and epidemiological research. As a result, our country has become the hardest-hit, with many more new cases expected due to dilapidated medical infrastructures, poor public transport system, lack of training, insufficient logistics, limited number of health practitioners coupled with structural and governance problems" the National Coordinator of NYAA-EVD emphasized.

Lavalah admonished the government to adhere to its Operational Plan for Accelerated Response to Re-occurrence of the Ebola Epidemic in order to rebuild public trust and implement effective measures to weed out corruption and ensure revenue generated from the Ebola Trust Fund should to be utilized to reach the needy population.

The National Coordinator of NYAA-EVD who is also the Executive Director of Youth Exploring Solutions, a leading grassroots youth-led development organization, registered one of NYAA-EVD's strategic plan of actions is to develop a report under the caption "Beyond Ebola: The Role to Prosperity".

"The proposed report will proffer smart recommendations that would assist in rebuilding the health sector, boosting investment in agricultural production, exposing transparency and accountability, thereby strengthening public trust, and advancing way forward to prevent further infection and another outbreak of the Ebola virus disease" the youth leader explained.

NYAA-EVD plans to carry out additional workshops in the upcoming week in Nickley Town, Virginia City and other communities across Montserrado County as well as many locations in the country.


LOAD-DATE: September 16, 2014

246 of 500 DOCUMENTS



The Analyst


September 15, 2014


Reduction in Ebola Cases in District #16 - Cleric Discloses


BYLINE: Anthony Q. Jiffan, Jr.


LENGTH: 406 words


The Resident Bishop of the Mission of Today Church in Liberia, Bishop P. Manneseh Conto, has disclosed that the cases of Ebola in District #16 and its environs have been reduced since the establishment of the District Taskforce. 

Speaking to members of the press at his office in New Kru town, the Bishop who is also a key member on the District Anti-Ebola Taskforce revealed that the deadly Ebola viral disease (EVD) is being kicked out of the district gradually due to what he termed as "total collaboration and cooperation of the citizens" with the task force and the continuous awareness and sensitization campaigns launched by the friends of Bishop Conto (FOBC) and the youth of the borough.

According to Bishop Conto, campaign efforts by the FOBC and the borough youth have ensured that every household get the preventive messages available to the public. The Bishop said his actions and coordinated actions by actors in the district were yielding greater results that he observed has amounted to the conclusion that the cases of infection in the district were reduced.

He indicated that to see the Ebola virus out the district, he and others have made donations of anti-Ebola material, including donation of a vehicle by him to aid in the transportation of patients to various treatment centers in and around the district.

He called for the establishment of call centers around the country to ensure easy access to the response mechanism to cases of Ebola in the country, saying such call centers should be established in every district to ensure that victims are quickly taken away from their homes so that other family members will not encounter the virus.

Ebola, it is said is transmitted through person-to-person contact, especially through contact with the body fluid of infected sick person. However, hygienic measures have been suggested by health authorities in the country which include the constant washing of hands with chlorinated water and soap, the staying away from crowded areas and the avoidance of handshaking amongst others.

Speaking to this, Bishop Conto beseeched residents to abide by all of the preventive measures announced so as to ensure containment of the Ebola viral disease. The Man of God called on the government to ensure that the life of every health worker in the country is secured so that the front liners in the Ebola fight will be encouraged in mass to work against the prevalence of the deadly virus.

The Analyst


September 15, 2014


Wesleyan Church Builds Ebola Education Center in 72nd


BYLINE: Anthony Q. Jiffan, Jr.


LENGTH: 384 words


The Wesleyan Church of Liberia has established an Ebola education and resource center in the 72nd Community in Paynesville, Montserrado County. Speaking Friday at the dedication of the center, Rev. P. FahnKollie, Sr., disclosed that the Center is to ensure that residents of the community are sensitized and prevented from the deadly virus in the country. 

The senior Pastor of the Wesleyan Church further disclosed that the center was built to increase access to Ebola education, reduce the rate of ignorance and denial among people about the existence of the virus and basic resources for vulnerable people in Paynesville.

Meanwhile, the Wesleyan Church has made available two water tanks each having the storage capacity of 500 gallons of well chlorinated mixed water with other solutions good enough to fight against the survival of the virus.

The PastorKollie revealed that they are doing everything possible to secure their community from the deadly virus. According to him, the government needs to tackle every corner in the country that is affected with the disease to ensure that the virus is eradicated from the country.

The clergyman said the church's initial contribution to the fight against the Ebola virus was the donation of buckets and other preventive materials to the Wesleyan churches in Liberia, making them to know about the existence of Ebola in the country. Pastor Kollie also disclosed that many Liberians are abiding by the necessary preventive measures against the deadly disease to save them from contracting the virus.

He urged the government to respond to emergency calls and pick up the sick patients and dead bodies in order to save other people from contracting the virus from relatives, friends and family members. "The government needs to use the funeral workers to respond to death cases and burial purposes instead of training new people who are not knowledgeable of how to deal with dead persons," the Pastorsuggested.

Meanwhile, KpetermeniMeinu, a survival of the deadly Ebola viral disease testified the reality and existence of the virus in the country. He said Liberians should stop denying the fact that Ebola is real and is in Liberia; instead he advised residents to follow all of the preventive measures against the virus to curtail its further spread in the country.

248 of 500 DOCUMENTS



The Analyst


September 15, 2014


Man, 62 Buried 21 Suspected Ebola Victims Without PPE


BYLINE: Philip T. Singbah


LENGTH: 640 words


A 62-year-old traditional oldman,SingbehDuwah, has told Journalists that he has buried twenty-one suspected Ebola bodies in the village of Balakerthela one of the quarantined communities in Bong County. The oldman told a team of reporters visiting Balakerthela recently that he embarked on the burial of the suspected Ebola bodies without the recommended personal protective equipment (PPEs) being used by health workers to conduct the disposed of Ebola suspected bodies.

Balakerthela is located in Konoyea Clan in Salala District; and according to the Bong County Health Team, the town has recorded thirty two suspected and confirm Ebola death since the outbreak in Bong County. On the basis of the severity of the Ebola attack on the town, the County Health Team in August quarantined the town. 

Speaking to the Journalists in Balakerthela Saturday, OldmanDuwah attributed his intervention to bury suspected Ebola bodies to the failure by the Bong County Ebola Burial Team to remove Ebola bodies from the town.

The Bong County Health Team however, recently admitted to our Bong correspondent that the county has a single vehicle to pick up bodies. Our Correspondent also gathered that despite the severity of the Ebola situation in Bong, the County with a population of over three hundred thousand population has a single Ambulance.

"Sometime in a day's time, there were about three to four dead bodies in the village and the corpses will be disposed in the village for three days waiting for the burial team to come," the 62-year-old man explained, saying, the longer you keep the dead bodies, the rapid the disease spread according to health workers."

The traditional old man intoned that he mobilized two of his colleagues to carry on the burial of the suspected Ebola bodies on their own due to the obscure absence of the County's Burial Team. "If you called the Burial Team to come and take away the corpses, they will sometimes drag for two or three days and we will not sit and see the bodies to decompose to contaminate the rest of the people" old man Singbeh declared.

When quizzed what precisely he used to conduct the burial in the absence of the world standard personal protective equipment, the traditional old man narrated that he applied traditional herbs on the corpses including him and his colleagues before carrying on the interment. The herbs that I have, if I used it on the dead body, it will not smell horribly for a week, Olman Duwah disclosed.

"The townspeople only help with the digging of the grave, but we the ones descend the bodies in the grave" the 62 years old man boasted, slapping his chest with his right hand.

He informed this reporter that he has been in the business for the past thirty years, but was swift to dejectedly tell this paper that one of his helpers whose identity was not established just passed a week ago. He was not aware that his colleague died pf the deadly Ebola virus.

The street corner debate centered around the authority used by him to bury suspected Ebola body without the required PPEs with others saying the old man is immune to the virus, while others are yet saying that the oldman is working along with the spirit of the dark world.

"If the old man was not immune to the virus, while his colleague who has been helping him to carry on the burial falls prey to the virus" Joseph S. Kollie a health practitioner asked. Whatever may be the case, the analyst observed that Oldman Duwah has embarked on a risky task and should be observed by health authorities. The oldman is right to act if the proper medical and burial people are dragging their feet to collect the dead, another analyst said.

Meanwhile, our Bong County Correspondent also established that some residents of Balakerthela have left the village for refuge in other satellite villages for fear of contracting the Ebola disease.


LOAD-DATE: September 16, 2014


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2014 AllAfrica Global Media.
All Rights Reserved


249 of 500 DOCUMENTS



The Analyst


September 15, 2014


Yes Conducts Anti-Ebola Gender Awareness Training


LENGTH: 956 words


The Youth Exploring Solutions (YES), a passionate, voluntary and an accredited nonprofit, grassroots youth-led development organization has organized a one-day intensive workshop geared towards training people of all ages on the gender perspective of the Ebola virus disease.

The Anti-Ebola Gender Awareness Training is an integral part of the Youth Exploring Solutions strategic plan designed to engage, educate, and empower people at the grassroots level to tackle the widespread of Ebola virus disease in Liberia. 

As part of the training, men and women acquired knowledge on problems affecting women, propose possible remedies, and figure out realistic opportunities in the midst of the prevailing medical crisis. It brings into the limelight analysis of the various signs and symptoms, methods of diagnosis, prevention and control of the Ebola virus disease.

In addition, the training highlights the plight of women in an epidemic and inspires men to join women to overcome barriers in adopting preventive measures against the world's deadliest Ebola outbreak. It also creates an enabling environment and platform to enhance exchange ideas in order to proffer best alternatives to safeguarding women at the front line in this medical crisis.

The training which took place on Friday, September 12, was organized at the New Jerusalem Assembly of God School along the Somalia Drive in Gardnerville Township. It brought together 50 participants from different religion, social status, and community.

Speaking during the event, Ms. Laura Tragbeh who is a volunteer and soon-to-be an Associate Program Officer of YES lamented a shocking statistic from the Ministry of Health & Social Welfare, which indicates 75 percent of the death toll from the Ebola virus disease constitutes female.

"It is very disheartening, disappointing, and disgusting to see a high proportion of those who died of Ebola in Liberia are female" Ms. Tragbeh stated in a wailing voice.

Ms. Tragbeh continues: "We can no longer afford to reluctantly stand and see our mothers and sisters, aunties and nieces, including our daughters increasingly dying of Ebola without taking any further action. Now is the time for us to wake up, shake up and stand up for female in Liberia to get the acquired information on Ebola and all necessary supports needed to stay living in the midst of an epidemic that have engulfed almost the entire country."

The young leader urged women and men to work together in finding amicable solutions to addressing the increase death rate among female as a result of the Ebola outbreak. She is at the same time calling on the government, humanitarian organizations, and benevolent individuals to assist Youth Exploring Solutions initiatives through partnership or donation, so as to decentralize the organization's activities to other parts of the country.

"We exist to complement government's efforts and not to perpetual criticize or sing everlasting praise. Moreover, we believe nongovernmental institutions are our partners and not competitors. Hence, we are willing, ready and prepared to work together in making our community, nation and world a better place" Ms. Tragbeh noted.

Ms. Pauline W. Nagbe, Gender Coordinator of YES, pointed out that women are caring, sharing and loving and all too often they are in the front line taking care of family needs and providing services that require direct contact with the public, which in most cases make them vulnerable.

The Gender Coordinator indicated that economic constraint among women and their involvement in cross border trade, internally commuting between markets, and regularly clustering at various market places served as a conduit to explore women to become at high risk of contracting the Ebola virus disease.

"Many women are responsible for the survival of most households in Liberia, they are responsible for school fees, medical bills, daily meals, children's clothing and house rents among other basic needs, consequently several market women are too busy in search of scarce resources and every so often many do not even have time to be informed and educated about the Ebola virus disease." Ms. Nagbe added.

For his part, Mr. Prince T. Nyumah, a volunteer of YES who presented on the topic: 'Community Engagement Technique & Data Collection' admonished the participants to adhere to all preventive measures approved by the government of Liberia including the World Health Organization and the U.S. based Center for Disease Control and Prevention.

Meanwhile, Mr. Nyumah has urged participants of the workshop to practice lessons acquired and spread knowledge obtained to their families, friends, households and communities so as to inform, involve and inspire more people to work hard in kicking Ebola out of Liberia.

The founder & executive director of YES, Stephen B. Lavalah spoke on 'Understanding the Ebola Virus Disease'. He explained the origin of the Ebola virus disease, ways in which it can be contracted, signs and symptoms, diagnosis, including control and prevention measures.

Lavalah who is a Liberian trained public health practitioner explicated that the Ebola virus disease is primarily contracted through bodily fluid like secretion, saliva, semen, and blood. The founder & executive director clarified in simple terms the meaning of isolation, quarantine, suspected, probable, and confirmed in the context of the Ebola virus disease.

The youth leader is urging the government and its international partners to harness local professionals in the fight against Ebola. He is cautioning the government to support youth-led development organizations and utilize community-based approach in ensuring public education and training opportunities for many Liberians who want to volunteer.

250 of 500 DOCUMENTS



The Analyst


September 15, 2014


Pres. Johnson-Sirleaf Writes Pres. Obama


LENGTH: 902 words


Liberia's health emergency has really hit hopeless proportion; at least that is exactly what the tune of President Sirleaf's letter to the President of the United States of America, Barack Obama conveys. "I am being honest with you when I say that at this rate, we will never break the transmission chain and the virus will overwhelm us," said Iron Lady and head of state Ellen Johnson Sirleaf to head of state Barack Obama.

Though it is not clear what Obama's response would be, having already reportedly promised a team of US military personnel to Liberia to construct a containment center and having committed a hundred million dollars to the fight against Ebola, the Liberian head of state sounds doleful in the communication to Mr. Obama. The Analyst reports. 

There is no debate now over who is winning the fight--Government and the deadly Ebola virus. It has come from the horse's own mouth, from Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, Commander in Chief and head of state of Liberia.

"Our already limited resources have been stretched to breaking point and up to now only a private charity, Medecins Sans Frontiers (MSF), has responded robustly in all the affected countries. But they too have reached their limits. Without more direct help from your government, we will lose this battle against Ebola. A WHO investigation conducted with other partners and our own Ministry of Health and Social Welfare projects thousands of cases over the next three weeks."

Those are the words of President Sirleaf in a September 11 letter to President Barack Obama of the United States.

First expressing Liberia's gratitude to the US president for the support he has provided the Mano River Union in the battle against the Ebola Virus Disease, President Sirleaf said to Mr. Obama:

"The virus is spreading at an exponential rate and we have a limited time window to arrest it. Mr. President, well over 40% of total cases occurred in the last 18 days. Our message has gotten out and our citizens are self-reporting or bringing in their relatives. But our treatment centers are overwhelmed. MSF is now running a 160 bed-unit that will expand even further."

"I am being honest with you when I say that at this rate, we will never break the transmission chain and the virus will overwhelm us," she admits definitely. "With blanket travel bans, border closures and interdictions on vessels berthing at our ports, this has become more than a humanitarian emergency in a country that has barely emerged from a 30-year period of civil and political unrest, with the presence of a large youthful (mainly unemployed) population, some of whom were child soldiers - this health emergency threatens civil order."

She added: "We need to provide up to 1500 beds in Ebola Treatment Units in Monrovia. We also need to create 10 additional sites in the outlying affected counties. This is beyond anything we are able to address on our own. Unless we significantly increase our capacity to isolate infected persons - their families and communities remain vulnerable and the transmission chain remains unbroken. With our own resources, we can only support and manage one (1) one-hundred bed treatment facility. Medecins Sans Frontiers will scale up to 400 beds, leaving a very significant gap."

The United States has been a steadfast friend and a partner, the President told President Obama about the US' roles in Liberia's history. "As impressive as our gains have been, they remain fragile and this outbreak now threatens to undermine those gains and reverse our progress."

Regarding specific assistance Madam Sirleaf craves for are the following which she unveiled to Mr. Obama: That the US government sets up and operates at least one Ebola Treatment Unit (ETU) in Monrovia. Mr. President at the current rate of infections, only governments like yours have the resources and assets to deploy at the pace required to arrest the spread.

Branches of your military and civilian institutions already have the expertise in dealing with biohazards, infectious diseases and chemical agents. They already understand appropriate infection control protocols and we saw these assets were deployed in Aceh after the tsunami and in Haiti after the earthquake. It is in appreciation of the difference in kind of disaster, that we requesting assistance from units with expertise in managing biohazards.

That the US government assists in restoring regular basic and secondary health services at least 10 non-Ebola hospitals. We have been told by healthcare workers on the frontline that only 80% of patients presenting symptoms at ETUs are infected with the virus. The other 20% need to be treated at non-Ebola health facilities.

However, we need appropriate infection control protocols and testing facilities to protect health care workers and non-Ebola patients in these facilities. Currently, in Monrovia there are 8 hospitals, ranging from 50 to 418 beds. Across the rest of the country we need to reopen at least one large public health facility to prevent deaths from treatable diseases and prevent maternal and infant mortality.

Maintenance of air bridges during the course of the response. With airlines servicing the country down to two from a pre-Ebola total of 11, movement of personnel with expertise and equipment into the country is becoming increasingly difficult. Until private air service returns, we will require assistance with air bridges to respond to the crisis.

251 of 500 DOCUMENTS



The Analyst


September 15, 2014


UN Under Secretary Assures Liberia Amidst Ebola Epidemic


LENGTH: 645 words


The United Nations Under-Secretary-General for Peacekeeping Operations, Mr. HervéLadsous has assured President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf that the United Nations remains on the side of Liberia in the wake of the Ebola epidemic and is prepared to support ongoing international efforts led by the World Health Organization (WHO) and others to contain the virus.

He reiterated that the Organization has taken the initiative to mobilize the entire UN system and beyond to effectively respond to the outbreak with the aim of containing the further spread of the deadly Ebola virus disease in the sub-region. 

"Currently, the United Nations Secretary General, Mr, Ban Ki-moon, has taken advantage of the ongoing United Nations General Assembly to engage different levels of world leaders and is committed to doing all he can do to stop the epidemic," adding further that the UN is also affected by the outbreak due to the presence of UN peacekeepers on mission here," Mr. Ladsous noted.

According to an Executive Mansion release, the UN Under-Secretary General made the assertion when he met with the Liberian leader at her Foreign Ministry office recently.

Mr. Ladsous conveyed the deep feelings of Mr. Ban about the current Ebola epidemic in Liberia and other countries in the sub-region. "My visit to Liberia is also to express the solidarity of the Secretary-General and to assure President Sirleaf of the UN system's commitment to help mitigate the risk placed on the hard won gains made in Liberia so far. I am here sitting with you and the Government on how we can more effectively help the situation," Mr. Ladsous said.

He reiterated that there is a general agreement that the outbreak is a threat to peace and security in the sub-region and therefore noted that the current mandate of the UN Mission in Liberia may not change because this is not the appropriate time.

For her part, President Sirleaf thanked the UN Under-Secretary-General for his visit to Liberia and recounted previous visits, including that of the UN Systems Coordinator on Ebola, David Nabarro and others to help respond to the outbreak.

The Liberian leader described the Ebola virus disease as an unknown enemy in the Liberian setting, making it critical to the response efforts. "Our collective response is yet to catch up with the acceleration rate of the virus thus far, but concrete efforts in strategic partnership with the international community and international responders are now in place to mitigate the situation," President Sirleaf pointed out.

President Sirleaf briefed Mr. Ladsous about several initial measures taken by the Government, including the closure of schools, entertainment centers, video club, etc. and noted that cultural and traditional practices also remain at the heart of efforts to break the transmission of the disease. She, however, expressed hope that the end will come soon as there are so many success stories associated with the release of more survivors from the treatment centers across the country.

"Our regular health care system was hard hit by the outbreak and needs support and attention to be able to respond to the growing number of non-Ebola cases that are also added to the death rate in the country. We are working with our partners to fully restore regular health care, and the UN's involvement is encouraged," President Sirleaf urged.

President Sirleaf pointed out that the Ebola outbreak is having serious consequences on the country's economy, and assured that the government is working with the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund and others to mitigate the situation now and the post-Ebola period.

She informed Mr. Ladsous that the security situation in the country so far remains calm. She pointed out that the desire of training more personnel in the security sector, particularly the police was on course but now restrained by the Ebola outbreak.


LOAD-DATE: September 16, 2014

The Inquirer (Monrovia)


September 15, 2014


City Mayor Honors UL Volunteers


LENGTH: 317 words


Monrovia City Mayor Clara Doe Mvogo on Friday, September 12 honored 45 University of Liberia students who volunteered to clean the city in preparation for the 167th Independence Day celebration in July. 

During the special program held in their honor at the Chevron Monrovia Central Park, Mayor Mvogo thanked the students for "demonstrating a sense of patriotism through voluntarism". She said "It is unprecedented to see university students voluntarily rendering free service to a national cause, and I urged you to continue doing so".

The Mayor noted that the Monrovia City Corporation has constructed 3 Ebola information and sanitation kiosks with the support of the President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf and the Ebola Task Force. The kiosks are located on McDonald Street, Rally Time Market and the Vai Town at the junction between the two bridges

The Mayor said an additional 4 kioks are under construction; "when completed, they will also be placed in other communities around Monrovia".

Four of the university volunteers were hired to manage the kiosks. They usually go out into the community where the kiosks are located with megaphones informing the public of the symptoms of Ebola, preventative methods and how to report suspected cases and dead bodies in their respective locations. Each kiosk has free chlorinated soap water for public use and for residents to take home.

Speaking on behalf of the honorees, representative of the student leadership of the University of Liberia thanked Mayor Mvogo for the special recognition given them, and further noted that it was a special day in their lives. He indicated that they felt invigorated by the recognition and promised to avail themselves whenever they were called upon.

The program was also attended by members of the University of Liberia Administration including Professor Dao AnsuSonii, Sr., Dr. S. Momolu Gataweh and Julius S. Nelson, amongst others.

The Inquirer (Monrovia)


September 15, 2014


Two Local NGOs Donate to Ebola Fight


LENGTH: 566 words


Two local non-governmental organizations, Compassion Fund International-Liberia Program /Security Watch for Children in Care on Friday, September 12, 2014, donated items worth over USD $ 5,000.00 to the National Task Force in addition to its initial contributions made to help in the fight against the Ebola Virus in the country. Speaking to pressmen after the presentation ceremony held at the GSA Compound on UN-Drive in Monrovia, a member of the international chapter (Compassion Fund International), Hon. Patrick TarnueWorzie, said that it is his organization's initiative to assisting the government in the fight to kick the virus out of the country. The donation made included 25 medical mattresses and 500 sacks of water. 

Hon. Worzie, who is also the local chapter Chairman (Compassion Fund Liberia) enumerated scores of previous assistance rendered to Ebola affected communities and health centers putting the total cost at over USD $ 15, 000. 00; since its operation began to this fight, noting that this amount accounts for contributions made by collaborating partners including, Compassion Fund International, as the major funder; the Security Watch for Children in Care, headed by the former Police Director, MunnahSieh, the National Social Security and Welfare Corporation(NASSCORP) .

The local chapter chairman asserted that his organization work on Ebola started in Lofa with support by NASSCORP where it is working closely with the traditional leaders in the county on their role on Ebola prevention. With the level of work been done by citizens, GOL and partners, the Chairmen believes that there is a bit of improvement especially in Lofa on case load due to the level low cases currently being reported; compare with the early period as he quoted statistics.

Speaking further, the Executive Director for Compassion Liberia, Mr. Alex Gborlee intoned that beginning Monday, September 14, 2014, his organization will begin working with those health worker identified by Ministry of Health to distribute food to various quarantined and health centers especially in Montserrado. He named the food and none food items as butter, wheat, bread, rice, milk, sugar, water, cholera, etc.

Continuing on his organization work Mr. Gborlee said, Compassion Fund Liberia is working with children that come in contact and conflict with the law and are venerable and; need assistance and also caters to venerable women and youth that need assistance. It focus areas he pointed are health, education, agriculture and protection.

Currently the Executive Director averred, his NGO is working in five counties (Nimba, Lofa, Margibi, Bomi and Rural Montserrado) and is implementing a project on legal intervention sponsored by OSIWA and, an agricultural project (Cassava production), sponsored by its headquarters based in Philadelphia, USA.

For his part, the National President of the NCA and Legal Counsel of Compassion Fund Liberia, Atty. J. Allison Barco described the gesture by Compassion Fund Liberia as a motivating role for other organizations and economic resourced persons to join the government in combating the disease.

Atty. Barco used the medium to thank the government and international partners on effort thus far but called on every meaningful Liberian and philanthropic organizations to emulate the good examples of donating and helping the Task Force to fight this national health crisis.
