254 of 500 DOCUMENTS



The Inquirer (Monrovia)


September 15, 2014


U.S. Military to Build 25-Bedroom Ebola Hospital


BYLINE: Timothy T. Seaklon


LENGTH: 648 words


It has been disclosed in Monrovia that the United States (US) Military will build a 25-bedoom hospital in the country to buttress efforts aimed at fighting the Ebola virus. United State Ambassador accredited near Monrovia, Madam Debra Malac, said discussions are ongoing as where the hospital should be built but was certain that it would be constructed in Montserrado County.

Ambassador Malac addressing the weekly Press Briefing at the Ministry of Information said the unprecedented outbreak of the Ebola Virus Disease (EVD) in West Africa is an International Security priority for the U.S. Government and as such they will continue to be engaged in the region to eradicate the disease. 

The U.S. Envoy said, "This is the worst outbreak of this virus in 40 years since it was first discovered. We defeated it and this time we will defeat it again. We will stop Ebola and it will take more work."

Outlining the U.S. Government's support since the outbreak of the EVD, Ambassador Malac said her government had spent US$100m dollars to combat the disease since March noting that such a support is in the form of kinds, materials and most in technical support from experts coming into the three most affected countries, namely Liberia, Sierra Leone and Guinea.

Madam Malac stressed that since this is the first devastating outbreak of the EVD, the United States is seriously responding by deploring the needed resources and technocrats to fight the virus.

She noted that already the United States has about 100 experts in West Africa among which are 70 Disease Control Experts, to combat the disease and has equally increased support to affected countries through international humanitarian organizations, Non-governmental Organizations(NGOs) the United Nations system and other experts.

The United States Diplomat used the occasion to dispel rumors that the United States Embassy near Monrovia has been closed to the public saying, "Our doors are open to the public and we are fully staffed but most especially overstaffed due to the number of experts coming from the U.S. government to help fight the Ebola."

Ambassador Malac recounted the numerous contributions made thus far by the United States Government to aid West Africa fight the Ebola virus among which include the provision of chlorines, buckets, body bags, Ebola Testing laboratories with one being at the ELWA Ebola Treatment unit, as well as US$100,000 assistance to the Liberia National Police (LNP) for the procurement of equipment and Personal Protective Gears to be used by officers who accompany burial teams.

She also recounted the United States efforts aimed at training health practitioners and noted that a major training process was in the making for the Armed Forces of Liberia and the LNP.

On the isolation of Ebola affected countries which include Liberia, Guinea, and Sierra Leone, by the international Community, Ambassador Malac said the United States is working with countries around the world and not to isolate these countries as isolation is not the answer to the problem.

"We do not want countries around the world to impose travel ban because we are dealing with the guidelines provide by the World Health Organization (WHO) which does not encourage isolation of these countries. However we encourage screening of travellers and not a travel ban," Ambassador Malac said.

One the out-sourcing of the Ebola fight to other countries or Non-governmental organizations (NGOs) Ambassador Malac said the fight against Ebola is a collective responsive effort that does not belong to a particular country or an NGO. Instead, she noted that it must be a unified coordinated effort.

Meanwhile, the U.S. Diplomat said the United States is awaiting the report of the investigation of the West Point incident which led to the alleged shooting of Shaki Kamara who bled to death and two others who are receiving treatment in Monrovia.


LOAD-DATE: September 15, 2014


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

All Rights Reserved

The Inquirer (Monrovia)


September 15, 2014


Grand Kru Citizens Strategies to Fight Ebola


BYLINE: Jefferson D. Tweh


LENGTH: 253 words


Residents of Grand Kru County residing in Monrovia and its environs have held a one-day meeting aimed at finding ways to support the fight against Ebola in the county. 

A Senatorial aspirant of Grand Kru County, Albert Tugbeh Chie who led the special meeting last weekend at his office in Monrovia, said collectively they should find positive solutions to fighting the Ebola virus that is claiming the lives of many people in the country.

He also proffered the conduct of massive awareness in the 12 communities in Grand Kru County to educate the people on preventive measures especially in Ebola-reported communities in Parluken, Forpoh District and said he also heard that many people have lost their lives in that part of the county.

The Sass town Chief, Joseph Weah, lauded Prof. Chie for recognizing and inviting the citizens of Grand Kru to discuss the current situation that is unfolding in the county.

Mr. Weah suggested that some residents from the 12 communities of Grand Kru County and residing in Monrovia and its environs should be trained and must be given materials to carry on the massive awareness which should also include the training of individuals who can speak the languages in the county.

Meanwhile, in an effort to fight the Ebola virus, Prof. Chie gave L$100,000 to the residents to kick off the Ebola awareness and at the same time said the Friends of Albert Tugbeh Chie (FOATC) had carried several buckets, cartons of clorax and chlorines as well as other materials to the county for Ebola awareness.

The Inquirer (Monrovia)


September 15, 2014


Save the Children Constructs Central Region 1st Ebola Treatment Unit


BYLINE: C. Winnie Saywah-Jimmy


LENGTH: 641 words


Save the Children has turned over a 50-bed Ebola Treatment facility in Suakoko, Bong County worth about US$170,000 intended to serve the central region as part of its contribution to the national fight against the spread of the virus in other parts of the country.

The construction of the ETU which is a project solely undertaken by Save the Children according to its acting Country Director, Mercy Gichuhi who turned over the unit, was as a result of a request made to them from the local health team of Bong County. 

Madam Gichihi said Save the Children believes that the construction of the health facility will go a long way in responding to the health need in that region and that Phebe Hospital focuses more on primary health care and at the same time give confidence to the health workers who will know that they have a place to refer confirmed Ebola patients.

She said Save the Children's partnership is with the government of Liberia and it is the county health team that will now have another agreement with the International Medical Corps (IMC) to manage the facility while Save the Children will always be there to support when there are gaps in terms of medical support and logistics.

Save the Children's acting County Director said the next county of support is Margibi where similar facility will be constructed noting that plans are well advanced to begin in the coming weeks and her message to Liberians is to focus more on controlling the virus and by adhering strictly to the advice of medical practitioners.

Extending her gratitude to Save the Children, Bong Superintendent, Selena Mappy,called, on her colleagues in government not to politicize the urgency of eradicating the virus from the country. She said political hats need to be put aside so that unity can be forged in fight against the virus adding that they should stop shifting blames and defeat the virus.

She also called on the international partners not to use the outbreak of the virus in Liberia to exploit the country because every intervention needs to be brought to the table and collectively the agenda can be discussed as in the case with Save the Children for the betterment of the nation and to ensure that the virus is eradicated.

Receiving the ETU, the County Health Officer of Bong County, Samson Arzoaquoi said Ebola has brought a serious situation in the country coupled with frustration from residents who suggested that Phebe Hospital be converted into a holding center.

Dr. Arzoaquoi who explained how the request to Save the Children was made said due to the prevailing situation, together with the local government, they found the site but were greeted with threats from the same residents whose protest nearly prevented the construction of the center.

He said attention was attracted from Save the Children who provided resources with no financial input from the County Health Team noting, "We congratulate you Save the Children for you have done for us what we never imagined. This is a dream which we imagined the day it would have ever come through."

He said the Ebola clearly showed that Liberia did not have the capacity to respond to any health emergency and its good side is that it attracts people and investors, resources who are now bringing them in to help and reminded the attendants that Bong County is one of the epic enters for Laser fever.

He said his appeal is that as the Ebola response is to international partners; their help would not be limited to interventions but to look at the country's capacity so that it does not appear as a brief case intervention.

The Regional Officer for Africa of the World Health Organization (WHO), Sir Daniel Kebaco said this is the largest Ebola epidemic seen ever in the world but said it can be overcome. He said with the opening of an Ebola Treatment Unit together, they can bring Ebola under control.

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

The Inquirer (Monrovia)


September 15, 2014


Ellen Dismisses 10 Ebola Absentee Officials


LENGTH: 803 words


President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf has dismissed 10 of her officials for failure to return home following her directive regarding restrictions on travel of government officials, including their return within a week for those who were out of the country without an excuse.

According to an Executive Mansion release, those dismissed include Dr. Othello Gongar, Commissioner, Governance Commission, Ms. Kona Beysolow, Commissioner, Public Procurement and Concessions Commission, Cllr. Wheatonia Dixon-Barnes, Deputy Minister for Administration and Public Safety, Ministry of Justice, Ms. Victoria Sherman-Lang, Deputy Minister for Economic Affairs, Ministry of Justice and Mr. Hilary Sirleaf-Siakor, Assistant Minister for Prisons, Ministry of Justice. 

Others are Ms. ArdiaKaikai, Assistant Minister for Afro-Asian Affairs, Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Ms. LaurettaReffell, Assistant Minister for Administration, Ministry of Public Works, Mr. James H.R. Cooper, Assistant Minister for Administration, Ministry of Post and Telecommunications, Ms. MeapehGono-Glay, Assistant Minister for Administration, Ministry of Labor; and Mr. Ebenizar Z. Gibson, Assistant Minister for Trade Union, Ministry of Labor.

President Sirleaf dismissed the ten government officials with immediate effect and also instituted several measures on officials of various agencies, commissions, and parastatals not subject to presidential travel approval for showing insensitivity to our national tragedy and disregard for authority.

Members of various Boards not subjected to direct Presidential travel approval who are to forfeit salaries, compensation, benefits and Board fees until they return home are Ms. Jackie Khoury, Member of the Board of Directors, NOCAL, Ms. Massa Roberts, Member, Monrovia City Council, Mr. James P. Cooper, Member of the Board, Liberia Telecommunications Corporation, Ms. Miata Beysolow, Chairman of the Board, National Social Security and Welfare Corporation; and Mr. James Thompson, Member of the Board, Liberia Water and Sewer Corporation

Junior officials who are also not subject to Presidential approval will also forfeit all compensation and benefits until they return home to join in the fight against the Ebola virus disease and they include Ms. Christine Norman, Mayor, Bensonville City, Montserrado County, Mrs. Ade Jones Captan, Commissioner, Congo Town, Montserrado County, Ms. Alexine Howard, Commissioner, Caldwell, Montserrado County, Ms. Annie Dillon, Commissioner Dixville, Montserrado County, Mr. Amos Forkay, Commissioner, Bolloh District, Grand Kru County, Mr. J. KaydioWreh, District Superintendent, Grand Kru County, Mr. Moses O. Z. Reeves, District Superintendent, Rivercess County; and Mr. Nathaniel During, District Commissioner, Rivercess County

Meanwhile, the senior and junior government officials, including those from various agencies, commissions, and parastatals who have claimed serious, sometime, life-threatening medical conditions, they will be examined on a case by case basis.

In another development, in accordance with an updated report received from the Liberia Anti-Corruption Commission on September 5, also posted on its website, President Sirleaf has suspended on the job for one month three eligible officials who have not declared or re-declared their income, assets, and liabilities.

They are Dr. Antoinette Weeks, Minister of Public Works, Mr. Claude Langley, Deputy Minister for Technical Services, Ministry of Public Works; and Mr. Francis Okai, District Commissioner, Margibi County.

They are to forfeit their salaries and have been directed to file their income, assets, and liabilities within one week.

The Executive Mansion release also said Part X-10.1 of the National Code of Conduct Act states: "Every Public Official and Employee of Government involved in making decisions affecting contracting, tendering or procurement, and issuance of licenses of various types shall sign performance or financial bonds and shall in addition declare his or her income, assets and liabilities prior to taking office and thereafter at the end of every three years; on promotion or progression from one level to another; upon transfer to another public office; and upon retirement or resignation."

A total of 321 government officials who are eligible under the Code of Conduct Act have declared or re-declared their income, assets and liabilities.

Additionally, those government officials suspended earlier and have declared or re-declared their assets in categories B and C, are to provide to the Ministry of State for Presidential Affairs evidence of payments into government revenue their fines and penalties as directed by the Liberian President. Failure to do so, within a week, the Ministry of Finance and Development Planning will be authorized to automatically deduct two months' salary.


LOAD-DATE: September 15, 2014


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2014 AllAfrica Global Media.
All Rights Reserved


258 of 500 DOCUMENTS



The Analyst


September 14, 2014


Ghana's President Arrives Today


LENGTH: 281 words


In respond to devastations the Ebola virus has unleashed on Liberia, Sierra Leone, Guinea and other West African countries, several African nations have closed their borders. At the onset of the Ebola advent in Liberia, Ghanaians reportedly picked up bulldozers to demolish a refugee camp where Liberians have been residing for over 20 years and chased them out. This rather unfriendly response, which pundits describe as un-African and inhumane, has triggered outrage amongst the affected countries, sparking diplomatic talks around the Continent to lift the African quarantine. Reports of the arrival into the country today of President John Dramani Mahama of Ghana to show "solidarity" appear to point to a breakthrough into the diplomatic complications or a commencement of damage control measures by some African countries. The Analyst reports. 

Ghanaian President and the ECOWAS current Chairman John Dramani Mahama will pay an official visit to Liberia today Monday, September 15, 2014.

While in Liberia, the Ghanaian Leader will make a donation of assorted food items to aid Liberia's fight against the deadly Ebola virus.

According to a Foreign Ministry release, the visit by the Ghanaian leader will also be a show of solidarity by the people of Ghana to Liberia as the country goes through this difficult period.

The release said President Mahama will also meet President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf for a brief bilateral discussion.

The military aircraft carrying the food items arrived in Liberia on Saturday at the Roberts International airport.

The Ghanaian Leader is expected to also pay similar visits to neighboring Sierra Leone and Guinea which are also hard hit by the Ebola virus.

259 of 500 DOCUMENTS



The Analyst


September 14, 2014


Mounting Calls for Pres. Sirleaf to Attend


LENGTH: 1579 words


Embattled by the raging siege and devastation visited upon the people of Liberia by the vicious Ebola virus, the Liberian political administration is berserk, finding rescuers and remedies. But there comes the somewhat good news that the world community is meeting this soon and, no doubt, the issue of Ebola, now declared an international health emergency, may feature prominently for discussion. President Sirleaf is reportedly sending a government delegation to put Liberia's case before the United Nations General Assembly, which means she is not inclined to make the trip in person, desirous to stay on the ground with the beleaguered people. Some say the President's decision is patriotic and motherly but others think it is little too ill-advised. The Analyst explores the debate of whether or not the President must attend the 69th UN General Assembly herself.

Despite pockets of criticisms here and there regarding its achievements and modus operandi, the United Nations is widely considered the hope of humanity particularly in terms of remedying the intractable problems of conflict, poverty, illiteracy and disease.

As this principle organ of the UN meets at its 69th assembly of member states, and despite the fact the world body is preoccupied with its post-MDGs agenda which 2015 deadly is next door, there would be the necessary distractions of discussing Ebola in West Africa which is already declared an international health emergency. 

Countries mired by the Ebola virus have since packed their luggage bound for New York where the 69th Assembly of the UN will be taking place. They are possibly armed with all eloquence and exhibits at their disposal in order to prick and attract the attention of the philanthropic groups, countries and peoples to help them fight the deadly Ebola disease being hopelessly fought in their countries.

According to the World Health Organization (WHO) report as at September 7, 2014, the total number of probable, confirmed and suspected cases in the current outbreak of Ebola virus disease (EVD) in West Africa was 4366, with 2218 deaths. Countries affected are Guinea, Liberia, Nigeria, Senegal and Sierra Leone.

But the WHO report has conveyed the gloomiest news from Liberia, which in the past week alone has seen almost 400 confirmed and probable cases reported which almost doubles the number of newly reported cases in the preceding week. Liberia has over half of all fatalities reported in the affected countries. Liberia stands over 2000 cumulative fatalities.

The dire situation Liberia faces, which experts contend is yet to reach its peak, warrants intense foreign shuttles, according to some pundits, to mobilize assistance as it is indicated that the virus' ferocity has outpaced the capacity of the country--of the Government.

But it is reported that President Sirleaf is not likely making any trip out the country soon, including attending the pending United Nations General Assembly where world powers and philanthropists will be sitting to hear cases from across the globe.

Reportedly, the President has set up a 20-men delegation to make the trip on her behalf, poised to remain on the ground with the Ebola-stricken population.

Those who support the President's decision say it is patriotic and motherly that she remains on the ground to assure inspiration and confidence in the population which is drowned in trepidations, fear and hopelessness.

"The United Nations assemblies are nothing but talking shops," said Maryann K. Flahn, who identified herself a women rights advocate. "This is not time to talk; it is time for action. Let the Old ma stay here to boost the fight against Ebola. After all the country is represented."

Jerry Kollie, Jr., Vice President of a community credit club, Wlee-mon-deh, agrees: "What does President Sirleaf have to do at the UN at this time. Is the General Assembly a place to share foreign aid? It is not. Everyone in the world has got the story about Ebola and this doesn't need the President to press for assistance."

According to one pundit, President Sirleaf's reluctance to attend the 69th UN General Assembly is a show of consistency, as she announced that all officials of her administration must remain in the country to help fight Ebola.

"The president cannot say one thing and do another," said the pundit who asked not to be named in print. "She is taking actions against those who violated her edict, and it would be inconsistent with the intent and spirit of her edict if she left the country for whatever reason, including attending the General Assembly."

Others have sharply disagreed, arguing that leaving the country to lobby for urgently needed support and assistance to repel a deadly virus makes more sense than staying on ground for the sake of it.

"What does staying on the ground or staying away from the pending UN General Assembly bring to the table in the fight against the deadly Ebola virus," quipped Robert K. Jebboe, a community watch team leader on the Somalia Drive. "Does it equip health workers in the frontline with the kind of materials, equipment and remunerations needed to fight this fast-spreading disease?"

Jebboe contends that if the president's presence at the Assembly was not necessary, she shouldn't have named up to 20 delegates to attend which is an apparent move to impress the organizers that Liberia is not taking the meeting lightly.

The most effective remedy to Ebola is a global response, said Jebboe further, adding: "And we have the global community--all the good will people--meeting in New York in days. Is it not time, in fact the most pressing time, for the President to make her presence felt?"

"Our President is on record for attending the General Assembly of the United Nations many times--in times when our country had been in relative peace; when it had not been so plagued by an invisible enemy taking hundreds of lives on the daily basis and with the potential of taking more lives and wrecking all the gains made after the civil conflict."

Also commenting on the issue was a local clergyman Emmet O. Hoff who posited that if the argument is made that soliciting international aid to fight Ebola does not necessarily have to be made by President Sirleaf, then it is unfortunate because it downplays and depreciates the President's prided image as a gifted international player and miracle-maker.

"All we know, or at least are told to believe, is that President Sirleaf is the only Liberian for now that is international popular and walks through the global world in pride and dignity and is able to act quickly Liberian issue," Rev. Hoff noted. "If that is true, and I have no qualm about it, then it is time for the President to show that juice of hers."

He posits further: "Firstly, if it is not important for the President to attend in person, and or if it does not matter who woos international support to fight Ebola, then why did the President telephone President Barack Obama to request assistance?

"Why was she the one at the early days of her administration living practically in the air shuttling from country to country drumming recovery and development support from international community? Or is it to say that the impact of Ebola--the death of over two thousand citizens in the hand of the virus and with estimates that thousands of more Liberians could die--is lesser and insignificant to reasons why she was attending every international meeting abroad?"

As the Commander in Chief of Liberia, and more so as someone who is good or gifted at making the global community listen to Liberian issues, Rev. Hoff said, "it is very necessary for President Sirleaf to leave home and attend the General Assembly meeting; she will definitely attract ample commitment from friends to quickly come and send the badly needed assistance to fight and promptly defeat Ebola."

The General Assembly exercises deliberative, supervisory, financial, and elective functions relating to any matter within the scope of the UN Charter. Its primary role, however, is to discuss issues and make recommendations, though it has no power to enforce its resolutions or compel state action. Other functions include admitting new members; selecting members of the Economic and Social Council, the nonpermanent members of the Security Council, and the Trusteeship Council; supervising the activities of the other UN organs, from which the General Assembly receives reports; and participating in the election of judges to the International Court of Justice and the selection of the secretary-general. Decisions usually are reached by a simple majority vote. On important questions, however--such as the admission of new members, budgetary matters, and peace and security issues--a two-thirds majority is required.

The General Assembly convenes annually and in special sessions, electing a new president each year from among five regional groups of states. At the beginning of each regular session, the General Assembly also holds a general debate, in which all members participate and may raise any issue of international concern. Most work, however, is delegated to six main committees, known as (1) Disarmament and International Security, (2) Economic and Financial, (3) Social, Humanitarian, and Cultural, (4) Special Political and Decolonization, (5) Administrative and Budgetary, and (6) Legal. (Committees are generally referred to by their number; thus, the Disarmament and International Security Committee is known as the First Committee.)


LOAD-DATE: September 15, 2014


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

260 of 500 DOCUMENTS



The Analyst


September 14, 2014


U.S. Expands Anti-Ebola Aid


LENGTH: 628 words


If the Ebola virus refuses to be contained and continues to claim the lives of many more Liberians, it would not be because the international community has failed to help Liberia overcome it. This is particularly true for Liberia's traditional friends, chiefly the United States of America which, for its part, reportedly made an intervention as early as March this year when the deadly Ebola was first announced creeping on the population from neighboring Guinea. Again, the US has expanded its assistance in wake of predictions that the fight against the deadly virus would be long and costly. The Analyst reports.

The United States says it is committing more than $100 million to combat Ebola Virus Disease (EVD) in West Africa since the outbreak was first reported in March 2014, and has expanded its efforts and increased personnel in response to the growing severity of the health emergency. 

In a statement delivered by the US Ambassador to Liberia last Thursday at a public forum, the United States announced it has already deployed than 100 specialists working in Ebola-affected countries, including a 26-member Disaster Assistance Response Team (DART) in Liberia, Sierra Leone and Guinea, and more than 70 disease-control experts from the Atlanta-based Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).

In April 2014, the US ambassador said, U.S. laboratory experts upgraded the testing laboratory at the Liberia Institute for Biological Research (LIBR) so that it could test for Ebola, which was not done in Liberia at the time. Since then, their work has helped to more than double LIBR's testing capacity.

"CDC, in partnership with the Global Outbreak Alert and Response Network and the U.S. National Institutes of Health, established the second Ebola-testing laboratory in Liberia. The mobile testing laboratory, placed at the ELWA campus, shortened the response time of tests for patients at the largest facility currently in Liberia," Ambassador Deborah Malac announced.

She added that, "Since August 23, the U.S. Government, through DART, has airlifted more than 16 tons of medical supplies and emergency equipment to Liberia, including 10,000 sets of personal protective equipment (PPE), 5,000 body bags, 2 water treatment units, 2 portable water tanks, capable of storing 10,000liters each, 500 infrared thermometers to bolster Ebola Screening efforts, and 100 rolls of plastic sheeting for construction of Ebola Treatment Units (ETUs)

In addition to bringing in supplies from outside the region, DART has purchased basic supplies locally, including 50,000 pieces of soap, 400 mattresses, 5,200 gallons of chlorine, and 2,500 buckets, she said, noting, "USAID has provided the World health Organization with 105,000 sets of PPE for healthcare staff and outbreak investigators in Ebola-affected countries."

Other assistance from the US, she said, include, a charter flight, funded by the U.S. Government and UNICEF that brought more than 40 tons of chlorine and 400-thousand pairs of medical gloves into Monrovia; supporting the UN Humanitarian Air Service (UNHAS), which is operating flights in and out of Liberia, Sierra Leone, and Guinea, the United States by providing $10 million to support the African Union deployment of 100 health workers to West Africa.

Ambassador Malac said the U.S. Government is working to expand the pipeline of medical equipment and supplies flowing into Monrovia.

In coming weeks, the DART will airlift 130,000 sets of personal protective equipment (PPE) to ensure the health care workers have the supplies they need to safely do their jobs, she said, stating further that USAID has also funded grants to conduct social mobilization campaigns, expand treatment units and to support the safe removal of the bodies of Ebola victims.


LOAD-DATE: September 15, 2014


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

261 of 500 DOCUMENTS



The Analyst


September 14, 2014


Brumskine Tours Bong, Nimba Counties


LENGTH: 1034 words


Emergency relief efforts to contain the deadly Ebola virus, as it was during the civil conflict, have largely been concentrated in Montserrado County, understandably because the casualty figures are high in this urban province of Liberia. But death tolls are also climbing in the countryside and there is evidently little nor no major concentration in terms of external assistance. Charles Walker Brumskine, the political leader of the opposition Liberty Party has discerned the disparity. Over the weekend, he was in Bong and Nimba Counties where he delivered much needed assistance. The Analyst reports.

During the weekend, and following a meeting with President Sirleaf and other opposition political parties where she rallied all Liberians to assist in the fight against Ebola, Liberty Party strongman Charles Walker Brumskine was in Bong and Nimba Counties. 

He entered Gbarnga, Bong County on Friday, September 12, 2014, along with the county's Senator Franklin Siakor, where they presented several consignments of rice to be distributed to quarantined communities in Gbarnga: Civil Compound and Millionaire Quarters. They also delivered rice to the association of disabled persons in Gbarnga.

Speaking to The Analyst in Gbarnga, Cllr. Brumskine said that he decided to visit Bong County in order to identify with the people as he has been doing in other counties.

He said his presence in Bong as well as Nimba counties, where he visited Saturday, would make a difference in the lives of some of the people.

Brumskine said if only one life was saved because that one person's trust him and the belief in the need to do things differently, his trip is worth the while.

He implored all Liberians to follow the instructions of the medical experts, adding, "We will overcome this national catastrophe."

The standard bearer emeritus of the Liberty Party emphasized that every Liberian needed to embark on a personal crusade within the limit of the capacity of their resources to complement government and the international community's efforts to rid Liberia of Ebola.

Counselor Brumskine called on Liberians to stop doubting the existence of Ebola in the country and take advantage of preventative measures recommended by the World Health Organization, (WHO) and the Ministry of Health and Social Welfare.

Speaking to a cross session of Bong County citizens Friday, September 11, 2014 in Gbarnga, Counselor Brumskine said he was in the County to identify with citizens amidst deadly Ebola virus disease outbreak in the County.

According to the Bong County Health Team, the virus has killed more sixty persons in the county including health care providers and ordinary citizens.

Counselor Brumskine said Bong County is centrally located and hosts thousands of Liberians from different parts of the country and therefore called on residents of the county to join efforts in combating the deadly Ebola virus diseases that continues to devastate the country.

He noted that his visit to the county was the beginning of series of visits he intends to do in Bong County in the coming weeks.

As part of his visit to Bong County, he provided 65 five bags of rice to the Bong County Branch of the Liberty Party for distribution to quarantined quarters in the county.

It can be recalled that the LP strongman on August 16, 2014 provided LD$100,000 to the Bong County Health Team to support the work of the Team in fighting Ebola in the County.

Then last Saturday the LP strongman was in Nimba County where he and the former Superintendent of Nimba County, Edith Gongloe Weh, presented PPE to Dr. Albert Willicor, Chief Medical Officer, United Methodist Hospital, Ganta.

Making the presentation, Cllr. Brumskine told Dr. Willicor that the fight against the Ebola virus begins with the medical professionals who are at the frontline in the national effort to contain the virus.

"That is why all of our medical practitioners and health workers need to be protected with personal protective equipment," he said.

Cllr. Brumskine and Hon. Gongloe Weh also presented a consignment of rice to be distributed to quarantined families in Nimba, along with other materials to be used in containing the Ebola virus.

Brumskine's message to the people of Bong and Nimba counties was uniform: everyone with whom you interact must be presumed Ebola infected.

He said his presence in the counties which have produced reasonably high numbers of virus-infected persons meant that no matter the situation, he cannot shy away from coming to visit his fellow countrymen and women.

"Until the Ebola virus is eradicated from our country, we will have to do away with certain cultural habits, such as handshaking, hugging, kissing, and so forth," he told citizens in Bong and Nimba Counties. "We are an intimate and caring people, but we have to now stop providing home healthcare for the sick, even if is a close relative, and have the health professionals take care of those who are ill, regardless of what we think the ailment is. Until the doctors have ruled out Ebola, it has to be hand off. No touching, not even your spouse."

In a related development, Liberty Party Bong County Senatorial Candidate Franklin Siakor has provided US$500 to Community Radio Stations in Gbarnga as part of efforts to intensify awareness and outreach activities in Bong County. The stations include Radio Gbarnga and Super Bongese Radio.

Mr. Siakor told The Analyst that the donation was to complement the efforts of the stations in reaching remote villages in the county to provide the opportunity for the voiceless to make inputs in the midst of the rapid spread of the virus.

The Liberty Party Bong County Senatorial Candidate also noted that the gesture is to also be used to improve the station's programming.

Mr. Siakor recommended that portion of the money be used be used to purchase digital recorders for the Language Programs at the two stations.

He commanded the Management of the Radio Gbarnga and Super Bongese for the role they continue to play in the fight against Ebola by creating the platform for medical practitioners, civil society actors and community people in the county to create awareness about the danger of the Ebola virus disease and preventative measures.

262 of 500 DOCUMENTS



The Analyst


September 14, 2014


Stop Abusing State of Emergency


LENGTH: 1295 words


Early fears about the declaration of a state of emergency by Government to contain a vicious pestilence were that it would be used to prey on unsuspecting individuals and groups, particularly dissenting voices that Government has got eyes on for a long time and that it would set loose marauding armed men upon the civilian population. The fears have not proven unwarranted. In less than a month of the declaration, the fears found legitimacy in the cow-boy styled knockdown of the Chronicle Newspaper and the gunning down of an adolescent youth West Point. This has alarmed, though not surprised, members of the Liberian human rights community who understand the traits and behaviors of Liberia's military and police forces and had predict the perversion of the state of emergency. Now another prominent member of the community, Kofi Woods, currently visiting the United States is warning against continued abuse of the state of emergency. The Analyst reports.

Former Public Works Minister now Legal Consultant of the Liberia Law Society is warning that the state of emergency in Liberia should not be used by government and its security forces to violate individual and collective rights of people.

Woods, one of Liberia's renowned human rights lawyers, urges Government not to use the state of emergency imposed professedly to address a health crisis to militarize the country and to restrict press freedom and freedom of speech. 

He made the remarks, according to a dispatch from the United States, while speaking to journalists. Woods used the occasion to condemn the shooting to death of Shaki Kamara, a youth in West Point, by soldiers of the Armed Forces of Liberia, as well as the closure of the National Chronicle Newspaper; terming these actions as overreaching, heavy handed and unwarranted.

He called on Government to commission an Independent Inquiry into the circumstances leading to the shooting and killing of Kamara and the bullet wounds suffered by another citizen.

Woods also called on the government to re-open the Chronicle Newspaper and halt all further intimidation of the Press, including the restriction on the freedom of the Chronicle's publisher to travel.

Atty. Woods insists that the Independent Inquiry should also examine the constitutionality of the blanketed state of emergency, the use of the security forces during this national health emergency, as well as their deportment and exercise of force. He noted that the work of the independent panel must also consider the future role of security and military personnel in non- military crisis, and the improvement of the psychology and capacity of security forces to deal with matters of civil engagements.

The human rights lawyer also strongly criticized the declaration of the state of emergency, noting that it lacks specificities as to its purpose, scope and limitations, as required by the Constitution of Liberia.

He questioned the constitutionality of the President's declaration of a state of emergency; noting that while Article 86 (a) of the Constitution grants the President the power to declare a state of emergency, Article 86 (b) clearly states that:

"A state of emergency may be declared only where there is a threat or outbreak of war or where there is civil unrest affecting the existence, security or well-being of the Republic amounting to a clear and present danger."

Woods noted that the best way to deal with the Ebola emergency while at the same time avoiding a constitutional crisis, stigmatizing the country and population and giving security forces the perception that they have the liberty to trample the rights of citizens is to use the Public Health Law, as opposed to the imposition a sweeping constitutional state of emergency with no specific objectives, targets and benchmarks. "How can we impose a national state of emergency, quarantine entire swaths of our population, restrict the movement of our own people, but at the same time criticize other countries and even airlines for imposing similar restrictions on our citizens,? Woods argued.

Woods maintained that the Ebola crisis is a national public health emergency that must be dealt with as such but noted that political decisions and considerations continue to dominate real health decisions and programs. In a health emergency we must listen to the health experts and health workers to guide our decisions and actions and revert to other legal/constitutional actions only where the public health law proves inadequate.

"Without any doubt, the Government's policies and actions appear uncoordinated, fragmented and fraught with contradictions. This has led to increased distrust in our national government and lack of national ownership of the on-going fight against the Ebola Virus", the renowned human rights activist averred.

Atty. Woods noted that some of the recent policies of government constitute what he terms as "moral sin and ethical transgression against the poor and weak in our society," emphasizing that government must return to the drawing board to review some of those policy options, in the hope of restoring confidence and re-energizing the fight against Ebola.

He has recommended the review of all policies and parallel actions to address the suffering of the poor. This includes the current restrictions on freedom of movement, health interventions, humanitarian intervention and other issues.

"As a nation and people, now is the time for us to begin to address with urgency, the moral, legal and ethical imperatives to heighten the fight against Ebola, restore the hope of our people, and assure them that this too shall come to pass, Woods, observed.

Lamenting the death of Dr. Abraham Borbor whom he referred to as a schoolmate, Atty Woods expressed his condolences to the bereaved family and maintained that the Liberian Government is under obligation to conduct a full-scale medical inquiry on the use of the experimental drug (ZMAPP) and bring to closure any doubt associated with its application.

The former Public Works Minister has made a number of recommendations to Government in the fight against Ebola.

Amongst other thing, Mr. Wood called for a review all actions and the term of reference of the National Task Force and restructure the national framework for policy, action and implementation; prioritizing the needs and demands of health workers and practitioners. Those at the forefront of this fight continue to complain of neglect thus victimizing the foot soldiers and a review and restructure and National Health Team led by the Ministry of Health. Bold decisions need to be taken in the regards.

He also urged government provide an initial financial update on all income, contributions and expenditures made to the fight against Ebola to date; develop task-sharing pathways assigning unto itself the monitoring and evaluation component of the fight while existing INGOs and their national counterparts including the Liberian Red Cross must be empowered to do the implementation; and that 85% of salaries, allowances and benefits in high brackets (Executive, Legislative and Judiciary) must be sacrificed for three months during the emergency to provide for the poor.

This is real sacrifice demonstrate that they too can sacrifice to help rescue our country, the human rights advocate said, adding: "All non-essential civil servants must be retrained and redeployed to assist with the fight against Ebola. The crisis with volunteers won't be occurring if the already paid civil servants are re-deployed and that there should be no negotiations and sale of oil blocks and concessions."

In another development and in support of the appeals made by Dr. Jerry Brown of ELWA, he has donated a laptop through CASE-Liberia and will sending some drugs to assist the treatment center.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

263 of 500 DOCUMENTS



The Analyst


September 14, 2014


Novafone Wants Health Workers Prioritized


BYLINE: Edwood Dennis


LENGTH: 623 words


The Director of Sales of the NOVAFONE GSM Corporation, Dr. Rajen George says unless health workers who are at the frontline of fighting Ebola from the country are motivated with the needed logistics and incentives, the fight against the deadly Ebola virus will not yield the desired success.

Dr. George indicated that nurses, physicians and doctors are first line of contact with the virus in the fight and should be given the needed attention. 

Against that backdrop, he pointed out that the NOVAFONE family was glad to firstly identify with the healthcare workers at the John F.

Kennedy Medical Center for their empowerment through the institution as they embark on the public service of combating the Ebola viral disease.

He made the statement Friday when the NOVAFONE Management donated assorted materials to the administration of JFK Medical Center.The donation was made in the compound of JFK Hospital in Monrovia with several senior staffs in attendance.

Items donated to the hospital include hundreds pieces of mobile phones to be used for group communication of staff members working in the Ebola response system of the JFK, several cartons of toiletries and detergent amongst others including toilet tussles, soaps, chlorides, Dettol, towels and tents to enhance the JKF Memorial Center's fight against the spread and for the containment of the Ebola virus out of Liberia,

The materials, Dr. George believed, will help nurses and doctors and other workers at the JFK get more motivated in the service of their nation and its people while fighting against the spread of the Ebola virus.

He said NOVAFONE as Liberia's best GSM provider, has always made it its responsibility to help in providing solution to situations such as containment of outbreak and spread of the Ebola virus, which the government and its partners have engaged to contain, saying that NOVAFONE will always be there to provide needed assistance to the country and its people.

Also speaking during the donation, NOVAFONE's Chief Executive Officer Bechir El-Khoury expressed appreciation with the level of efforts being applied by the management of the hospital to preventing the disease from further spreading in both its facilities and in the country.

JKF Hospital under the leadership Dr. Winnie McDonald Scott, the NOVAFONE Boss, said was very effective in the fighting against the virus thereby compelling the NOVAFONE Management assist the institution in its Ebola response efforts to save humanity.

Mr. El-Khoury said the mobile phone company is committed to identifying with the Liberians people, especially with medical institutions, beginning with the JKF Memorial Medical Center as one of the first frontline fighters against the virus in Liberia.

Receiving the consignment of assorted items, JFK's Chief Administrator, Dr. Winnie McDonald Scott, praised the management of NOVAFONE for the donation, promising that the hospital staff will use the materials wisely.

Dr. Scott said the materials will help the staffs to increase their participation in the fight against the deadly virus in Liberia, noting that the JFK has been contemplating on expanding its facilities as part of its plan of containing the virus.

The new facilities the Center is considering to construct on its compound is to serve as a first approach in detecting suspected cases of the Ebola virus, Dr. Scott hinted.

She said the facilities to be constructed will serve as a channel for preventing the spread of the virus and would help the administration to usefully work in the interest of the public and the state.

She appreciated the management of NOVAFONE and called on the company to continue its support in the general interest of Liberians and Liberia and the fight against the Ebola virus.

264 of 500 DOCUMENTS



The Analyst


September 14, 2014


Tell Us Your Mission or Leave Bong County


BYLINE: Edward B. Palmer


LENGTH: 434 words


Bong County superintendent Madam Selena P. Mappy has warned international aid partners without defined objectives of operation in the county to account for their operations in Bong or leave.

The deadly Ebola outbreak has attracted huge attention of the international community for quick intervention as it becomes a matter of global threat and concern. 

Accordingly, the World Health Organization, Medicine San Frontier, USAID, Samaritan Purse and others have been engaged in the country intervening to bring the spread of the disease under control. But Bong County Superintendent Mappy said some aid agencies have been operating in her county with some degree of insincerity.

Addressing a large audience during the dedication ceremony of the Bong County Ebola Treatment Unit erected by the Medcine San Frontiers (MSF) recently, Supt. Mappy noted that many aid partners are operating in the county without a defined goal or objective.

She asserted that aid partners are carrying out operations without reference to local authorities, adding that whatever aid that is being provided by these partners, be it financial or logistical, is not accounted for and not done in consent with the county authorities.

Although she did not name a particular aid agency in Bong that her office is not officially aware of, she is not withstanding expressed believe that aid agencies should know that it is the locals that should set priorities for areas of their operations.

"Let me be clear about this, to you our partners, you either tell us what you came here to do or leave. I am saying this because most of you come here to eat the same money you are claiming to be providing to assist the county without achieving anything," she said.

She warned further, "So you either tell us what you have or don't get involve. We don't want people operating here under false pretense," she added.

Supt. Mappy who was praised for her efforts in ensuring the erection of the treatment unit, lauded the efforts of MSF, citing the enviable and major role they continue to play in helping to eradicate the deadly Ebola virus not only in the county, but in the country at large.

She expressed confidence that with the erection of the treatment unit, the rate of Ebola cases will reduce in the county since, according to her, they have somewhere to admit, observe and treat suspected and confirmed cases.

The Superintendent called for concerted efforts in dealing with the spread of the virus, while cautioning the Bong Legislative Caucus to do away with politics and unite in the fight against Ebola as there is no time for political bickering.


LOAD-DATE: September 15, 2014


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2014 AllAfrica Global Media.
All Rights Reserved


265 of 500 DOCUMENTS



The Analyst


September 14, 2014


Sirleaf Writes Obama - 'We'll Lose Ebola Fight'


LENGTH: 900 words


Liberia's health emergency has really hit hopeless proportion; at least that is exactly what the tune of President Sirleaf's letter to the President of the United States of America, Barack Obama conveys. "I am being honest with you when I say that at this rate, we will never break the transmission chain and the virus will overwhelm us," said Iron Lady and head of state Ellen Johnson Sirleaf to head of state Barack Obama.

Though it is not clear what Obama's response would be, having already reportedly promised a team to US military personnel to Liberia to construct containment center and having committed a hundred million dollars to the fight against Ebola, the Liberian head of state sounds doleful in the communication to Mr. Obama. The Analyst reports. 

There is no debate now over who is winning the fight--Government and the deadly Ebola virus. It has come from the horse's own mouth, from Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, Commander in Chief and head of state of Liberia.

"Our already limited resources have been stretched to breaking point and up to now only a private charity, Medecins Sans Frontiers (MSF), has responded robustly in all the affected countries. But they too have reached their limits. Without more direct help from your government, we will lose this battle against Ebola. A WHO investigation conducted with other partners and our own Ministry of Health and Social Welfare projects thousands of cases over the next three weeks."

Those are words of President Sirleaf in a September 11 letter to President Barack Obama of the United States.

First expressing Liberia's gratitude to the US president for the support he has provided the Mano River Union in the battle against the Ebola Virus Disease, President Sirleaf said to Mr. Obama: "The virus is spreading at an exponential rate and we have a limited time window to arrest it. Mr. President, well over 40% of total cases occurred in the last 18 days. Our message has gotten out and our citizens are self-reporting or bringing in their relatives. But our treatment centers are overwhelmed. MSF is now running a 160 bed-unit that will expand even further."

"I am being honest with you when I say that at this rate, we will never break the transmission chain and the virus will overwhelm us," she admits definitely. "With blanket travel bans, border closures and interdictions on vessels berthing at our ports, this has become more than a humanitarian emergency in a country that has barely emerged from a 30-year period of civil and political unrest, with the presence of a large youthful (mainly unemployed) population, some of whom were child soldiers - this health emergency threatens civil order."

She added: "We need to provide up to 1500 beds in Ebola Treatment Units in Monrovia. We also need to create 10 additional sites in the outlying affected counties. This is beyond anything we are able to address on our own. Unless we significantly increase our capacity to isolate infected persons - their families and communities remain vulnerable and the transmission chain remains unbroken. With our own resources we can only support and manage one (1) one-hundred bed treatment facility. Medecins Sans Frontiers will scale up to 400 beds, leaving a very significant gap."

The United States has been a steadfast friend and a partner, the President told President Obama about the US' roles in Liberia's history.

"As impressive as our gains have been, they remain fragile and this outbreak now threatens to undermine those gains and reverse our progress."

Regarding specific assistance Madam Sirleaf craves for are the following which she unveiled to Mr. Obama:

That the US government sets up and operates at least one Ebola Treatment Unit (ETU) in Monrovia. Mr. President at the current rate of infections, only governments like yours have the resources and assets to deploy at the pace required to arrest the spread. Branches of your military and civilian institutions already have the expertise in dealing with biohazards, infectious diseases and chemical agents. They already understand appropriate infection control protocols and we saw these assets were deployed in Aceh after the tsunami and in Haiti after the earthquake. It is in appreciation of the difference in kind of disaster, that we requesting assistance from units with expertise in managing biohazards.

That the US government assists in restoring regular basic and secondary health services at least 10 non-Ebola hospitals. We have been told by healthcare workers on the frontline that only 80% of patients presenting symptoms at ETUs are infected with the virus. The other 20% need to be treated at non-Ebola health facilities. However, we need appropriate infection control protocols and testing facilities to protect health care workers and non-Ebola patients in these facilities.

Currently, in Monrovia there are 8 hospitals ranging from 50 to 418 beds. Across the rest of the country we need to reopen at least one large public health facility to prevent deaths from treatable diseases and prevent maternal and infant mortality.

Maintenance of air bridges during the course of the response. With airlines servicing the country down to two from a pre-Ebola total of 11, movement of personnel with expertise and equipment into the country is becoming increasingly difficult. Until private air service returns, we will require assistance with air bridges to respond to the crisis.


LOAD-DATE: September 15, 2014


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

All Rights Reserved


266 of 500 DOCUMENTS



The Analyst


September 14, 2014


Madam Sirleaf Needs to Show Face At UN [editorial]


LENGTH: 914 words


THERE HAS BEEN quite a hilarious debate amongst pundits of late over whether or not President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf should personally attend the 69th United Nations General Assembly upcoming in New York. While arguments on all sides of the debate sound good, we think the President making the trip in person at this time of national emergency makes more sense. And we would like to see the "Iron Lady" trashing all odds and mustering the courage to face the world at this crucial meeting of the international community.

YES, IT IS true that during most part of her presidency, the 24th Liberian head of state has long been criticized and condemned for making too many foreign trips--some say unnecessary trips--not only at the expense of taxpayers but also in disregard to a more demanding domestic agenda. Some critics have catalogued and publicized all President Sirleaf foreign trips and coming to the conclusion that she could enter in the World's Guinness Book of Record as topping all modern presidents in foreign travels. In fact, some have mocked that she was an airplane-freaked leader. Others have said she was obsessed with foreign travels that she was usurping the functions and duties of the Minister or the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. 

BUT IN COUNTERING those apprehensions, the President's supporters have said, and perhaps absolutely rightly, that a post-conflict country like Liberia, which was nearly expunged if not ostracized from the community of nations in an inter-dependent world order, deserved first and foremost nothing less than an urgent, rapid and sustained engagement with the international community. They have contended that Liberia needed first and foremost its lost place at the conference table of the global community and all the social, economic and political goodies from the friends abroad that a war-ruined nation must be nursed with to get back on its own. The President Sirleaf's supporters have also maintained, perhaps absolutely rightly, that her most proven leadership strength as the "Iron Lady" lies solidly in her international persona, repute and charm in international affairs.

IF THOSE STRONG counters from supporters and admirers of President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf are anything to go by, if those widely exalted traits of hers are truly reflective of her inner powers found expressive in "This Child Will be Great"--something we absolutely have no objection about--then there is no better time to justify supporters and prove critics wrong than now. In other words, there is no better time for President Sirleaf to summon and muster her natural gift and capacity, and to prove potent her magic wand and dexterity in international relations than now at the General Assembly of the United Nations.

WE SAY THIS because the nation and the people that President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf leads risk annihilation to the invasion of Liberia by an invisible enemy force. Already, in the space of actually two months, nearly two thousand citizens are clawed away by the Ebola virus and its accomplices: other related sicknesses and diseases, and the accompanying social and economic depravities created. And experts are predicting that the tide of fatality hasn't reached its peak: meaning that this invisible enemy, which the whole of modern humanity despite all its advancement has got no solution for, is winning the war and the population faces ultimate decimation.

AT THIS TIME, and in the face of this looming apocalypse, the world community is meeting in New York and the devastation of Ebola and what's needed to be done is certainly high on the agenda. Needless to say to President Sirleaf, a noted international civil servant, that it is at such crucial meetings that beleaguered nations and their woes take center stage and leaders of those countries walk in personally and directly to make their cases for collective international remedy. In the past and even now, the world has seen at this forum even the most despotic regimes alarming about some domestic uprisings against their leaderships and the sovereignties of nations they lead. What about this unprecedented health emergency facing Liberia that has made the entire world to marvel in disbelief and trepidations? As the world meets to hear from first hand from the most affected countries--Liberia being the worst hit--and certainly as the international community will be contemplating how to fathom decisive response measures, isn't it a better time for President Sirleaf to walk in personally and directly, take the podium to do what she's best known and respected for at home and abroad--make the world see clearly the situation at home and to do something quickly? Who else in her Government share that persona and capacity to make the world hear and act?

WE WONDER WHAT President Sirleaf would have done if this Ebola invasion were a military insurgency having the same casualties the disease has caused and is further predicted to cause. We think President Sirleaf would have long been in New York prostrating before powerful countries to solicit conceited international intervention on behalf of her Government and people. This is why we don't understand why she would not like to do likewise with Ebola which everyone says is equally deadly and in fact inescapable compared to military uprising. And we believe it is only her representation that would make the desired impact of attracting, and quickly, the kind of international response the crisis at home really deserves.


LOAD-DATE: September 15, 2014


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2014 AllAfrica Global Media.
All Rights Reserved


267 of 500 DOCUMENTS



The Analyst


September 14, 2014


Memo to the President Ref. - We Think You Must Attend [column]


LENGTH: 824 words


Your Excellency:

All indications are that you will not be attending the United Nations General Assembly this year, and that you have turned over to some Government delegation the role ascribed to you as head of state to appear before the world body to give the state of the nation. The other day, it was the Minister of Defense who addressed the Security Council of the United Nations. In the next couple of days, it would be one Liberian or the other that would take of podium to act in your stead.

We understand, and somewhat acknowledge, that you are not making the trip and would not be seen and heard at the United Nations as expected because you intend to be on the ground here with Liberians to provide leadership, inspiration and confidence as the fight against the virulent Ebola virus rages. Perhaps you think, and we somewhat acknowledge, that it is more honorable, substantive and worthy staying on the ground to back up efforts and rally fighting forces repel Ebola, to comfort victims' families and to keep a semblance of normalcy than to embark on a talking shop tour. Or perhaps you think, and may be advised, that nothing you may say or do in New York that your principle deputies cannot say or do. 

While the justification for staying on the home front to mother the fight against Ebola sounds good, we think your personal presence in New York for a few days to rally international support for the situation back home is more strategic, rewarding and critical for ultimate victory against the pandemic. We remember when you were often criticized for frequent foreign travels at the onset of your administration, your defense as amplified by supporters was that the magic wand for Liberia's recovery and development lied outside of the country since we lacked the resources and expertise, and in fact the recognition and respect of the international community, due to a protracted civil conflict. And it was said that no other member of your administration--and no other Liberian for that matter--had the charisma and acumen to charm the then highly suspicious international community and to bring home the badly need goodies. And, to some convincing degree, you proved yourself an indisputable maestro of diplomacy, well articulate and well respected. A lot of the goodies came.

So, Madam President, let us ask: When does a child destined to be great prove its worth to parents and nation? Or what is the better time a true mother proves her parenthood? When does a warrior show his trait and powers?

For us, if there was any time in your life, and in the history of Liberia, you needed to manifest your inborn powers as an Iron Lady, an international whiz, an acclaimed lobbyist and fundraiser, the time is now. While it is true that Ebola's temporary triumph over Liberia is due to the fact that it's the country's first experience and also due to pervasive denial and distrust, we believe the major reason is the lack of capacity--both human and material capacities--to respond quickly and decisively. And we also have no doubt that the worse scenario predictions could come true or be thwarted depending on how much is done to address this resource capacity problem.

And, Your Excellency, the upcoming General Assembly of the United Nations presents the perfect platform for Liberia, particularly for you as the head of state, to get over the resource capacity problem. The time has come to, as you are well known for doing, make the global community rally around Liberia in this great time of need. You know the key international partners very well than any of your lieutenants do, and the international partners do have explicit confidence and deep respect for you than they do for any of your lieutenants, and would therefore listen and feel moved to act swiftly to our emergency crisis were you to appear before them in person.

As anyone would note, Madam President, the scourge and trail of the Ebola virus is no different from an armed incursion. Like a military insurrection, Ebola kills. It maims. It makes orphans, widows and paupers. It ruins the national economy and renders the nation vulnerable to intermittent instability. So, let us ask again: If fatalities and upheaval caused by Ebola had come from an armed incursion, wouldn't you be in haste to run to the international community for rescue? Certainly, this pandemic has overwhelmed your administration. It has put to risk everything and everyone you preside over as head of state. The ultimate solution lies in a global response and you are well suited to drum up that response. Other leaders from countries similarly plagued by Ebola will be making their various cases; they will be competing for the ears and hands of the economic powers meeting at the 69th General Assembly of the United States. Liberia cannot afford to lose the grand opportunity in these critical times. We trust you can do better. You need to attend.

Thanks for listening to voice of reason.


LOAD-DATE: September 29, 2014


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2014 AllAfrica Global Media.
All Rights Reserved


268 of 500 DOCUMENTS




The Guardian (London) - Final Edition


September 12, 2014 Friday


Discoverer of Ebola seeks 'army-style' intervention


BYLINE: Lisa O'Carroll


SECTION: GUARDIAN HOME PAGES; Pg. 29


LENGTH: 634 words


The microbiologist who helped identify the Ebola virus in 1976 has urged David Cameron to support a "quasi-military intervention" to stop the epidemic that is spreading unchecked in west Africa.

Professor Peter Piot, the director of the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, said the outbreak was now so bad that a UN peacekeeping force ought to be mobilised in Sierra Leone and Liberia, with huge donations of beds, ambulances and trucks as well as an army of clinicians, doctors and nurses.

"At the moment, I'm not so optimistic. I'm pessimistic about how to control it. It's one thing to isolate patients or put a small village or town in quarantine; it's another thing when entire countries are affected," he said. "This requires a state of emergency and a kind of quasi-military intervention - and it's not my style to exaggerate." 

Piot, who has worked for the UN and the World Health Organisation, said the US and UK efforts were good, but not good enough. "It's all going far too slow; I think there's still no sense that this is an absolute emergency and catastrophe," he said.

Describing the "formidable management challenge" that lies ahead, he said the biggest question for him was what would happen if the disease spread to "megacities" in Nigeria, where there have already been seven deaths from 19 confirmed cases.

"One of the reasons for this being out of control is because of the slow response both from the national community and the international community, with the exception of Medecins sans Frontieres," he added.

Piot said the Ebola outbreak had been discussed at a meeting of the government's Cobra national emergencies committee last month, so he knew Cameron had been briefed on the problem.

He said: "I call on the government and the prime minister to intensify the country's efforts and provide assistance, and to accelerate it also."

He said Cameron should sanction the release of up to 100 NHS doctors and nurses to go to Sierra Leone and Liberia and called on the UN to put an international emergency programme into action. "There is no way that the three countries affected most can handle this on their own," he said.

In an interview with the Guardian, Piot also called on British Airways and other airlines including Air France to resume flying to the two countries, saying the closure of services this summer "has not been helpful" to the aid effort. He said security could be guaranteed if passengers were screened before boarding.

A Belgian, now based in London, he co-discovered the virus in Zaire 38 years ago but never thought he would see an outbreak of this scale. It has already affected four countries and claimed about 2,300 lives, more than the combined total of all previous outbreaks.

Piot, who is working behind the scenes to provoke a sense of urgency at government level, said the head of the UN's peacekeeping operations in Liberia had already offered to assist, but that the force needed training. The African Union has also offered to get involved on a military level, but again needs outside help from experts.

"This is an enormously complicated logistics job. Frankly, the military, together with DHL and so on, and companies who do transport and delivery, they would be extremely useful," Piot added.

He urged the UN high commissioner for refugees to get involved, together with other agencies which deal with disasters including the International Rescue Fund, chaired by David Miliband.

"This should be the last epidemic of Ebola where all we have is quarantine and isolation," Piot said. "What we need the next time are stockpiles of drugs or treatments or vaccines in countries where undoubtedly the virus will resurface."

Captions:

Peter Piot, who co-discovered Ebola in 1976, said a 'quasi-military intervention' was needed to stop the virus spreading


LOAD-DATE: September 12, 2014


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

All Rights Reserved

The Guardian (London) - Final Edition


September 12, 2014 Friday


Corrections and clarifications


BYLINE: Column editor


SECTION: GUARDIAN LEADER PAGES; Pg. 45


LENGTH: 287 words


* A graphic guide to the Scottish referendum that filled the centre spread of yesterday's print edition (11 September, pages 24 and 25) gave "campaign spending" figures of £1,383,000 for "yes" and £2,416,475 for "no". In fact those figures relate not to spending but to totals of donations of over £7,500 received by the Yes Scotland and Better Together campaigns respectively in the period 18 December 2013 to 21 August 2014, as recorded by the Electoral Commission. 

* We erred in saying the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation had announced that it would spend "$50m (£31m) - on top of $10m already committed - to support the emergency response to west Africa's Ebola outbreak" (Gates charity to spend $60m on fighting Ebola, 11 September, page 30). In fact $50m is the total sum pledged, including the $10m announced previously.

* A panel accompanying a feature on football's loan system (How loan system turned into the Wild West of football, 10 September, page 4, Sport) said that Rio Ferdinand caught Manchester United's eye while on loan at Bournemouth from West Ham. In fact Ferdinand moved from West Ham to Leeds United for £18m before subsequently joining Manchester United for £30m in July 2002.

The readers' editor's office looks at queries about accuracy and standards. Email reader@theguardian.com including article details and web link, or find us on Twitter @GdnReadersEd. You can also write to The readers' editor, Kings Place, 90 York Way, London N1 9GU; or phone +44 (0)20 3353 4736 between 10am and 1pm UK time Monday to Friday excluding public holidays. The Guardian's policy is to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Contacts for Guardian departments and staff can be found at gu.com/help/contact-us
