364 of 500 DOCUMENTS



The NEWS (Monrovia)


September 05, 2014


'Serious, Deeply Worrying'


LENGTH: 678 words


The rapidity at which the Ebola virus is spreading across the West African sub-region has attracted the attention of the global community with the United Nations echoing that the disease is "critically serious and deeply worrying".

UN Deputy Secretary-General Jan Eliasson said the fear factor plays a strong role in the crisis. He urged member states of the UN, businesses and individuals to take decisions based on scientific evidence, not on fear. 

He explained that misinformation about Ebola can only exacerbate an already dire or fragile situation in the impacted countries and beyond.

UN Deputy Secretary-General Jan Eliasson made the statement on Tuesday, September 3, 2014 at a meeting with member states on Ebola at the United Nations.

Mr. Eliasson said although only a few countries have been affected, three of them severely, other countries are increasingly concerned, rightly so, about the possibility of further spread.

He indicated that the health systems in the affected countries (Liberia, Guinea, Nigeria and Sierra Leone) are overwhelmed by the magnitude and complexity of the problems, noting that the affected nations are finding it extremely difficult to cope with the situation.

"We, the international community, must now step up our efforts and boost the capacity of the affected countries and their systems and provide all support needed," Deputy Secretary General Eliasson appealed.

He informed the world body that considering the number of infections and deaths, the outbreak is more than a health crisis and that it has already taken a disproportionate toll on economies and affected the daily life and the very fabric of families and societies.

"As far as the United Nations is concerned, this is one of the most serious health challenges we have ever faced. The reality on the ground is no different from those caused by natural calamities and conflicts of great magnitude -- and in some ways even more difficult with dire consequences in several other areas of society. At the country level, an enormous amount of work is already being done by the United Nations Missions, peacekeeping operations and United Nations country teams," the Deputy Secretary stressed.

However, he said the UN cannot do it alone, that it needs effective strategies, partnerships and capacities.

"But we cannot do it alone. We need effective strategies, partnerships, and capacities. There cannot be any weak links in this operational chain. We also need to think in unconventional terms and demonstrate speed and flexibility in defining and executing our strategies. We are faced with severe strains on our own staff working in these difficult conditions. We may need to involve Member States in this coordination task. I recall the tsunami in South-East Asia and the Haiti earthquake when we had a more active role of Member States in those operations," Mr. Eliasson pleaded.

According to him, the Secretary-General has established a United Nations System on Ebola virus disease coordination mechanism to ensure that it offer integrated support to affected countries, while helping to prevent spread to other countries.

This coordination mechanism, he added, will be guided by the leadership provided by WHO and by its Ebola Response Roadmap. Dr. David Nabarro, who has just returned from visiting the affected countries, will, as Senior United Nations Coordinator, ensures effective United Nations system-wide response.

Eliasson: "There have been strong responses by Governments, multilateral and regional organisations, United Nations agencies, non-governmental organizations and other partners. I thank them for their support but encourage them to do more and to do so rapidly. I particularly want to commend MSF for their quick and solid response. I would also like to particularly thank the Governments of those affected countries for their political will and determination to come to grips with the problem. Financial resources and a unique mix of capacities to come into those countries are needed immediately so that the spread of the disease can be contained rapidly."


LOAD-DATE: September 8, 2014


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2014 AllAfrica Global Media.
All Rights Reserved

The NEWS (Monrovia)


September 05, 2014


Companies, MSF Undertake Massive Fight Against Ebola


LENGTH: 439 words


The fight against the eradication of the deadly Ebola virus in the country continues to gain massive support from construction companies, agencies, international partners as well as non-governmental organizations (NGOs) since its outbreak early this year in Lofa County, northern Liberia. 

The disease, since its outbreak, has claimed the lives of several hundreds of Liberians leaving sorrow in their homes. Family members, whose love ones have been taken away by the infection, continue to mourn in memory of them as efforts are being made at all fronts to eradicate the disease in the country.

Some of the companies and organizations involved with the fight against the eradication of the deadly infection in the country are SSF Entrepreneur Incorporated and MSF, an aid and medical organization. These two organizations are collaborating to build the ELWA quarantine center outside Monrovia which is designated by the government to place suspected Ebola patients under observation for the period of 21 days.

SSF management told newsmen early this week that it is not involved with the establishment of the ELWA quarantine center for political reason or recognition, but it said it is involved with such work owing to the fact that Liberia is being faced with a pandemic, making investment and development activities to come to abnormal stage.

This, the company said, was worrisome and troubling adding, there is a need for every Liberian, institution, company and agency to join the fight against eradication of the infection.

"We are doing this work because it is necessary for us to do such given the situation we are nationally faced with. This is our own way of helping the government and our people," Joseph Fallah, an engineer from SSF, said.

The company's management further stated that being a Liberian business and while it carries out its operations in the country, it is traditionally binding on it to swiftly respond to the outbreak of any natural disaster threatening the lives of the people. "Such forms part of our corporate social responsibility," management added.

A medical officer from MSF, who preferred anonymity, said his organization is in Liberia to help with the fight against the eradication of Ebola. He told newsmen that MSF is mainly concerned about saving the lives of Liberians, saying that in this direction it would do all that is possible to make the country free from the spread of the infection and that its people gain confidence in public health, while they return to normal way of life in a reasonable period of time.

He revealed that strategies are being primed to adequately respond to the epidemic.

The NEWS (Monrovia)


September 05, 2014


PWC - Liberia Donates Anti-Ebola Materials


LENGTH: 425 words


The PricewaterhouseCoopers, (PWC) Liberia, an international auditing firm with a branch in Liberia has made a cash contribution of one thousand United States dollars to the Town Center Community located in the Township of New Georgia. 

The donation, which was made on Friday, August 29, 2014 when community and the collection of youth organizations under the banner Association of Youth Organization launched anti-Ebola awareness, is in support of efforts being exerted by the National Taskforce, businesses, private and public financial institutions, international and local non-governmental organizations to contain the Ebola Viral Disease (EVD) that is ravaging Liberia.

Making the contribution on behalf of PWC, Mr. Tweh Tommy said it was the company's way of helping the community during this period of national emergency where everyone is endeavoring to stand up to the fatal Ebola virus.

The PWC official thanked the Council of Elders and the Youth Association of the community for the farsightedness in undertaking such anti-Ebola initiative, adding "the battle against Ebola can only be won collectively."

He also called on others to emulate the example of his institution by making financial and material contributions to the National Taskforce or communities that are aiding the efforts of government.

In response to PWC-Liberia's gesture, Rev. James Togba who spoke on behalf of the community thanked the entity for coming to the aid of the community dwellers as they buttress the efforts of the government through the National Taskforce to beat back Ebola.

Although they do not have any confirmed or suspected Ebola cases in their areas, Rev. Togba said it was necessary to take preventive measures, and added that "the success of the anti-Ebola campaign was based on the contribution made by the PWC and individuals in the community."

"We are overwhelmed and very appreciative that PWC, regardless of the short notice, was able to reach us, enabling us to take the messages and preventive measures to our people," Rev. Togba said. "The amount will be used for the intended purpose."

He, however, called on the Government of Liberia, the business communities, local and international partners to take the Ebola fight to community level, and noted that proactive actions at the community levels will ensure success against the deadly disease.

Up to 3,069 persons have been infected with the virus with 1,552 deaths in Guinea, Sierra Leone, Liberia, and Nigeria as of August 26, 2014, the World Health Organization says in its latest report on the virus.

The NEWS (Monrovia)


September 05, 2014


Political Parties Want Ellen to Outsource Ebola Fight


LENGTH: 263 words


Eight out of Liberia's 15 registered political parties have called on President Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf to outsource the functions of the National Ebola Task Force to private institutions that are knowledgeable and experienced in disease control and prevention. 

The parties believe that if this is done, it would ensure effectiveness. In a joint communiqué, the political parties said there are indications that challenges to eradicate the Ebola virus disease from the country have outweighed the National Task Force headed by President Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf. The eight political parties said instead of the President heading the Task Force, the government should be receiving report from these private institutions.

The parties include Union of Liberian Democrat (ULD), Alliance for Peace and Democracy (APD), National Patriotic Party (NPP), Grassroots Democratic Party of Liberia (GDPL), Movement for Progressive Change (MPC), Victory Change (VCP), Liberia Transformation Party (LTP) and People's Unification Party (PUP). With regards to the state of emergency and curfew, the eight collaborating political parties resolved that it remains in enforced, but called for an adjustment in the curfew time from 11 pm - 6 am.

The parties also agreed with government's stance on restricting people's movement, describing it as a workable tool in containing the spread of the virus.

In the wake of the state of emergency and curfew, the parties want the government to provide increased technical and logistical support to the Liberia National Police to beef up their presence in the communities.


LOAD-DATE: September 8, 2014


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2014 AllAfrica Global Media.
All Rights Reserved


368 of 500 DOCUMENTS



The Analyst


September 04, 2014


Police Promises Care of Dolo Town Residents


LENGTH: 697 words


Amidst the scare of Ebola and the subsequent quarantining of the Dolo Town Community, the Police Community outreach team on Tuesday, September 2 visited Dolo Town near Harbel to provide reassurance to the people that all efforts will be made by the government to cater to their needs.

It's the second in a series of outreach programs being executed by Police authorities after a successful launch in West Point two weeks ago to spread the message of hope and to provide tips to residents on how to prevent contracting the deadly Ebola Virus. The Police convoy was greeted by jubilant residents who lined the routes to the Market center to welcome the Inspector General and delegation as well as listen to the message. 

At a brief ceremony, Police Inspector-General, C. Clarence Massaquoi, who led an array of senior officers, and accompanied by the Head of the United Nations Mission Police in Liberia (UNPOL) Commissioner Gregory Hinds said the government was concerned about their plight and would do anything to provide the much needed humanitarian assistance while they are being quarantined.

Inspector General Massaquoi said the Police was delighted to visit the area as part of its community outreach programme to engage in public awareness on the prevention and spread of the deadly Ebola Virus that has caused the community to be quarantined by the Liberian Government.

"Our presence is to show that we love you and will not abandon you", Police Inspector General Massaquoi told the enthusiastic crowd as he distributed Ebola and Crime Prevention materials to the community of Dolo Town.

The Police Boss used the occasion to remind that they have a responsibility to ensure that the community is free of the deadly virus by listening to advice of Health Workers and engaging in activities that would curtail the further spread of the disease.

"The government and its International Partners are doing all in their power to fight this deadly Ebola Virus, but it is also incumbent upon you, the residents of Dolo's Town to also make sure that you cooperate in the fight". We all have to fight to kick Ebola out of Liberia" drawing the crowd to chant in support. He said the Police will remain engaged with the various communities in the fight against the virus.

The Police presented thermometers, safety gloves, and dozens of T-shirts with inscriptions of Ebola messages, symptoms and preventative measures. In Special remark, the UNPOL Commissioner of Police spoke the UMNIL commitment to assist the Liberian Government in the fight against Ebola.

He said the UN Police is working collaboratively with their Liberian National Police in ensuring that the mandate of the Police was implemented without hindrance. UNPOL recently donated six Nissan 4x4 Jeeps to the LNP for deployment in communities severely affected by the Ebola scourge.

Earlier, Margibi County Statutory District # 2 Superintendent Henric Marcus Speare welcomed The Police Hierarchy to the township and expressed gratitude that the Inspector General Massaquoi and his team of Senior Officers had come to the town to identify with the people.

Also in a show of support for the Inspector Massaquoi and the Police efforts, a local charity, Crowd '50 donated an assortment of food items valued at over two thousand United States Dollars to the Dolo's Town residents. The items included 50 bags of 25kg of rice, 20 three-gallon of vegetable oil, four bags of 50kg of sugar, two bags of flour and 150 sacks of mineral water.

The President of Crowd '50, Samuel Wonwi Thompson said his organization support to the residents was a way of identifying with their plight and to boost Police efforts to provide humanitarian assistance in addition to their official mandate of protecting life and property.

Crowd '50 was founded in the 1980's by Liberian men born in the 1950's from various professional backgrounds to cater the needs to Liberians nationwide. Responding, various speakers representing the religious, youth and other groups hailed the Police for the gesture and their continuing protection. They described the Police as a friend of the community who was also ready and willing to render assistance to them when called upon.


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 2014


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

369 of 500 DOCUMENTS



The Analyst


September 04, 2014


Liberian-Based Pan African Initiative Launched


LENGTH: 467 words


A Liberian-based Pan-African Initiative to stop Ebola was launched this week by Dr. Togba-Nah Tipoteh. The initiative is called Servants of Africa Fighting Ebola (SAFE). The principal objective of SAFE is to make Africa safe from Ebola. 

The work of SAFE gives highest priority to Liberia because, according to Dr. Tipoteh, Liberia is globally considered as being the Country that is now experiencing the most dangerous Ebola attack.

In his Launching Statement, Dr. Tipoteh said that the present phase of the Ebola attack started in Guinea in March of this year and Ebola has spread to Liberia, Sierra Leone, Nigeria, Senegal and the Democratic Republic of the Congo within Africa.

The Ebola spread has attacked countries outside of Africa, as in Saudi Arabia and Sweden with threat to spread to more countries. Dr. Tipoteh pointed out that this Ebola spread has to be stopped immediately, as it has now become a threat to national and international security.

Dr. Tipoteh indicated that the Organizers/Advisory Board Members come from various parts of Africa with over forty years of experiences in the planning and implementation of People-to-People activities throughout Africa.

He observed that these experiences are most important because SAFE is a People's Organization, to be working to stop Ebola by using the people-to-people approach where the people take ownership of the activities of SAFE in making non-physical contacts through the village and town criers, the mass media and the social media of the internet.

Dr. Tipoteh, in his Launching Statement, stressed that the guarantee for the campaign to stop Ebola is the participation of the people in decision-making and their attendant ownership of the anti-Ebola activities.

SAFE is based in Liberia with the following persons, mentioned by Dr. Tipoteh, as being the Headquarters Organizers/Advisory Board Members: Dr. Mary Nema Brownell, Founding Chairperson the Liberia n Women Initiative and Founding Member of the Mano River Women Peace Network; Rev. Dr. Arthur Flomo Kulah, Bishop (retired) of the United Methodist Church, who served as Bishop in Liberia.

Nigeria and Sierra Leone; Sheikh Kafumba Konneh, President of the Inter-Religious Council of Liberia and Chairman of the National Muslim Council of Liberia; Mrs. Frances Greaves, National Chairperson of the National Civil Society Council of Liberia; and Prof. Dr. Togba-Nah Tipoteh, Founding Leader of the Movement for Justice in Africa (MOJA) and Founding Chairperson of the Erstwhile Interest Groups of Liberia.

In closing the Statement, Dr. Tipoteh expressed condolences to the families of all of the people who have died from Ebola and called upon all Africans and Friends of Africa to work together to stop Ebola so that the deaths of the victims of Ebola would not have been in vain.

The Analyst


September 04, 2014


Grand Kru Caucus Donates Food to West Point


BYLINE: Edward B. Palmer


LENGTH: 504 words


The Grand Kru County Legislative Caucus over the weekend made a donation of several assorted food items to inhabitants of the West Point Community. The food items included 50 (25kg) bags of rice, 40 gallons of vegetable oil, two bags of flour, 100 sacs of mineral water, a cartoon of sardines among other assorted items were donated by the caucus' Chairperson, Senator Cletus C. Wotorson on behalf of the lawmakers. 

According to Senator Wotorson, the donation of the items to the people of West Point is the caucus' way of buttressing the government's efforts at fighting the deadly Ebola virus out of the country. Senator Wotorson asserted that the outbreak of the Ebola virus, which led to the subsequent quarantining of the community, is a strange happening that people do not understand.

The Grand Kru County Senator recalled that the outbreak of the Ebola virus since early March this year has caused the deaths of several doctors and nurses and expressed fears that this had caused the profession to be abandoned. For this reason, the Grand Kru lawmaker and his colleagues have mustered the courage to make its own contribution to the people of West Point as a sign of identifying with the community during its time of quarantine.

He cautioned Liberians to adhere to measures put in place by health workers in order to eradicate the existence of the virus in as much as the outbreak of Ebola is a strange phenomenon in the country. As he regretted the quarantining of the West Point Community, urging community dwellers everywhere in the country to be patient and allow to this period of Liberia's trying time to expire so that life can return to normal.

Making further comment on the donation was the caucus' Vice Chair, Sen. Peter Coleman, who expressed happiness over identifying with his people. Sen. Coleman said their visit in the community was overdue, but added that there could have been no better time to do it than the time of their visit. He explained that the outbreak of the virus was Liberians' fault, saying that the outbreak is a sign of warning from God.

Admittedly, Sen. Coleman noted that the Ebola virus is killing more people and assumed that more people are yet to die from the virus. According to Sen. Coleman, what is happening in West Point shows that the government is robust in trying to illuminate the prevalence of the virus, adding that what is happening in a suspected outbreak area can happen anywhere once there is a suspicion.

"What is obtaining here shows that government is not alone in its fight," the Grand Kru Senator and former Minister of Health & Social Welfare said, adding that there are other partners who have the community at heart.

Though the virus is not in Grand Kru, Coleman, also a medical practitioner said massive awareness is being carried out so as to prepare the citizens for any potential outbreak He then concluded by urging the citizens of West Point to remain calm, noting that their community is not the only community that is being quarantined as a result of Ebola.

371 of 500 DOCUMENTS



The Analyst


September 04, 2014


Gov't Extols U.S. Contributions to Ebola Fight


BYLINE: Sallu K. Swaray


LENGTH: 495 words


The Minister of Information Cultural Affairs and Tourism, Lewis G. Brown, II, has praised the government and people of the United states for the numerous contributions that country has made in Liberia in assisting in the fight against the deadly Ebola viral disease. 

Extolling the United States for its assistance towards Liberia's anti-Ebola efforts, Minister Brown said that the U.S. Military has trained 230 Armed Forces of Liberia (AFL) Personnel on the proper use of the personal protective equipment (PPE), the safe handling of patients, securing health sites, escorting humanitarian and medical personnel.

Addressing journalists at the ministry's regular Ebola update briefings, Minister Brown said the training is part of "U.S. Onward Liberty", a five-year program run by the U.S. Department of State and Defense to support and strengthen the Armed Forces of Liberia.

Mr. Brown said the Government and people of Liberia are grateful to the United States for the supports, noting that Liberia is equally appreciative to friendly governments, including the Government of Sweden, which recently donated several tons of disinfectants and other medical supplies to the government of Liberia.

The MICAT boss further lauded the Government of the People's Republic of China, which the minister noted was the first country to have responded to the Ebola situation in Liberia and for their generous contributions of over US$1.7 million worth of consignment to Liberia towards the Ebola fight.

Mr. Brown said the Ebola Treatment Response Agency (ETRA) of the Defense Department in charge of countering weapons of mass destruction provided PPE to the Liberian Government, including a surgical gown, protective overalls and gloves as well as decontamination hand sprayers.

Regarding the fight against Ebola in Liberia, the MICAT boss recounted that the United States Government has already committed more than US$21 million to combat the disease in West Africa. Mr. Brown indicated that since the outbreak, the U.S has lifted funding amounting to US$1.7 Million that is being used to provide direct food assistance to Ebola patients in Liberia.

A 26-man disaster response team (DRT) is already present in the country, Sierra Leone and Guinea to oversee the U.S. Government's response to the Ebola crisis, the Information Minister said.

According to Minister Brown, the Atlanta-based Control for Disease Prevention has sent more than 70 disease control experts to West Africa that are providing technical expertise to national public health institutions and agencies to help protect and prevent the spread of the Ebola Virus.

He stressed that the CDC in partnership with the Global Alert Network Response Team and the U.S. National Institute of Health has already established the second Ebola Testing Laboratory in Liberia, which he added, is a mobile testing laboratory at the ELWA Campus to short end the response time of test for patients at the largest facilities currently in Liberia.

372 of 500 DOCUMENTS



The Analyst


September 04, 2014


'Ebola Virus Will Be Contained' - Disease Control Center


BYLINE: Edwood N. Dennis


LENGTH: 1143 words


Barely a day after United States President Barrack Obama announced the U.S. Government's preparedness to work with West African Ebola inflicted countries, the Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has again assured Liberia and other afflicted countries of a comprehensive approach that would lead to the containment of the deadly Ebola viral disease from West Africa; reports The Analyst's Edwood N. Dennis.

Since this year, three West African countries, including Guinea, Liberia and Sierra have been plagued with the Ebola pestilence, a situation which has triggered supports from international agencies and friendly nations to Liberia and other neighboring countries. 

Nigeria lately joined the fight against Ebola adding to afflicted countries that are now getting international attention for the containment of the virus in the region. The CDC said it was stepping up its partnership to get Liberia and the rest of the sub-region out of the health nightmare, but emphasized the need for more community treatment centers and the training and engagement of local medical practitioners.

In a teleconference with journalists in America and in other parts of the world, including Liberia on Wednesday, the Director for the CDC's Center for Global Health (CGH), Dr. Thomas Kenyon, has expressed confidence that the virus will be contained in Liberia and the sub-region with the present engagements of the governments and the involvement of the international partners including the United States.

The United States' top disease control expert and head of the CDC further told journalists during the teleconference that Ebola outbreak in the capital cities of the affected countries was unprecedented and shocking to the rest of the world.

He indicated that the nations of the world need to learn from the response process by both effected country's governments and the international partners. The virus, he said, is spreading rapidly in Liberia, Guinea and Sierra Leone with Liberia being the worst in the response action and approach to controlling the disease. If nothing is done, the situation would go to an alarming ratio within the borders of countries currently experiencing the outbreak, Dr. Kenyon said.

The Ebola disease, Dr. Kenyon explained, is preventable; "I wondered how come that the virus become prevalent in capital cities of the countries." In Monrovia, Ebola has become the nightmare for the residents, ruining the social-cultural behavior of the people. Liberians' gesture of greeting has been handshake with the snap of the fingers, but this gesture has to abruptly stop due to health restrictions occasioned by the outbreak of Ebola in the country, especially in metropolitan cities.

Billboards, fliers, broadcasts, newspaper pages and jingles are running messages, including "No Touching, No Handshake... " amongst others to the people, a reason for which residents become to eschew each other in the fear of transmission of the virus amongst the populace.

Besides, most Liberian dishes usually have dried meant as cherished ingredients, which is now restricted from the time of the outbreak of the Ebola virus, while they care for and mourning for relatives and love ones in time of death has also been restricted as measures against the spread of the Ebola virus which can also be contracted from monkeys and other bush meats.

Addressing the teleconference, Dr. Kenyon said people should stop ignoring the facts about the danger of the virus; rather he counseled that residents should apply every serous health tip available to them in preventing the Ebola virus.

He mentioned staying away from already sick and dead people who have shown every sign of the Ebola virus, noting that by that, the possibility of controlling the disease from spreading is achievable. He, however noted that people contacting the disease were not far from the possibility of being cured when the necessary antibiotic medication are provided and served them at the treatment centers that would be set up around the countries.

"Those who are treated at the treatment sites and returning in communities need to undergo a psycho-social program conducted by those with the professional qualification in psycho-source works from these nations that are under the threat of the virus," he said.

The director for the Center for Disease Control and Prevention further noted that it was impossible for Ebola survivors to regain consciousness of living with other people without psychosocial counseling, considering the hope lost as a result of dejection experienced during their time of difficulties while suffering the Ebola disease.

On isolation of Ebola stricken countries, Dr. Kenyon indicated that one of the best ways of preventing the virus rather than isolating nations by closing airports to travelers was proper screening and regular temperature testing of people coming and exiting the various airports and borders for other destinations.

Dr. Kenyon stressed the need for the construction of more Ebola treatment facilities in communities around the countries affected, including Liberia, as a measure of containing the virus so as to ease the problem of overcrowding of established centers provided for responding to people contacting the virus.

Facilities constructed, he stressed, should always remain open and proactive to ably respond to the outbreak if Liberia (or other countries affected) and the international community are to achieve a positive mark in fighting against the Ebola virus, which according to him has now become a global threat. He accentuated that upon constructing and making operational more Ebola treatment Centers the next thing is the recruitment and training of more nurses and health workers in Liberia and other affected countries by international health organizations combating the virus.

He said the fight against the Ebola virus do not really need the involvement of a large number of expatriates to do the job; the local health workers instead are suitable for taking up the responsibility and challenge when they are recruited and properly trained in handling Ebola cases and patients.

Dr. Kenyon then concluded that it is abundantly clear that the threats the virus has posed to Liberia and the already affected countries is serious to the extent that it has made it impossible for anyone of these nations to stand alone in fighting the virus, adding that the objective of containing the virus is hardly achievable without the direct participation of the USA and other partners.

Also speaking during the teleconference, the Special Assistant to the President and Senior Director at the National Security Council, Madam Gayle Smith emphasized the USA government's commitment through bilateral engagements to work with governments in supporting the require efforts that would lead to the elimination of the virus in the sub-region.


LOAD-DATE: September 5, 2014


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

373 of 500 DOCUMENTS



DAILY MAIL (London)


September 4, 2014 Thursday


I'M FINE! EBOLA NURSE WALKS OUT OF HOSPITAL


BYLINE: BY NEIL SEARS


LENGTH: 315 words


THE British nurse infected with ebola walked out of a London hospital yesterday - free of the disease he feared would kill him.

And William Pooley, 29, who caught the lethal virus while helping sufferers in Sierra Leone, said that to the delight of his mother, he can't return there - because his passport was incinerated amid fears it was contaminated. 

Mr Pooley, who said he felt wonderfully lucky' to have made a full recovery, talked about his ordeal in a Press conference at the Royal Free Hospital in Hampstead.

He had been treated in an isolated tent in a sealed-off special unit since being flown to Britain by the RAF 11 days ago.

Chillingly, he first learnt he had the disease when, after falling asleep, he was awoken by a World Health Organisation doctor who did not even have to speak - because the anti-infection suit and face mask he was wearing said it all.

Mr Pooley said: I'd had a blood test in the early afternoon, then went to bed. I was woken that evening by one of the WHO doctors in full PPE [personal protection equipment], so I knew it was bad news.

I was worried I was going to die, I was worried about my family, I was scared.'

Asked whether he was going to return to West Africa, Mr Pooley said: They incinerated my passport, so my mum will be pleased to know I can't go anywhere. I'm going back to Suffolk this afternoon and I'm most looking forward to seeing people in the village, and just relaxing in the nice countryside.'

The nurse - who spent last night at his parents' home in Eyke, near Woodbridge - was modest about his decision in July to volunteer at an ebola clinic.

He said: When ebola started, everyone was frightened and concerned. It was something engulfing the country, so it was just natural. I was in a place to help.

I wouldn't change my decision. To look after people when they're really suffering - that's what being a nurse is all about.'

© Daily Mail

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

374 of 500 DOCUMENTS




The Daily Telegraph (London)


September 4, 2014 Thursday  
Edition 2;
National Edition


"They incinerated my passport. My mum is pleased to know I'm not going anywhere';
"They incinerated my passport. My mum is pleased to know I'm not anywhere'


BYLINE: Sarah Knapton


SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 15


LENGTH: 972 words


WILLIAM POOLEY, the British nurse who contracted Ebola in West Africa, was at home with his family in Suffolk last night after recovering from the virus.

Mr Pooley, 29, who became infected while treating patients in Sierra Leone, said he had no plans to return to the country and joked that his mother would be pleased that his passport had been incinerated.

He was evacuated 12 days ago by the Royal Air Force and underwent treatment in an isolation tent at the Royal Free Hospital in London. 

Yesterday he was discharged by doctors who said he was clear of the virus and no longer contagious.

Mr Pooley said he had feared he would die and felt "wonderfully lucky" to have survived the disease, which has killed 57 per cent of sufferers in the outbreak sweeping West Africa.

"I am most looking forward to seeing all the rest of my family, seeing friends, seeing people in the village and just relaxing for a few days, and spending some nice time in the Suffolk countryside," he said.

"They incinerated my passport. My mum will be pleased to know that I am not going anywhere at the moment.

"It hasn't affected how I feel about my career. My work in Sierra Leone is a real privilege; to go to look after people when they are suffering. That's what being a nurse is all about.

"I have no regrets. But I need some time. I don't know exactly what the medium term holds."

More than 1,500 people have died from the disease in Liberia, Sierra Leone, Guinea and Nigeria and double that number have been infected. The World Health Organisation has warned that there could be 20,000 victims before the outbreak is brought under control.

Mr Pooley described how he was tested for the disease after feeling sick and was woken by a doctor from the WHO.

"He was in PPE (personal protective equipment) - I knew it was bad news.

"The lowest point was immediately after I was told really. It suddenly hit me that I would have to tell my parents. That was the hardest thing. I was worried that I was going to die."

The nurse was flown back to Britain on August 24 and treated with the experimental drug ZMapp.

He suffered high temperatures and some stomach problems but avoided the worst symptoms.

He praised the "world-class care" he received at the Royal Free Hospital and thanked the Government and the RAF for getting him home so quickly.

He added: "I was very lucky in several ways: firstly in the standard of care that I received, which is a world apart from what people are receiving in West Africa, despite various organisations' best efforts.

"The other difference is that my symptoms never progressed to the worst stage of the disease - people I have seen dying horrible deaths. I had some unpleasant symptoms but nothing compared to some of the worst of the disease, especially when people are dying.

"The level of care and the level of skilled professionalism and compassion that I received is not the same in West Africa."

Recalling his time in Sierra Leone, he said: "I have mixed memories, some great memories and some horrible memories - lots of people dying.

"But also some wonderful memories of people going home, people showing massive spirit and cheer, despite the horrible conditions, the truly heroic people that I worked with, people that went on to get sick, so it is a massive mix of memories."

After more than a week in an isolation chamber, Mr Pooley appeared in public for the first time yesterday.

Describing the experience of being isolated, he said: "It was really busy, especially for the first few days - there was lots going on.

"I was constantly doing my obs (observations). I was having fluids and blood tests, things like that.

"So I was really busy actually and I didn't have a lot of time to really ponder the full potential of the illness." He said that coming out of the isolation tent had been a "special moment" and expressed his gratitude to health staff who found supplies of ZMapp, which is running out across the world.

Dr Michael Jacobs, the infectious diseases consultant who treated Mr Pooley, said the nurse posed no contagion risk to members of the public. However, the doctor said not enough was known about the disease for him to be able to say whether Mr Pooley was now immune. He said it was likely he could still be infected by a different strain.

Dr Jacobs added: "The virus is clear from the body and there is no risk to the wider community in any way."

Mr Pooley's case provides more evidence that ZMapp may be a cure for the disease.

Last week a study showed that the drug cured 100 per cent of monkeys who were infected with the illness.

William Pooley's recovery adds weight to claims that the experimental drug ZMapp can cure Ebola.

The drug is a blend of three laboratory-made antibodies designed to neutralise the virus.

Two US doctors who were infected with Ebola while working in Liberia recovered after being given the drug. The treatment reversed symptoms including excessive bleeding, rashes and liver damage.

However, it is not known whether they were saved by the drug or simply got lucky. About 47 per cent of those infected in the current outbreak have survived without treatment. Previous epidemics have killed more than 90 per cent of those infected.

Mr Pooley's disease was caught early and he was treated before symptoms could take hold. At least two other patients treated with ZMapp have died, possibly because help got to them too late.

Research published last week in the journal Nature suggested that 18 rhesus monkeys infected with Ebola all made a complete recovery after being given ZMapp. Three untreated animals died.

Ebola kills by overwhelming the immune system and sending the body into shock as blood pressure drops to dangerous levels. Where ZMapp has been unavailable, management of the Ebola outbreak in Africa has been confined to palliative care and preventing transmission.

Sarah Knapton

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

Cured of Ebola, now stay at home, son

Watched by his clearly delighted mother, William Pooley, the British nurse who contracted the Ebola virus in Sierra Leone, arrives home in Eyke, Suffolk, yesterday after being given the all clear by doctors. He joked that his passport had been incinerated and his mother, Jackie, was 'pleased'

The Guardian (London) - Final Edition


September 4, 2014 Thursday


Corrections and clarifications


BYLINE: Column editor


SECTION: GUARDIAN LEADER PAGES; Pg. 33


LENGTH: 294 words


A report on the Ebola outbreak in west Africa said that the World Health Organisation estimated last week that 20,000 people had been infected over three months. In fact WHO did not say that: it estimated that 20,000 people could be infected, even if the outbreak is brought under control within three months (World must use its military assets to assist fight against Ebola, leading doctor tells UN, 3 September, page 16). 

* The GMB union claimed the majority of Amazon staff earn £6.39 an hour in a story about an appeal by the union to Co-operative members to oust the online retailer's lockers from the mutual's grocery stores. Amazon was unavailable for comment at the time the article was written but following publication asked us to point out that its permanent staff earn a minimum of £7.10 an hour and that outside of the runup to Christmas about 80% of employees at its warehouses are permanent (Call for Co-op branches to oust Amazon lockers, 15 August, page 30).

* Because of an editing error, two Manchester City footballers' names appeared in the wrong order in a piece (Di Maria won't solve central problem that haunts United, 26 August, page 4, Sport). It was Fernando who was "a £12m bargain from Porto", not Frank Lampard.

The readers' editor's office looks at queries about accuracy and standards. Email reader@theguardian.com including article details and web link, or find us on Twitter @GdnReadersEd. You can also write to The readers' editor, Kings Place, 90 York Way, London N1 9GU; or phone +44 (0)20 3353 4736 between 10am and 1pm UK time Monday to Friday excluding public holidays. The Guardian's policy is to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Contacts for Guardian departments and staff can be found at gu.com/help/contact-us.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2014 Guardian Newspapers Limited
All Rights Reserved


377 of 500 DOCUMENTS




The Guardian (London) - Final Edition


September 4, 2014 Thursday


'I feel lucky to be alive,' says Briton who survived Ebola: Nurse gets all-clear after Sierra Leone evacuation: Aid worker treated with experimental drug ZMapp


BYLINE: Lisa O'Carroll


SECTION: GUARDIAN HOME PAGES; Pg. 8


LENGTH: 742 words


The first British Ebola patient, Will Pooley, said yesterday he felt "wonderfully lucky" to be alive after he was given the all-clear by doctors at a north London hospital.

The volunteer nurse was discharged yesterday morning from the isolation unit at the Royal Free hospital in Hampstead, north London, days after being given the experimental drug ZMapp.

He said he feared for his life after catching the disease two weeks ago while working with Ebola patients in Sierra Leone. 

"I was worried I was going to die," Pooley, 29, said at a press conference. "I was worried about my family. I was scared."

He said he felt a "kind of reprieve" that others could not get in west Africa, where the Ebola epidemic has claimed more than 1,500 lives.

Looking gaunt but happy, he praised the "world-class" treatment he had received at the hospital after being evacuated by the RAF. Asked how he felt to have pulled through from a disease that can kill within four days of symptoms showing, he replied: "Wonderfully lucky."

Dr Michael Jacobs, the infectious diseases consultant who led a care team of dozens, declared Pooley totally free of the virus and of no risk to others. "The great thing is once someone has recovered from Ebola as Will has, (he) is no longer infectious to anyone else . . . There is no risk to the public in any way," he said.

Pooley planned to return to his family home in Eyke, Suffolk and said he was not averse to returning to Sierra Leone where he helped treat Ebola patients. The only problem was his passport had been incinerated, something that pleased his mother, Pooley joked.

He was airlifted to the hospital 10 days ago, and was treated inside a plastic tent designed to isolate his care team from any contact with the virus. Pooley said the moment doctors told him "the viral load had come down" he knew he was over the worst. "Coming out of the tent was a special moment," he said.

He said he was fortunate his illness did not progress to the potentially deadly phase typical of Ebola including vomiting and internal bleeding.

"I had some unpleasant symptoms but not the worst. I never had vomiting for example," he said. "I had some pretty high temperatures at times . . . I had some chills. I had some gastrointestinal symptoms as well, but nothing as bad as in west Africa."

Asked about the lowest point of his ordeal, the nurse said it was the thought of breaking the news to loved ones.

"There was no point when I thought 'God, I am going to die', but the thought of telling my parents - that was the worst thing. No one wants to upset their parents in that way."

Pooley had been given the experimental drug ZMapp last week and said he felt this may have helped his recovery.

"It was a long intravenous infusion. It ran over 12 hours. We don't know - there's no real way of telling what impact it had. But a day or so after having it I was feeling a lot better," he said.

"The numbers in terms of my viral load were much improved. We don't know whether that was down to ZMapp or whether that would happen anyway," he said.

ZMapp was also used on the two US doctors who recovered from Ebola but at least two others who received it as part of their treatment have died.

Jacobs sounded a note of caution about any plans Pooley may have to return to Sierra Leone. "Will will have immunity, but I don't think we understand enough about it to say to Will that he is completely protected from Ebola in the future," he said.

Pooley had been working in a hospital in the city of Kenema, the main centre of the Ebola outbreak, when he tested positive.

"I wouldn't change my decision to go out there, I have no regrets. I am more committed than ever to nursing," he said.

Describing the moment he was told he had Ebola, he said he had been feeling unwell and gone home after getting a blood test. He knew the worst had happened when he was woken by a World Health Organisation nurse dressed in full protective clothing. "It was a bit disturbing to get that diagnosis. I suppose I was half expecting it because I was feeling ill.

"And immediately I was surrounded by a team of people that all they wanted to do was look out for my best interests.

"I spoke to the high commissioner in Sierra Leone and doctors, and immediately I knew there were lots of people looking out for me and that was a massive comfort."

Dr Michael Jacobs

Captions:

Pooley at home in Suffolk after being discharged from the Royal Free Hospital in London Photograph: Rob Howarth/Albanpix

378 of 500 DOCUMENTS




Guardian.com


September 4, 2014 Thursday


UK government urged to allow NHS staff to help Africa's fight against Ebola


BYLINE: Lisa O'Carrolltheguardian.com


LENGTH: 420 words


ABSTRACT

Most cost-effective way 'to control our health is control health of those around us', say tropical disease experts in the Lancet 

FULL TEXT

Leading tropical disease experts have called on the government to free up NHS staff to help fight Ebola, which is continuing to spread across west Africa.

Prof David Moor, of the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, and two of his senior colleagues say it is incumbent on the UK to share the burden that is crippling the already weak health systems in Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea - the three countries worst affected by the deadly virus. 

"We believe that in order to support the UK's response, the NHS must allow staff temporary leave of absence from their post to contribute to the global response.

"Consultant physicians, specialty trainees, and specialist nurses in specialties including infectious diseases, microbiology, virology, public health, intensive care and infection control are well placed to offer assistance and should be supported," Moore said in a letter to the Lancet. It is co-signed by Catherine Houlihan, a senior research fellow and Dr Ron Behrens, a clinician at the college.

They said they had anecdotal evidence of NHS doctors, nurses and other health professionals who had been refused unpaid leave or permission to go to west Africa in holiday time.

"We really have to think much bigger than the day to day. The best way to control our health is control the health of those around us. Studies have proven that. In the US, cost-benefit analyses showed that the best way to control TB was to assist the South American countries in controlling TB," said Behrens. "It is much more cost effective.

"We are a global community and as a society we depend on others. We have to take global support more seriously," he said.

Their intervention comes two days after the first British patient, Will Pooley, was declared completely clear of the disease after being treated at the Royal Free hospital in north London.

He said organisations such as the World Health Organisation and the King's Fund, which had volunteers in Sierra Leone, were all "desperate" to get skilled staff there.

NHS staff are trained in both risk assessment and use of personal protective equipment but they also have specialisms critical to the fight against the spread of Ebola including expertise in virology, microbiology and infection control.

"Their experience and new skills would enhance the NHS pool of expertise for similar events in the future," they said in their letter.


LOAD-DATE: September 4, 2014


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

379 of 500 DOCUMENTS




Guardian.com


September 4, 2014 Thursday


Ebola will take six to nine months to control, says WHO leader


BYLINE: Sarah Boseleytheguardian.com


LENGTH: 543 words


ABSTRACT

World Health Organisation director general Margaret Chan calls for global response and says stopping epidemic will cost $600m 

FULL TEXT

The Ebola epidemic can be stopped in its tracks, but it will take at least six to nine months and cost more than $600m (£365m), according to the director general of the World Health Organisation. 

Speaking in Washington, senior WHO leaders including director general Dr Margaret Chan, called for a massive global response to the outbreak and suggested it would take longer to control than has yet been assumed.

The Ebola outbreak is "the largest, most complex and most severe we've ever seen", said Chan and spreading at a pace that outstrips effort to control it.

Guinea, Liberia, Nigeria, Senegal and Sierra Leone have between them reported about 3,500 cases and 1,900 deaths. The latest spread is to Port Harcourt in Nigeria, where it is likely that the virus will have been transmitted to many people from an infected doctor.

Médecins Sans Frontières, which says its volunteer doctors on the frontline are overwhelmed, has called on UN member states to send in teams of military and civilian biohazard experts. WHO's assistant director general for global health security, Keiji Fukuda, just back from west Africa, acknowledged that there are not enough people with the necessary skills and training to deal with all the cases in the affected region.

He said: "We don't have enough health workers, doctors, nurses, drivers and contact tracers. Most of the infections are happening in the community, and many people are unwilling to identify themselves as ill. And if they do, we don't have enough ambulances to transport them or beds to treat them yet."

Families are forced to care for patients at home, putting them and their contacts at risk of infection because of the shortage of health workers and facilities, he said. Mobilising international financial support and additional health personnel is a top priority for scaling up the international response, he added.

Airline routes to affected countries also urgently need to be re-opened. Closures "have a huge impact," Fukuda said, impeding the flow of experts and supplies into Africa, and the outbreak itself is having a negative impact on the economies of Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone. "People need medical supplies, food, fuel, charcoal, and other provisions. We have to get it to them."

Fukuda pointed out that WHO had not recommended any travel restrictions, "except in cases where individuals have been confirmed or are suspected of being infected with Ebola virus disease or where individuals have had contact with cases of Ebola."

Dr David Nabarro, UN coordinator for the Ebola response, said the UN system is working together on 12 detailed steps for the global response, which he estimated will cost at least $600m and require "several thousand people to scale up our response by three to four times".

Urgent needs in the affected countries include communications and messaging, care for the infected and proper burials, diagnosis and contact tracing, health services for other conditions, transport and supplies, cash to pay health workers, medical services for responders, air and sea access, and strong coordination to avert economic downturns, says WHO.


LOAD-DATE: September 4, 2014


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2014 Guardian News and Media Limited or its affiliated companies
All Rights Reserved
Registered in England and Wales. No. 908396
Registered office: PO Box 68164, Kings Place, 90 York Way, London N1P 2AP

The Inquirer (Monrovia)


September 04, 2014


Dolo's Town Boosted By Police Visit


LENGTH: 693 words


Amidst the scare of Ebola and the subsequent quarantining of the community, the police Community outreach team on Tuesday, September 2 visited Dolo Town near Harbel to provide reassurance to the people that all efforts will be made by the government to cater to their needs.

It's the second in a series of outreach programs being executed by police authorities after a successful launch in West Point two weeks ago to spread the message of hope and to provide tips to residents on how to prevent contracting the deadly Ebola Virus. 

The police convoy was greeted by jubilant residents who lined the routes to the Market center to welcome the Inspector General and delegation as well as listen to the message.

At a brief ceremony, Police Inspector-General, C. Clarence Massaquoi who led an array of senior officers, and accompanied by the Head of the United Nations Mission Police in Liberia (UNPOL) Commissioner Gregory Hinds said government was concerned about their plight and would do anything to provide the much needed humanitarian assistance while they are being quarantined.

Inspector General Massaquoi said the Police was delighted to visit the area as part of its community outreach programme to engage in public awareness on the prevention and spread of the deadly Ebola Virus that has caused the community to be quarantined by the Liberian Government.

"Our presence is to show that we love you and will not abandon you", Police Inspector General Massaquoi told the enthusiastic crowd as he distributed Ebola and Crime Prevention materials to the community of Dolo Town.

The Police Boss used the occasion to remind that they have a responsibility to ensure that the community is free of the deadly virus by listening to advice of Health Workers and engaging in activities that would curtail the further spread of the disease.

"The Government and its International Partners are doing all in their power to fight this deadly Ebola Virus, but it is also incumbent upon you the residents of Dolo Town to also make sure that you cooperate in the fight". We all have to fight to kick Ebola out of Liberia" drawing the crowd to chant in support.

He said the police will remain engaged with the various communities in the fight against the virus.

The police presented thermometers, safety gloves, and dozens of T-shirts with inscriptions of Ebola messages, symptoms and preventative measures.

In Special remark, the UNPOL Commissioner of Police spoke the UMNIL commitment to assist the Liberian Government in the fight against Ebola. He said the UN Police was working collaboratively with their Liberian National Police in ensuring that the mandate of the police was implemented without hindrance. UNPOL recently donated six Nissan 4×4 Jeeps to the LNP for deployment in communities severely affected by the Ebola scourge.

Earlier, Margibi County Statutory District # 2 Superintendent Henric Marcus Speare welcomed The Police Hierarchy to the township and expressed gratitude that the Inspector General Massaquoi and his team of Senior Officers had come to the town to identify with the people.

Also in a show of support for the Inspector Massaquoi and the police efforts, a local charity, Crowd '50 donated an assortment of food items valued at over two thousand United States Dollars to the Dolo's Town residents.

The items included 50 bags of 25kg of rice, 20 three-gallon of vegetable oil, four bags of 50kg of sugar, two bags of flour and 150 sacks of mineral water.

The President of Crowd '50, Samuel Wonwi Thompson said his organization support to the residents was a way of identifying with their plight and to boost police efforts to provide humanitarian assistance in addition to their official mandate of protecting life and property.

Crowd '50 was founded in the 1980's by Liberian men born in the 1950's from various professional backgrounds to cater the needs to Liberians nationwide.

Responding, various speakers representing the religious, youth and other groups hailed the police for the gesture and their continuing protection. They described the police as a friend of the community who was also ready and willing to render assistance to them when called upon.

The Inquirer (Monrovia)


September 04, 2014


Gov't Adjusts Prices for Rice, Others


BYLINE: Timothy T. Seaklon


LENGTH: 460 words


The Government of Liberia has adjusted the prices of rice, Liberia's staple food as well as other essential commodities on the Liberian market. The government's action comes at a time when businesses are hiking prices due to the outbreak of the Ebola virus.

Information Minister, Lewis Brown, announcing the adjusted price listing yesterday at the Ebola News Briefing held in Monrovia said, "This is not the time for businesses to impose another level of suffering on our people while we are fighting the Ebola disease." 

Minister Brown urged consumers to pay the adjusted prices and not succumb to a price increase strategy being put in places by businesses operating in the country.

According to the adjusted price listing, a bag of 25 kg bag of rice (Bellaluna IR64) be sold for US$16.00 in urban areas and US$20.00 in rural area. The 25kg bag Ofrice (Lady Noora) is at the price of US$ 14.00 in urban and US$19.00 in rural areas.

The 25kg bag of rice (Bellaluna 1001) is for US$14.00 in urban area and US$19.00 in rural while the 25kg bag of rice (Indian Parboiled IR64 five Percent broken) is available for US$16.00 in urban areas and US$20.00.

The Indian Parboiled 100 percent 25kg bag of rice is at US$14.00 in urban areas and US$20.00 in rural areas while Indian Parboiled Finda 100 percent broken rice in the 25kg bag is US$14.00 in urban areas and US$ 19.00 in rural areas. The Mario Indian Parboiled five percent broken rice in the 25kog bag is at US$14.00 in urban areas and US$19.00 in the rural areas.

The government also puts the wholesale selling prices of gasoline at US$4.00 and that of fuel at US$4.08. It estimated the retail pump price of gasoline at US$4.18 or L$345.00 and fuel at US$4.26 or L$ 355.00.

The government also adjusted the recently released transportation fares as from Broad Street to other parts of Monrovia and its suburbs.

According to the new transport fares from Broad Street to ELWA Junction is L$30.00 in a bus and L$55.00 in a taxi while from Broad Street to Red Light is L$45.00 in a bus and L$75.00 in a taxi.

The fare from Board Street to Freeport is L$15 in a bus and L$25.00 in a taxi. The fares also registered that from Broad Street to Logan Town is L$20.00 in a bus and L$30.00 in a taxi. It also noted that from Broad Street to Duala in a bus is L$20.00 and L$45.00 in a taxi.

From Monrovia to Brewerville and Hotel Africa is L$20.00 in a bus and L$25.00 in a taxi as a travel from Board Street to Po River is L$35.00 in a bus and L$60.00 in a taxi. From Board Street to VOA Junction in a bus is L$25.00 and in a taxi L$45.00.

From Broad Street to Gardnersville Supermarket is L$25.00 in a bus and L$50.00 in a taxi while a bus traveling from Broad Street to Bardnersville Estate is L$35.00 in a bus and L$60.00 in a taxi.

The Inquirer (Monrovia)


September 04, 2014


Confirmed Ebola Cases Swell to 412


BYLINE: Timothy T. Seaklon


LENGTH: 375 words


Statistics released by the Ministry of Health through the Ministry of Information relative to confirmed Ebola cases have swelled to 412. The statistics which was read by Information Minister Lewis Brown also noted that from Marc h 22 to September 1, 2014, there has been 396 confirmed Ebola death recorded. 

Minister Brown, addressing the daily Ebola Briefing session held at the Ministry of Information yesterday, the total suspected cases of Ebola stands at 512, total probable cases at 847 while cumulative confirmed, probable and suspected cases is at 1,771.The statistics further revealed that cumulative cases among health-care workers are 150 while cumulative death among health-care workers is 76.

Minister Brown said total death in confirmed cases are 396, total death in probable cases 381 total death in suspected Ebola cases 238 while the total death in confirmed, probable and suspected cases are 1,015.

The statistics which comes from the Ebola Situation Report number 109 also said the Cumulative Fatality Rate (CFR) from March 22 to September is 617.

Minister Brown reiterated that the Ebola virus has reached the stage of national crisis but stressed that Liberians can overcome this virus if together they can observe the preventive measures put in place.

The Information Boss further stressed that there are two major ways one can contract the virus and that is by touching sick person or a dead body. He urged all to refrain from these habits and continue the process of hands washing if the disease must be defeated.

Liberia has been at war with the deadly Ebola virus since March 2014 and has claimed the lives of medical doctors, health-care workers and hundreds of citizens.

Recently the World Health Organization (WHO) said the virus might claim about 20,000 lives in West Africa before it can be brought under control while the Director of the United States based Center for Disease Control and Prevention, Dr. Tom Frieden said the Ebola epidemic will worsen before it ceases.

In a related development, the head of Medicine San Frontier (MSF) told the United Nations that the fight against the Ebola virus in West Africa is more of a 'wild goose chase', information which has added more fear among people of the West African Sub-region.

The Inquirer (Monrovia)


September 04, 2014


Nine Bodies Discovered in Ganta


BYLINE: Solomon T. Gaye


LENGTH: 284 words


The remains of nine persons have been discovered in various communities in the commercial city of Ganta, Nimba County.

The bodies were discovered by the Ebola Task Force set up to fight the Ebola virus in Nimba County, our correspondent in the northern Liberian county has disclosed. 

Our correspondent quoted the Ganta City Mayor, Dorr Cooper as saying that some of the nine bodies discovered met their untimely demise over the weekend having been abandoned by their families. The City Mayor said some of the diseased left Ganta to some unknown destination where they died and that it has not been established by the Nimba County Health Team whether the nine persons died from the Ebola virus.

Since the outbreak of the Ebola virus in the country, report of people killed by the virus continues to swell in Nimba. In an interview, Mayor Cooper appealed to the international community and donors to extend their services in Nimba to help save the life of people affected by the deadly Ebola virus.

He said those quarantined by the Ebola Task Force along with the Nimba County Health Team are in dire need of food and medication as they await their treatment. The death tolls in the commercial city of Ganta continue to rise over the past three days as bodies are said to be almost every parts of the city thus, creating serious fear amongst local residents in the county.

Recently, a man believed to be in his 30s was discovered dead at the Monrovia parking station in Ganta. The man according to report is an employee of the Federation of Road Transport Union in Ganta and that the death of the man has created serious panic amongst workers of the Transport Union as they are attributing it to the Ebola virus.

The Analyst


September 03, 2014


Rep. Snowe Opposes Interim Gov't Agitation


LENGTH: 304 words


Montserrado County Representative Edwin M. Snowe has frowned on individuals calling for the configuration of an interim regime, using the country's current Ebola crisis as justification. He made the statement Tuesday when he served as guest panelist on the ELBC 99.9 Super Morning Show. 

Representative Snowe said the Ebola outbreak should not be used a political tool, and regretted that some people are using the recent decision to quarantine West Point and Dolo Town as if the government is punishing its own citizens. Rep. Snowe noted: "We can help our people without using the (Ebola) situation for political gains or without attaching a price tag to our assistance to the people."

Snowe, who is Montserrado District #6 Representative, pointed out: "Some people claiming to be Liberians are sitting out of the country, not knowing the ongoing situation and are calling for a change of government; they don't love this country."

He observed that the current fight against the deadly Ebola disease has plunged the country's economy into a state of regression that needs to be speedily recovered in order to guarantee the attainment of the country's development agenda. The lawmaker challenged Liberians to assist the government in recovering the country's economy as engaging in negative political undertakings will only hamper government's effort to strengthen the growth of the country.

Meanwhile, Snowe has said the statement that Liberia's situation will get worse before it gets better as observed by a visiting American official should not be taken lightly, noting that every Liberian must now begin to redirect their efforts in assisting the government in the fight against the Ebola virus. "Liberians are a resilient people who are strong and we can fight this disease and eradicate it from this country together," he said.
